=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Light worker placement with card set collection.

This 2-4 player game is about collecting resources in order to acquire buildings (which are points), and cards (which are minimal immediate benefits and potentially large endgame points), while maintaining a steady food supply in order to feed your meeples (people).

The game mechanic is the tried (tired?) and true worker placement, and the options are: 1) resources, of which there several- wood, clay, stone, and gold- in that order of value and difficulty to obtain, 2) food, which is needed to feed your workers each and every round, 3) farms, which provide a guaranteed food income each round, 4) tools, which increase the probability of your obtaining resources/food, 5) buildings, which can be built for points using specified resources, 6) "loveshack", which produces an extra worker, 7) cards, which again require resources, and which give small immediate benefits, but are really collected for endgame considerations- there are several different types of point modifiers based on number of endgame buildings, workers, etc., as well as set collection of different culture cards.

In order to obtain resources, the new (old) in vogue dice-rolling mechanic is used- roll a dice for each worker placed in an area and count the number of dice pips.  Divide this number by the appropriate factor (ie: 2 for food, 3 for wood, 4 for clay, etc, rounding down), and that's how many resources you obtain.  You can modify the results with tools, with the tool value being added to the number of dice pips.  Obviously, this can result in some spectacularly good or bad results on any given roll- in some ways this is thematic, but...

Turn order rotates each round, and as with all placement games, it's always better to go first rather than last. You need to feed your people each round (1 food per person) or you lose 10 points per round- although this is apparently a viable strategy to ignore feeding and take the 10 point hit.  The game ends when you run out of cards or a stack of buildings is depleted.  The components are great, and the game seems to scale well (well not really, it plays quite well as a 2-player, 3-player is OK, and 4-player has all of the issues outlined below in abundance, and is no longer playable as such IMO).

Now my issues with the game: 1) it is FAR TOO LONG for what it is, and 2) turn order is a bit too significant a factor- there is no turn-order change placement like in Caylus, Age of Empires III, and Pillars of the Earth.  Basically if you randomly start the game as 4th player, good luck to you, and oh by the way, if you're not a lucky dice roller, good night!  If this game played in 45 minutes it would be a pretty decent albeit light game.  If there hadn't been about 10 games of this nature released before it, it might be a really good game.  As it is, it's a very derivative, lengthy luckfest.  That said, the theme and ease of gameplay MIGHT still get it to the table occasionally, but again the length is the biggest issue.  If I want to play a light worker placement game, I'll go Pillars of the Earth everytime, hands down.

Edit: OK, well now I've played this about 230 times on BSW (I only play 2-player), and with about a 70% win percentage and nothing close to lucky rolls (I suck at rolling, even computer generated rolls!), I have to admit there's a pretty good amount of strategy hidden in this game, for 2-players at least.  I'd probably rate this about a 8 for 2-players. 

Own the [boardgame=107576]Style is the Goal[/boardgame] expansion and the [boardgame=147541]Casino[/boardgame] and [boardgame=238004]the Mammoth[/boardgame] promos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Pretty dull worker-placement fare, with limited thematic integration. The pictures are all very nice, but ultimately you are swapping resources for un-named cards without really telling any form of story: there is no progression. This is where Agricola excels over superficial games like this one (and others in the genre). The dice-rolling makes the game frustrating at times and adds little. The game works and is not unenjoyable, but it's a tired genre and this is not the most exciting example.

RATING: 7
2 plays / 4 players

LIKE: Excellent gateway game. Tiny bit of engine building with a lot of push-your-luck mechanisms and dice rolling. I like the arc of the game from getting resources to scoring points on the cards. Many ways to mitigate the dice rolls.
DISLIKE: Randomness in the dice. A little on the lighter side of the weight spectrum.

OVERALL: Good to great game, depending on the level the players are at.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.73
A great introductory worker placement game.  Not as "pure" as others due to resource collection being governed by dice rolls, but have only played a couple of games where the probabilities swung wildly in favor of or against a player so the random element here isn't necessarily a killer.

A large percentage of the game's points are determined in the end-game scoring, thus it can be difficult to assess mid-game just how well one is playing relative to other players (absent paying very close attention to what special cards each opponent has purchased).    


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fantastic worker placement. I enjoy the dice factor contributing to the game. Mechanics are balanced. 100/200 point markers needed to be included in the base set.

RATING: 8
Probably my most played worker placement game.  Caverna is better, but its so much more of an undertaking that Stone Age just hits the table more.  SA is just simple enough that you can play it with people that are intimidated by Rosenberg-level complexity, but it has enough depth that I don't feel I'm playing a watered-down worker placement game.  Love the way the dice mechanic allows for random "Woo!" and "Argh!" table moments but gives players lots of control over how big of risks they'd like to take.

Why it's previously-owned:
I really enjoy playing Stone Age, and was revitalized when playing it with its expansion.  
However, when playing with relatives, they also really seemed to latch onto this game and love it so I left this game with my relatives hoping to further their decent into true gaming madness.  We still have tons of other worker placement games to play so we don't miss this one too much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Played it and liked it.  It's very nice to look at, but it's just missing something.  It's just not very exciting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The word that comes to mind is elegant when I think about Stone Age. The gameplay is worker placement but everything just flows so well and fast. The theme is not total immersion but actions make sense and the amount of times the mating hut is referenced as a joke adds its own caveman references. The placing of workers once a round also adds the theme of the limited time each caveman had to do things. It also adds so much to the gameplay due to the limitation to maximise efficiency and importantly adds some player interaction. The rules are also easy to learn and plays in about an hour.

Downside is the dice rolls can be a problem for some if one has an issue with dice but that can be mitigated with tools in the game. 

In conclusion, definitely a modern game classic I will try to play more often. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Y'know what?  I like this game.  Yes, it's dicey and luck may equal win, but it's just fun!  I enjoy playing it and will rarely say no.  Plus the pieces and board are fantastic.  Rating raised from 7 to 8 (7/05/08).

EDIT (3/25/2016):  Rating lowered from 8 to 7.  Great game but the ios version, and me playing WAY too much of it, taught me that the strategies here are paper thin.  There's not much variation, despite the apparent randomness.  And while good/bad dice rolls can have a significant effect, there are ways (well, one easy way - tools) to mitigate them.  Overall, I've seen too much to really love this one again.  Still, it's a good, solid game, just not one I want to play very often any more.

RATING: 8.1
[b]Affordability[/b] - [microbadge=39229]
[b]Functionality[/b] - [microbadge=39229]
[b]Originality[/b] - [microbadge=39228]
[b]Quality[/b] - [microbadge=39229]
[b]Reusability[/b] - [microbadge=39227]
[b]Variability[/b] - [microbadge=39227]

[b]Solo Variant[/b] - [listitem=1129551]Stone Age SoloPlay[/listitem] by [user=GameRulesforOne]GameRulesforOne[/user] with Custom Expansion Variant

:thumbsup: The challenge of managing an entire civilization is real, and nearly every part of gameplay feels brilliantly thematic.
:thumbsup: Deciding on the resources at the start of the game adds to the challenge and is rather interesting each time.

[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]The steps taken at the end of each turn can be a little hard to keep track of, and may feel fiddly at times.
[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]The rules are rather in-depth and typically require extra time to look up definitions during play.

:thumbsdown: Certain moves and decisions feel somewhat scripted, since they typically always occur in certain situations.
:thumbsdown: The random assortment of building tiles and civilization cards, as well as luck, play a stronger role than strategic decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Bought at the UK Expo 2010 in Birmingham UK, from Games Lore. Excellent three/four player game - playable with two as well. No player elimination. Difficult to tell who is winning until the final count. Lovely pieces, good firm card board.

RATING: 8
FAMILY, STRATEGY

Players assume the role of prehistoric cavepeople who are trying to advance their civilization. Develop tools, hunt food, harvest lumber, and mine gold and stone in order to build dwellings and discover aspects of culture. The player with the most points wins!

Recommended with 2-4 players (best 4). 60-90 mins.

RATING: 7.6
:cry: :D :D :) Great light-medium worker placement. Enjoyable on its own merits; it would probably only be a 7.5, but gets bonus points because it is incredibly popular and is the #1 compromise game for people who like lighter games and people who want heavier ones. 

The only way this isn't fun is when not everyone understands how to fight a Starvation player. I played a tournament game once where the other players practically refused to take cards and drill huts, and mostly helplessly watched the guy win with like 250+ points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I bought this game around Christmas to play with my family. I had heard that 'worker placement' was all the rage, but I had not had the chance to try the mechanic before this game. I knew about games such as Caylus and Agricola, but I wanted to baby step into those. This turned out to be a great option.

The use of dice is extremely clever in this game. It is very strategic and I cannot understand the comments stating that this game is too luck orientated. Risk management does come into play and you should know when it's safe to gamble and when it's not. Learning this is part of the experience.

Everyone I've taught this game to has enjoyed the experience. I don't expect that to change with age. The dice, huts, and cards should add enough variation to keep the game feeling fresh every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a pretty bare-basics worker placement game. I might play again if I exhaust what I felt were slightly more fun (Castles of Burgundy) alternatives in my library. Essentially, it's the tried and true method of economic efficiency engines with extreme passive-aggressive spot-taking. That's by no means a negative at all and Stone Age does the genre proud by offering solid gameplay. The problem is that I cannot honestly rate this game high in replay value as Caverna and Feast for Odin do everything better.

RATING: 8
A really great worker placement game with a good amount of randomness.  The dice mechanic is a lot of fun, but the real element of chance comes from the distribution of certain powerful specialists on the boats.  Players need to decide if they want to reach for those powerful boats at the cost of their other plans in a given turn, and there's a lot of challenge to getting the timing correct.  While it may feel too luck-based for some, I think this adds a lot to the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Meh.  Decent worker placement with some things here and there, some dice rolling, this that and the other.  It's easy to teach, but there are a pile of tiles and the goods are just numbers on the trade-in-for-points wheel.  Scoring is also really obtuse because it's just matching bonuses.  To be honest, if I want a light worker placement I prefer Waterdeep because it's got more player interaction and less of the fuss involved in dice rolling for resources.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-4(4)

It's fine. Pretty accessible and the dice add some tension. The other mechanisms generally make the game interesting (tools, agriculture). Some parts feel mechanical (grabbing the special slots early).

I'm just not entirely convinced that there are multiple interesting victory paths. I mean, there are the huts and there are civ set cards and there are the civ multiplier cards.

The other issue is that it's pretty overbalanced. It's kind of annoying and pointless how mathematically balanced everything is. Wood = three pips and pretty much always converts to three points. Gold likewise with the number six. I mean, in Agricola at least you *feel* that wheat, veggies, sheep, pork, cattle, wood, reed, clay, and stone all have a different place in the game. In Stone Age all the resources will be variously randomly in demand or not depending on what hut (randomly) flips, and for the wild card huts it's just a straight conversion of pips spent into points. Bleh. The only distinction is one resource of any sort to feed (thus making food a good occasional play) and needing non-food resources to snag a Civ card (thus making wood more valuable). Otherwise, depending on the huts to flip, there's NO distinction between clay, stone, and gold. Overbalanced.

Likewise with the multipliers. Tools, farming, and extra people all give you extra actions and being able to cash in on these just depends on when and how the Civ cards come out.

I'm not as hot on this these days, but I'll play it. Others enjoy it fine and it looks gorgeous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Quite a pleasant worker placement game in a similar vein to Pillars of the Earth.  Like Pillars, Stone Age has randomness, though it's in the form of buckets of dice, so you can play the averages and take calculated risks.  Like several other worker placement games, interaction is limited to occupying a spot before an opponent.

My impression is of less going on than in Pillars, so that play is fast and smooth, if a bit repetitive.  Strategically, the game gives you options without overwhelming them in a mass of detail. Given that repetition, game length is on the high side.  If it played in an hour, I might actually want to own a copy.

Stone Age is lightly thematic, though there is one jarring bum note. Early agriculture was hugely labour intensive compared to hunter-gathering and yet the great advantage of farming over hunting in Stone Age is that crops require no meeples to tend them.  

The artwork is quite pleasing and functional.  Production quality is high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
A nice, quick medium-light game, but, after many plays, I am growing more and more dissatisfied with it, just like I did with Settlers of Catan, and for the same reason (the roll of the dice determine too much of the outcome for my tastes).

UPDATE: I no longer feel that the dice play too much of a factor.  The beauty of Stone Age is the degree to which you can mitigate the luck involved with respect to the dice.  Build a huge population so you don't have to worry about crappy rolls, or invest in tools to accomplish the same effect.  This is actually one of my favorite two player games.

RATING: 8
+ Interesting combination of worker placement and dice
+ At first, the game seemed mechanical without meaningful decision making. After few plays, the game is still mechanical, but it has plenty of meaningful decision making.
+ Simple enough to play with whole family
+ Good game for teaching the kids probability and expectation values
- Starvation strategy can be overpowered if the other players won't react
- The power of different cards vary substantially
- Some downtime while collecting the workers in the end of round

RATING: 7
This game doesn't hit the table very often anymore as other euros have taken its place.  It still stands out as being unique in the way dice are rolled and the luck of said rolls needs to be thought out and mitigated through other actions in game.  What I dislike about Stone Age is the fact that certain worker placement spots are obviously better than others so that typically makes the first few workers placed each round predictable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
The resource collection mechanic is a little bland, based on the luck of the dice.  This is offset by the fact the player has to decide how many of his workers to allocate in order to maximize that collection.

The rest of the game works extremely well and has nice interaction, in that only one worker can be placed on a desired card, building or tool area.  

Increasing the size of your family requires two workers, so you've got to time that just right.

RATING: 6
May 2011:  A very basic worker placement game, that feels a little weak for me.  Giving it a 7 of 10.  

March 2013:  It also feels very marginally thematic in the sense that the game is so very directly, and so obviously, about acquiring resources, following placement and dice rolls, to purchase huts and cards that truly have nothing to do with those resources in particular.  

Thus, this game is all basic and well-worn mechanics really, though the board and cards do seem to have nice cave-people graphics.  I just have no desire to play this game again, so I have to downgrade it to a 6.

I love Stone Age for its simplicity and love Agricola for its complexity.  =)

RATING: 9
One of our favorite worker placement game. Thank you Sam Healey from the Dice Tower for talking so much about this one. Love the theme and the artwork (my dream game room will have Michael Menzel game boards framed and mounted on the walls [I might have mentioned that before] )but most of all the game play. The resource gathering using the dice can be a bit random but it's easy to offset. The one thing we don't like about it is how the scores can go into the 100s. It's  just silly really. Why do the scores need to go that high? Our last game ended with a score of 265 to 242. That's insane. But it is the only dent in this otherwise flawless game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
No esta mal para pasar un rato pero no tiene mucha variedad en cuanto a las acciones posibles. Las partidas son todas bastante similares.

La cosa de tener que tirar los dados le da cierto toque aleatorio que le sienta muy bien. Al tirar los dados siempre tienes esa sensación de "a ver lo que me toca", "ojala salgan muchos 6s!!" que le da un encanto especial. 

pero...

Hay gente que detesta tirar los dados. Aquí lo haces siempre que deseas conseguir recursos y si no estás de suerte puedes recibir menos recursos de los esperados. Aunque el azar tiene mucho que ver en el juego existen tres formas de controlar tu producción:

La más obvia es empleando más trabajadores en la tarea para tirar más dados y tener más posibilidades de conseguir más recursos. A veces, si es vital conseguir un recurso concreto, no se debe escatimar trabajadores y "jugartela" hay que poner suficientes para asegurarse un mínimo aceptable.

Otra es fabricando y utilizando herramientas que modifican, a tu favor, las tiradas de dados de producción.

Finalmente siempre puedes ir a por las cartas que otorgan recursos directamente (sin  tirada) y encima proporcionan puntos de victoria.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Bastantes partidas no registradas.

Eurogame redondo de gestión de recursos ideal para jugar con no jugones ya que se explica en 7 minutos.

En su parte buena, es muy entretenido y variado gracias a cartas y tiles. Tiene mecánicas chulas y aunque jugar no es difícil, tiene la suficiente profundidad para rejugarlo con cierta frecuencia sin cansarte. Lo más positivo que puedo decir es que es muy redondo, nada sobra, nada falta y además las tiradas de dado le dan un punto muy divertido sin ser totalmente determinantes (se pueden mitigar con las herramientas).

En su parte mala, es un eurogame asequible con lo que eso implica. Si eres muy jugón, puede quedarse un poco corto para tí. Además, las mecánicas no son especialmente originales ni tampoco tiene tanto tema que te vayas a sentir un troglodita.

La expansión no la he probado, pero no la veo necesaria. Además creo que acabaría con el efecto de redondez que transmite el juego.

Un eurogame más, que a mi particularmente me gusta jugar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stone Age has a strong strategic worker placement element without the complexity that is Agricola.  The scoring system is based on several elements, and you are not able to do/buy everything you want to on a turn.  So you really have to balance your strategy and adapt to what others are doing.

The only stupid thing is that the box inserts and boards don't fit in the box.  This doesn't affect game play.

RATING: 7
Somewhat underwhelmed after the first face to face play, but hitting it up on BSW really opened the game for me.  There is luck and it does seem like there should be some kind of turn order compensation, but overall I think it's a very solid Euro.  Placement, dice, dice control, collection, the ability to emphasize scoring paths, controllable game length, blocking, all kinds of stuff really.  I want to play this much more than Notre Dame, Caylus, etc.  Rather enjoyed the theme after thinking about it too.  Surprisingly good with 2P!  Perhaps best?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
This is one of the few games that I can well and truly enjoy even when it's not going very well for me. There's just something about being able to blame the dice that takes the pressure off.

That said, while the dice are definitely very meaningful, it's very possible to play in a way where you're almost assured to get what you plan for and not feel like you're sacrificing actions to do it. I'd really like to play this game 4-player to get a feel for how much different it plays than in a 3-player game. I have the feeling the decision-making process is much more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Do dice dance when you are near?  When you pick them up, do they quake in your hands at the awesomeness of your luck?  Can you close your eyes and have them land on the table with exactly the values you pictured?  If you answered yes to any of these - you should own 2 copies of this game and make your living gambling.  If you more normal with dice and you are tired of Yahtzee, then this might be worth picking up.  If dice skitter away at your mere presence or crack and crumble at your touch then you should avoid this like a plague.  This game is capable of single-handedly destroying the very basis of probability and will leave you a worthless shell of randomization.  Is it luck driven?  Maybe just a wee bit...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I played three games in a 24 hour period (with practically everyone new to the game) and enjoyed all three games. Different numbers involved change the dynamics of what can be taken by whom and each player, after working out the rules, seems to have a different idea as to best strategy.
So far this seems to be the single worker placement game that I'll actually go out of my way to play.

2008-12-05 Have been informed that there was a problem in the rules interpretation (my fault) and so I may have to change my rating of this after a couple of games with the correct rules. I don't think it will impact on my enjoyment significantly though.
2008-12-10 Having played with the right rules I'm not changing my rating down, it may go up.
2008-12-31 Up it seems, my third 9.
2009-12-01 After a year it's dropped back. Mainly as a result of excessive 2-player games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've only played one game of Stone Age, and I really want to like it!  However, throughout the entire time I felt like I was just cashing in things for victory points.  There was no sense of progression, as there is nothing to work toward besides getting resources and then spending them on cards or huts (the latter give you no special powers and give you the exact same amount of victory points as your resources are worth, with no regard for how difficult those resources were to procure).  

Sure, there was the occasional blocking maneuver thrown in, as in other worker placement games, but the lack of interaction and sense of repetition really drags Stone Age down.  

I would like to play again to see if I'm really missing something.

RATING: 7.2
Lovely artwork, and the mechanics work very well, but they also feel rather abstract: You're gathering resources purely to score points (with each resource having a distinct scarcity level), not to actually use that type of resource for a specific purpose. Gameplay feels purely strategic, without a whole lot of actual tactics nor meaningful decisions once you've picked a direction. Has started to feel stale relatively swiftly.

RATING: 7.8
One of the new classics of hobby games.  A solid worker placement game with some interesting dice mechanics, fun theme, and smelly dice cup.

Much more interesting than the popular (but ultimately shallow) Lords of Waterdeep, but not nearly as engaging as something like Caylus or Agricola, it sits firmly in the medium-weight euro category.

The only reason I don't own this is because I have Alien Frontiers which I feel scratches the same itch, but I will happily play Stone Age if it's suggested.

RATING: 7
Absolutely gorgeous board and pieces.
The game play is very similar to most resource gathering, victory point purchasing games.  The twist is that you get a "random number" of resources when you collect them.

Unfortunately it is a raw random roll and it is entirely possible for you to come away empty handed.

I don't like that you can't really mitigate the luck.  It is possible to lose because of the roll of the dice without any mechanism to recover from it.  

I would like to see an expansion or variant that allows you to recover from really poor rolling.

RATING: 10
2 − 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I consider Stone Age more of a tactical drafting game than a worker placement game. The workers are your drafting currency while the civ cards, huts and raw goods are the resources you draft to convert to points. Each resource has differing levels of guaranteed and potential ROI and some resources simply require more currency than others. 

The civilization cards are what breathe life and longevity into the game as they are what make the resource valuations more challenging. In my first few games, I was concerned about the role of the dice. I'd say that the timing of availability and the tactical decisions surrounding the civ cards are much more significant than the dice rolls. As such, luck of the dice is no longer a concern. The part of the game I'm most leery about is the endgame where vindictive, non-optimal "blocking" can occur which ultimately can skew the final scores. At this point though after about 10 plays, the potential kingmaking plays tend to be minimized when playing with experienced players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Enjoyable game, great theme and looks like there are several strategies that could win. Prefer Cuba though.

(Pusztan azert, mert az emlitett jatekokban a kockadobasok eredmenyenek ismereteben cselekedhettem, mig itt a cselekvesem utan abszolut kiszolgaltatotta valtam Fortuna szamara.)
Eppen ezert lazba egyetlen pillanatig sem tudott hozni.
A megjelenese az utobbi idoben a HiG kiado magasra tett lecet is siman viszi, mar ami a jatek koriteset illeti! (doboz, tartozekok, dobozon talalhato informacio a szerzorol, designerrol, + zacsik - az utobbi piti dolog, de megis...)
Talan a ezzel a jatekkal kapcsolatos pozitiv dolgok vegere is ertem.

Sajnos a masodik jatekba mar bele-bele untam...

Ketszer ekkorat nem tevedhetek - a HiG kiado uj vonulatanak messze leggyengebb jateka! Egy ekes bizonyiteka annak, hogy megfelelo koritessel minden eladhato... (nekem is!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dec-29-2008
First game.  The game has great production values.  The meeples are unique and the resources have unique shapes that tell you what they are.  The only thing I am disappointed with though is that there are only 10 gold pieces.  It is pretty lame that the publishers did not provide enough.  Overall it is a good gateway game.  It is a really simple game to play.  You start with 5 cavemen that can gather resources, tools, make babies and purchase cards.  When gathering resources each caveman designated to gather resources represents a dice.  So if you put 4 cavemen to get wood, you roll 4 dice.  The sum of the dice results divided by the value of the resources would equal to the number of the resource you receive.  There is set collection as well for points in form of cards and converting resources to points by building buildings.  I think the publisher should have provided 4 sets of dice so that during the activation phase, everyone can roll their own dice to gather the resources since nothing in this phase will change the outcome.  The meat and potatoes of the game is during the cavemen placement phase.  This is when you decide what your cavemen will be doing.  The game should play half of the time if people have their own set of dice to determine the amount of resources they will get.  Overall a good game.
Initial Rating: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I only played this game once and I didn't enjoy it very much. After watching it on TableTop a few weeks ago I realized that it isn't quite as complex and I remembered and that I actually did enjoy the die rolling to determine resource gathering. I'd definitely want to play this again and may rate it higher once I do. 

Edit: Moved it up to a 7. I played with my brother and his friend and began to understand how it works a bit more. I still really appreciate the RNG of the worker placement for resources, but I do have a negative. Knowing which cards provide which multipliers at the end of the game is too predictable. Each time I've played, the person who goes hut heavy and gets the 3x hut multiplier blows the rest of the people out of the water. Additionally, the 'starvation' strategy should be punished more, so that if you starve once, it is -10, if you starve your people again is it -15 or -20, etc. The negative isn't bad enough to deter people from doing it. I still want to get it and play it, despite the nasty smelling cup.

RATING: 7
It's funny...upon playing a game that is so highly rated, enjoying the adventure, the dice cup feature, the myriad decisions to be made, and a beautiful board with great bits, I feel no compulsion to add this title to my collection.  Very odd, since all of the above have been individual reasons for me to purchase a game, and here they are all together. I don't know if it's because it feels like I'm playing Caylus and Pillars of the Earth at the same time, or if my opponents always seem to have a better grasp of strategies that work, I just don't feel the urge for it to take up shelf space...even stranger when you see some of the things that are already there collecting dust.  I'm usually willing to play if it's brought out, but I guess my feelings will just have to be unexplained for the time being.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2008[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2008[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 3/17/09, Rated: 9[/i]

Despite its Cro-Magnon theme, [i]Stone Age[/i] is a perfect example of the modern-day Euro game.  All of the trappings are there: a richly-saturated board, individual player mats, wooden bits galore, tiles, cards, coins, and dice.  Wait, strike that last item.  Dice aren't very [i]chic[/i] in Euro games, but they are present in [i]Stone Age[/i], along with a natural leather dice cup.

All of these components (except the dice) are used in a very familiar fashion.  Like [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=24480]The Pillars of the Earth[/thing][/i] before it, [i]Stone Age[/i] requires you to place workers to gather different resources.  These resources are then used to acquire victory points.  These mechanics should feel ancient by now, but [i]Stone Age[/i] manages to evolve towards simplicity.  There is no "ownership" of spaces like there is in [i][thing=18602]Caylus[/thing][/i]: you can place your workers in an open spot without agonizing about helping an opponent, too.  There is some contention for the best places (a fiddly rule that works), but overall the options are more balanced than the choices in [i][thing=24480]The Pillars of the Earth[/thing][/i].

There are a few different ways to score points.  The set-collection nature of the cards combined with the multiplying factor of upgrades requires forward planning, but so does resource collection when purchasing the different buildings.

Where do the dice come into play?  When collecting resources.  Here is the unique mechanic of [i]Stone Age[/i], which will be very catalytic.  Each worker figure placed at a specific resource location enables the owning player to roll one die.  The total number of "pips" rolled determines how many resources are collected.  It is possible to soften the blow of a bad roll by purchasing upgrades, but you can't completely mitigate the luck in this game.  Either you're okay with this quality, or you'll hate it.

In an ironical fashion, [i]Stone Age[/i] represents an evolution of the worker placement mechanic, even though its theme is from a more ancient time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Less stressfull and less of a challenge than Agricola (this may of may not be your thing).

RATING: 7
Stone Age is a solid game, a worker placement game where the actions and goals are easy to understand. It's not hard to be successful and earn some points, but skilled play gives big rewards.

It can be difficult to teach the scoring rules, as there are different elements that score immediately, score a certain value, score a variable value, multiply something else at the end of the game, or are multiplied by each other. Lords of Waterdeep has a more obvious do-quest-get-VP mechanic, and it's probably where I'd introduce people to worker placement.

RATING: 8
A bit of a miracle game this one. I hate most games with dice but somehow this one manages to overcome this genetic defect and evolve into a classic resource management game.

Build quality is very good with chunky tiles and excellent wooden tokens and meeple. Next the rules are very straight forward with sensible and highly effective variants to cope with 2&3 players as well as 4. The game can be explained and started in 10 minutes.

Most importantly there is significant player interaction. You have to keep an eye out for what the rest are up to and block them off when necessary. It seems there are several routes to victory so all in all it seems to lead the pack when compared to other games of this ilk (Pillars of the Earth etc).

And its on line at Yucata.com, who could ask for any more?

Well the 3expansion with the decorations actually. This expansion is such an improvements. I will only want to play with the expansion in future.

RATING: 5
Not sure what it is about this game I don't like.  Maybe it's because I do so poorly everytime I play.

After 4 plays:  I think I've figured out why I don't care for this game (having finally won my first game).  In every game I've played, victory is decided by the cards.  Generally, 2/3 of your total points will come from cards.  Though there may be several "secondary" strategies (thus as starvation, tools, farms, etc.) the main goal is to get as many cards as you can.  Your "secondary" objective is dictated by the cards you've managed to gain.  I generally don't care for games that appear to only have one strategy to win.

RATING: 10
It can drag, but when everyone knows what they're after, it can be one helluva game.  Learning it isn't hard.  Learning to be good at it takes a game or two.

I like the game, but I have to be ready to play to want to play this.

01-27-11:  Punched it to a 10 when I caught myself measuring pretty much every euro resource I've played against it.  In my opinion, this has it all when I want to explain what a good resource euro is.

The big thing in resource gathering games (not so much even worker placement as this one is), is you need to formulate a strategy and plan accordingly to this strategy.  

What's great about this, is that to anyone who has played just one of these types games before at any point in their life, you can see what someone is doing when they're doing it, and how much it's getting them, immediately---whereas in 90% of your resource euros, it's not readily obvious until 3-4 turns later when you're kicking yourself for letting the guy across the table corner the market on something.

As such, one can immediately react in basically whatever way he feels appropriate.  When he does, he's not limited by any strategy and path chosen initially.  All options are always on the table for everything at all times.  Whereas in most of your resource games, either changing-up a strategy or doing something offensive is a bit like doing a barrel roll with a B-52.  More often than not, for as bad as you want to do it, it's just not something that would be prudent given the immobility of the situation.

THEN, there's dice as that final element of, "Well, even the best laid plans of mice and men go awry."  Because quite a few of the more complex games, I feel add so many layers of complexity, it might as well be luck of the dice anyway.  This takes that, and makes no facade about what it is.

Overall, just the level of strategy, competition, simplicity, elegance, and emotional content of this game... this game is one for the (puts sunglasses on) ages.  (YEAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHH!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All components are gorgeous, but play reminds me of many other games. Still, a solid choice. 

Some Geek recommended playing a two-player game, but I have yet to go below the three-player count.

RATING: 10
The first time I played this at one of my gaming groups in late 2017, my instant feeling was "Where have you been all my life??" I love everything about this game, even if there was no such thing as gold mining in the Stone Age. It's the definitive worker placement game, and also great for those who enjoy natural resource management. There are many paths to victory, and it's fun trying out different strategies. It flows smoothly, and always provides a varied, engaging and enriching experience.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
CONCEPT: a village of cavemen/cavewomen break off into smaller groups to create the best community. Best being determined by stone age advanced, most buildings, most people, most food production, etc. 

OVERALL GRADE: B to B plus (but only if you enjoy resource management games which are competitive but less so than wargames and the standard Axis & Allies board games) 

NUMBER OF PLAYERS: 2-4 

AGES: 10 and up, though, I think it's more like 12 and up. Seems complicated for 10 years olds. 

OVERALL SPREAD: every player starts with 5 pieces that represent a group of their people. Every phase of your turn you get to place some of those pieces into a certain category on the board. 

Those categories are typically: 

1. VILLAGE CENTER: put two pieces to create a baby at the end of the piece. You can also increase your food production or build tools that offset bad rolls. 

2. RESOURCES: you can go for more food by hunting or seek out quarries for wood, clay, stone or gold. Gold is the hardest to get per turn. You need a six on a regular die to get this so most players use multiple workers to have a shot at getting just one gold resource. 

3. BUILDING: there are four stacks of possible huts to build. What is required are a variation of resources. The better resources means more victory points. One thing about this stacks is that when one runs out the game is over. 

4. CARDS: there are four cards laid down. You have to put a worker down and also pay resources. These cards typically give you something or give you a chance of getting something. One of the big victory point conditions on these cards are artifacts which can really add up your total. In addition, there are special types of people, like shamans (who add bonuses to your total people at the end of the game), builders (for number of huts at the end of the game), farmers (adding totals to your food production at the end of the game) and workers (adding bonus totals to your total tool use point total). Like building cards, the game ends when there are no more cards to draw from the pile and there are less than four cards remaining. 

TACTICS: this is a game where blocking your opponents can really pay off. For instance, if someone is close to ending the game the other players can block a card he/she needs to play or they can sit on a resource that he/she cannot take. In fact, the rules actually suggest you do such things 
Heh. 

HOW DOES IT COMPARE TO AGRICOLA? For those who have played this game the answer is that STONE AGE is about half the time and a third to a quarter of the many resource pieces. 

Enjoy!!!!

RATING: 9
An enjoyable, somewhat light game that hovers somewhere between Settlers and Puerto Rico in terms of accessibility. RATING: 7.4
Another worker placement game of which we already saw so many in the past years. Gameplay is satisfactory but don't look for anything new in this game. Different roads to victory apear to be present but do not seem very balanced. Opinions may change after more plays.

After playing this a bit more there seems to be more to the game than meets the eye at first glance. Also the learning curve was a bit steeper than I expected from a so called family game. While I agree that it can be played as a family game in a casual way, I'm also starting to apreciate the game more as a gamers game. The competition for the different assets in the game can be fierce and timing is so important. The downside when playing it competetively is that there is still a pretty big luck factor involved in getting the resources.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:

Fun/Social: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Components: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fairly straighforward gameplay in this game, because the actions tend to make some thematic sense.  It has several paths to victory, which I love.  Occasionally one person can get hosed by bad die rolls, but overall it's a quality game that does a good job of mitigating the luck factor.  New players often overlook how significant the endgame scoring can be, but they will learn quickly after the first game.

The big problem I have with this game is the length.  Things tend to get a little repetitive and the game goes on for a very long time especially with 4 players.  This is made even worse if any of the players suffer from analysis-paralysis, as they can lock up every single time they are supposed to place workers on the board.  I want to love this game, and my family wanted to love it as well, but the length just outlasts the fun.  For the first hour it tends to be a really enjoyable game, but at that point I suddenly find myself wishing the game would just end.  I'll play again if asked, but I'm not going to seek out opportunities to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Initial impression.

I was expecting to hate it (dice! my nemeses!), but I actually quite liked it.

You essentially have 1 of 4 options in worker placement - increase your food infrastructure, increase your workers, increase modifiers to die rolls, or go for points via resources, buildings, and cards.

There are some issues with "pip" (the dots on the dice) balance that I might have with the various methods of infrastructure generation which might become more obvious with repeated play, but I'm interested in giving it another go.

UPDATE:

Meh.  Not horrible, too long for a filler, too light for time commitment.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this is my favorite resource management game, emphasize think here!  I do know it is one of my favorite games of all time as well. It scales fantastically for 2 players, and beats the snot out of Lords of Waterdeep. It hits a sweet spot in game length of about 90 minutes. While some argue there's too much luck involved I don't agree with them. Yes rolling "unlucky" could hurt you, but when you can stack the odds by devoting more dice to get what you need, I think it becomes the epitome of "resource management" as you can work hard to counteract this "Unluck." I really enjoy this game.

RATING: 9
iPad version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stone Age is a greeat example of a game that has enough randomnes to make every game different.  The coolest mechanic in the game is your ability to affect  randomness in your favour.  This game is really a hidden gem.  Another fantastic part of this game is it completely visual.  The board, cards and items used in the game are without words.  They use icons that represent actions.  This means the game is playable by any nationality as long as the rules are translated.  The game is light enough to play with your family and has a great learning value for children with respect to math, managing resources and making choices.  In my first game, a 10 year old beat us all.  Most enjoyable loss of my life.  I highly recommend this game and will go out on a limb and predict that it will win several awards this year.  Game designers need to play this game and incorporate the the quality, the randomness and the flow found in this game into their games.  This is a winner.

RATING: 7
It is similar to the awful [i][gameid=24480][/i] in that you assign your workers to areas to work for resources which you use to buy victory points, where you also have to allocate a worker to claim. You also have the option of growing the number of workers you have as well and you always have to feed the workers you have. The complete randomness of turn order in [i]PotE[/i] has been replaced by rolling a die for each worker at an area which allows you to somewhat control the randomness and that is enough to make this a game worth playing and owning.

RATING: 7
OK, there is nothing wrong with Stone Age. Nothing at all. I just didn't find it very exciting or engaging.

It is very light, perhaps a little bit too reliant on the dice, and a touch repetitive for my taste but not a bad game by any means. The play tends to be fairly tactical, though with some room for longer term planning.

Actually, do you know what has been niggling at me about the game - the food. It is too easy to get. You never have a difficult decision about whether to go for some points or gather food - always go for the points, you can syphon up some food with your last couple of meeples. Perhaps it is just uneccessary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
«What’s gold doing in the stone age»?
If you manage to dismiss the anachronism of gold exploitation in the stone age as a ludic licence, then there’s nothing else in this game that can annoy you: quick enough to understand and master, Stone Age makes for a good game, even though one you can’t play too frequently.
After a good handful of runs indeed it gets pretty repetitive, for the strategies are more or less the same all over each game: hence success usually smiles on the one player who just made one right move at the right time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It has luck. Luck of the draw on what cards come out when. Luck of the dice for resources. Luck of the draw again for what huts will appear. But you know what, it was a very good thing in this game. Worker placement games can be a bit structured and someone can precisely figure out exactly what needs to be done at what point in the game. The dice eliminate the ability to optimize precisely which gives the game a bit of risk (and fun). I almost didn't pick this one up because I was somewhat turned off by Pillars (which it had been compared to, play wise and visually) but I'm glad I did (and I still have Pillars on my trade list). The scoring is "mathy" but that's cool. Everything scores it seems but you have to pay attention to what you are doing to get a winning score.

RATING: 7
The quintessential Worker Placement game.  Strangely gets flak for its dice but the randomness is mostly in the Civ cards and buildings.  Not a groundbreaking design but it pares the genre down to the essentials and manages to stay interesting through repeated plays (not easily accomplished by its peers).  I do wish the tools/farming/baby spots weren't such obvious picks and that the resources were slightly more balanced (seems like wood is the clear favorite).

RATING: 9
Worker placement game with a set collection element. It's still interesting after 50+ plays because it has it all: some randomness that can still be mitigated to a certain extent, tactics, and a little strategy as well. However, even though the artwork is great, thematic integration is cringeworthy. Why aren't people starving to death? Why would people from the Stone Age build huts with blocks of stone and gold? Aside from these logic flaws, scoring is too convoluted because of the huge swings of the final scoring. All in all, it's still quite possibly the greatest family game around, certainly the best I know.

RATING: 7
8 plays.  A dicefest for sure, but it's an enjoyable game of resource management and luck mitigation.  Just do the best you can with what you've got.  Lots of hidden points that come from purchased cards... so card counters with photographic memories might spoil the game (unlikely).  Seemed to run long for this type of game... but I guess it needs some length to balance out the luck of the dice.  Gameplay is pretty straight-forward, and families like mine should like the game since it's challenging but not overly complex.  Main problem is that it only goes up to 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Unquestionably the best gateway worker placement game I've played. Far easier to explain than Agricola. While I'd always be willing to play it, there are certainly better, deeper worker placement games that you'll want to move on to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent game. I've played a lot recently, both ftf and on BSW, but I still want to play this again. 

There is plenty to do in this game, you need a play or two of it to see what strategies work the best. Nice balance of growth vs feeding and a rush for the best picks of worker locations creates some interesting mechanics. I've learned that huts multipliers are rarest, so more tools or more people may help more (although saying that, I have won a game by pushing for huts - I did have 9 in a 4 player game).

The no feeding strategy can be pretty powerful if you have a lot of people early on, as "only" losing ten points a turn can easily be countered by the additional actions you can take with at least 3 people who are not hunting every turn.

RATING: 9

RATING: 6
My two gaming contexts are my geeky friends and my wife. I bought this for her. While the theme isn't geeky enough and there isn't enough direct conflict for them, it is very good for her as she enjoys light worker placement games without significant screwage. This is one of my first forays into worker placement games and I admit that I do like it more than Agricola though that might change with more experience with the latter. Stone Age has beautiful components and is very accessible to learn. It's not what I call a brain burner though more competitive players have some opportunities to think more intensely about blocking the strategies of the other. While I wouldn't say it has generated exhileration during or stories afterwards, it is a pleasant game that I'm happy to play. Many worker placement games I've encountered can't boast that same level of easy enjoyment.
Update: The thing that kept bothering me about Stone Age is that there is no real engine building. The last turn is the same as the first. The continuity comes through counting and remembering more than I like. It's easy and light fun, but I think Lords of Waterdeep asks the same investment and provides more return.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Trying to explore the feasibility of not taking the wheat *every* single time you have the first play, at least in the beginning. This is more obvious towards the endgame, but is it mandatory in the beginning in order to win?

RATING: 7
Love it! The game is mega fun. I will not judge it as the other games because before You play it You know there is A LOT of randomness (you can increase the luck factor during a game). You will find some strategy here. There is many ways to develop Your society and not enough time for everything. Appearance - madness. Implementation - one of the better-made games. Theme - strongly felt. Actions really build theme in this game. There is always traffic in cottage where You can make kids :P Watch out for negative interaction between players. Great for 2 players!
Minus - lack of little scorebook for points. Counting in the end is pain in the ass without it (thanks God You can download and print one from BGG). 
Finally - right now it is my favorite easy, economic game. 
"Catan" can rest in peace after buying Stone Age! :D

I had sold my original copy of Stone Age and have now reacquired it.  Such a great light game that still has some decision space, and great for introducing new players to worker placement.

RATING: 10
For me this is just about a perfect game.  It's engaging, likeable and fun.  It's strategic, but not too much.  It provides multiple paths to victory but not so you can't change paths mid-game should circumstances dictate.  It looks and feels fantastic, the components and artwork are first class (even my cup remains pristine and odour-free), it's easy to explain but has enough depth to keep you thinking all the way to the end.

It has luck, of course, but the luck can be mitigated with skill and forethought.  It's my favourite game and I would play it anytime and anywhere.

Only change I make is have everyone start with one tool, that seems to fix any problem with an early really bad roll.

RATING: 9
What could be more entertaining than stone aged love and homestead building long before indoor plumbing...?  Apparently maybe not too much?!!

This game is an extremely pretty game where everything is easy on the eys and very sturdy components with minimal set-up time.

Once player order is established, each turn intiative is passed and selections are then made to aquire a privelage you would like for that current turn.

Players then take turns claiming rights to various positions/resources/buildings/"and cards" which will gain them commodities or the opportunity to trade for scoring points now or various cards tallied later, at the end of the game.  Currency is found in in the form of resources(brick-lumber stone and gold) which ire aquired to trade. 

Trade well and manage your offspring and food gathering well and you will keep the human race successful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After 1 play, I am thoroughly enamored with Stone Age. It packs a lot of tough decisions into a small time frame, while keeping the players involved and minimizing downtime.  I love that it is relatively easy to evaluate almost everything in the game in terms of pips or VPs, and yet the decisions are still not obvious.  I love that there are multiple viable strategies.  I love the feeling of expanding capability as you build toward the end.  I love that it is simple enough to teach to non-gamers, and short enough to keep their attention.  I love that it played very well with 3, even though it was designed for 4, and it looks like it would work well with 2 as well.

Update: 8 plays now.  This is a game of valuation - you evaluate which move will get you the most points, and take it.  The game is not entirely tactical, but almost.  The valuation of actions is relatively easy with practice, and I am finding that I can play mostly on auto-pilot.  Which is not to say that it's a bad game, but it is not a really gripping experience either.  

I still say that it plays well with a wide variety of people, is relatively easy to teach, and is presented well.  This game deserves a spot in most collections because it fits lots of "casual" gaming situations.  But I wouldn't say it's a favorite anymore - there's just not enough depth to it.  I will still suggest it, though, when I think a lighter, well themed title will go over well with the rest of the group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Another solid Euro. I liked this more than Trajan or Marco Polo, two other recent Euros I've played in my quest to play everything in the BGG top-100. It's more streamlined than either of those games, but on the other hand like those games doesn't bring anything new or exciting to the table either. Good playtime that didn't overstay its welcome. I'm not a huge fan of the dice here, and there didn't seem to be enough to mitigate the luck (although the tools can help, sure, it's still swingy). That said, I think the game might be too stale without them. Not in a hurry to play again, but I definitely would play if it was hitting a table.

Edit 09/04: bumped down to a 6. Too light and too much luck. Still ok tho.

RATING: 10

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dice are back!! I have had enough of Risk years ago, but games like Yspahan and Stone Age have found a way to use them as an appropriate mechanic for enjoyable game play. I played with my younger group of kids, and they all enjoyed placing their people figures, and did quite decently. I liked that it challenged their math skills as well. I could tell that they were not grasping the civilization cards though, since I smoked them on the final scoring with those cards. They did well with scoring the buildings, but the civilization card scoring was not as apparent to them. So far, very pleased with the game play, even though there is a lot of rolling the dice. The bits are excellent for the theme. There needs to be more gold pieces but I use the gold from Citadels to compensate. The rules presentation is one of the clearest and free of FAQ reference of any new game I have played. UPDATE: Kids are catching on to the strategy and playing more for the points. Very enjoyable family game. And there is a neat element of tension with taking the civ cards to either enhance your own bonuses or block an opponent - but having to sacrifice an opportunity to place a worker on a much needed field or tool space. Great game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What a beautiful game.  For that reason alone, I'll always keep this.  I knew my wife would love the theme, and she did, but the components still make me smile every time I see them--Beautiful board artwork, meeples, shaped wooden resources, food tokens, first-player marker, and more.  My wife and I love the dice cup, but unfortunately later versions had smelly leather which ruined it for some gamers.  The gameplay for me did start to feel predictable--only a few paths to victory, but after some time away, I've started enjoying this one again.  I'll always play when someone asks, but won't suggest it too often.  This is a game I would strongly recommend to people for the "game after a gateway game" experience (like Settlers of Cataan or Ticket to Ride).

RATING: 5
Honestly I'm not a fan.  I find the luck element to be too strong - maybe it's that I'm horrifically unlucky but I find it bites me in the arse at every critical moment it could.  Additionally I cannot stand not having even a faint sense of how well I'm doing until the game has ended - I feel this is a strong weakness to the game, it is only afterwards when thinking about it that I can see where my mistakes were made.  There's little hope of adjusting on the fly to catch up to a runaway leader as you can't tell who that leader is (sure you can guess, but it's never better then a guess - and often an incorrect one).

Stone Age just rubs me the wrong way, I've never liked it and after 10 plays I still don't.  I'll play, because my friends are fun - but not because I enjoy the game itself (I enjoy the company) and the game is light enough that it doesn't impede on being social.

This is Pillars of the Earth/Leonardo da Vinci with added luck stemming from repeated dicefests.

RATING: 8.9

RATING: 7
Love hate relationship with this one.   The game is well designed with nice pieces, and multiple paths to victory.  Also seems to have fairly good replayability due to the cards.

One aspect I don't like is the sizable disadvantage that the last player in round 1 has.  The player who starts 2nd actually gets a huge advantage imo.

RATING: 7
Mostly play online, can't seem to get enough of it at the moment.  Hits that sweet spot of luck vs. strategy, and scales amazingly well.

[Update 9/8/09] Downgrading to an 8.  Still enjoy this a great deal; I think I'm just getting pickier in my old age.

[Update 11/2010] Now at 7.  Still a good game, and I'll happily play it, but it's not the first game I reach for.

(Update 9/5/2013) Played again recently.  It's still a solid, enjoyable game, and an excellent introduction to worker placement.  Shame I don't like the expansion (even without the awful title.)  What makes this game work is the careful balance of resource value vs. rarity.  The expansion, IMO, tosses that out the window.

RATING: 10
10 is very unique - but so is Stone Age! Gorgeous artwork and a relatively simple gameplay easy to teach.

The mix of luck and stragedy are a sweet symphony working perfect together. I hear a lot of people complaining about the unforgiving dice, but to me it makes sense with the theme; you are not quite sure how productive the men you send working or hunting will be. Have they had any obstacles in the harsh souroundings? It makes sense to me.

Stone Age is a very peaceful game, and every single time I play it, I enjoy it 100 pct.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Stone Age, like its compatriot also designed by Tummelhofer, St. Petersburg, is a rock-solid mid-level Euro.  While it has dice, they are used to good effect - that is, the luck element is still low, and can be planned for.  There is a lot to like here, multiple paths to victory and many nice interlocking parts.  This is a nice lean Euro, very little fat.  My only question thus far is the balance of the civ cards... not that they are unbalanced, but that, at the end of the day, they are all that matter, so the win could wind up being based solely on who took what when.  If played by two skilled players (or two players paying close attention) it shouldn't matter, but I can't see how building huts is anything more than a somewhat lucrative sideline.  Like St. Petersburg, then, the endgame scoring can be a real bitch (in that it creeps up on you).  Really, this is a classic of its kind - we even love the stinky dice cup (so thematic)!

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
Much easier to pick up than Agricola but I think Agricola is a much better mental exercise and hence, I prefer Agricola. Now, my girlfriend may prefer Stone Age just for that reason but I don't like the many multipliers and scoring. and there's always the randomness of dice which some like but I think the odds of having 1 player with a great start and 1 with a horrible one are just too high.

in 2p, the luck of the randomness of the buildings/civ cards coming out determines far too much imo. hard to mitigate at times.

however, it's still a fun game. not so sure I'll like to play it as a tabletop as opposed to online though. hence, it's still a 7.

RATING: 8

Nothing here you won't have seen before and perhaps just a touch on the long side - even with three but more markedly with four - but, overall, very nice.  A few more plays trim the time a little and it also plays well - and quickly - with two, with admirably minor tweaks to the rules - uprated.

[/c]
[b]TOTAL = 387.5/50 = 7.75[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

POSITIVE POINTS:

++ Good light-medium weight gateway worker placement game with a few paths to victory path.
++ I love the ressource collection mechanism in this game, which feel more thematic than having a fixed number of ressources per workers: Send x workers, get x dice to roll (some control luck is thus involved), then use some tool to get better returns.
++ I like having the possibility to do "Tools" to be able to change the results of the dice and thus mitigate the luck factor in dice rolling, but still stay true to the theme (having tools help gathering more ressources efficiently).
++ Easy to teach and fast to play.
++ There is one expansion available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Gameplay can become somewhat repetitive after a few games.
-- Blocked worker-placement spaces for 2 and 3 players could have been depicted directly on the board to make it easier to remember.
-- Maybe too few paths to victory to keep some good replayability.


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 2.5/5
Release Date = 2008
Number of Player = 2-4
2-player length = Approx. 60 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 2, great at 3, recommended at 4! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played this again for the first time since it came out in 2008. Wow, it's just really a dull game. No dramatic tension, no pace, no pulse, no punch to the decision-making process. That a game this uninteresting would have done so well is mildly dispiriting. It's well-crafted, there just isn't anything there.
---
Not bad. I enjoyed my one play. It's definitely got overtones of Pillars of the Earth, or maybe Aladdin's Dragons, but it's definitely not either of those games. Two things sort of stand out, the randomness of resource collection, and the maintenance requirements. The random resource production is actually much cleverer than it first looks, mixing calculus of both risk and efficiency. The food pressures are sort of neat, in that you have to feed your workers, which acts as a drag on growth.

Two things worry me. Firstly, on first inspection, it's just not that thematic. To me, it's obviously an evolution of earlier games (Pillars and Aladdin's Dragons, primarily), sort of transported to the stone age, without the traditional thematic trappings. All the game bits are clever, but they don't seem to function as a unified whole in a thematic way.

Secondly, this designer's previous game (Saint Petersburg) had a very similar feel - but was critically unbalanced. Similarly, there are a lot of moving parts here, and I am rather nervous about the balance.

Anyway, a fun game, one I'll play again, but not a buy for me. I liked Pillars of the Earth better - it's more interesting, more nuanced, more thematic, and better-paced, without being noticeably more complex - and they just aren't so different that I feel Stone Age adds anything to my collection.

RATING: 7
Original game but for me it starts to feel a bit tedious with the grabbing and placing of wooden bits turn after turn.  I find myself wanting to hurry and buy all the huts in a stack just to finish the game and tally up the score.

The parts are fantastic and durable (save for the lame cardboard stand-up cheiftan).  The genuine leather dice cup adds to the theme tremendously.  I like how there are no words written on the cards or game board itself; only artwork and numbers.  It adds to the caveman theme going on.

I'll keep playing this game, just not very often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[thing=34635][/thing]is a simplistic worker placement resource management game.  Each round, players take turns allocating one or more of their workers to a single area on the board.  Five areas provide resources: food, wood, brick, stone, gold.  The resources are acquired by rolling dice and expending the pips; better resource require more pips for a single unit.  Three areas improve your resource collection abilities.  You can reduce your need to gather food, increase the value of your dice rolls, or gain extra workers.  You can convert all resources except food into victory points equal to their cost in pips by trading them (usually in batches of three) for buildings.  This mechanic is a little reminiscent of [thing=39683]At the Gates of Loyang[/thing], which incentivizes players to convert as much cash as possible to victory points each turn.  Alternatively, you can spend resources of any type to acquire civilization cards which give a short term benefit (e.g., a resource) and provide end game victory points.  To maximize victory points, the cards encourage either set collection or specialization (e.g., get lots of people).  At the end of each round, feed each worker a food.  And that's the game.  Place workers, roll dice, collect resources, trade resources for VP, lather, rinse, repeat.  

As someone who really enjoys meaty games with thematically integrated mechanics, the popularity of Stone Age is confounding.  I don't mean to imply that it is a bad game, but I consider it only marginally more entertaining than similarly colorful, innocuous, mechanic-driven, overly balanced fillers, such as [thing=30869]Thebes[/thing] or [thing=27173]Vikings[/thing], and I would have expected it to be similarly rated (i.e., down around 100-120).  Oddly, I have no problem with Stone Age's use of dice (if you were about to fire off a snarky comment about the game being less luck-based than it appears, you can stop right now).  As a regular poker player, I can appreciate the way that the game implements risk management into resource acquisition.  But unlike most resource management games, the resources have no function.  They are acquired solely to be converted into VP or spent (interchangeably) on cards.  A great example of the thematic disconnect that results is that, during our game, players couldn't decide whether the gray wooden bits were supposed to be stone, iron, or silver.  Why couldn't they tell?  Because it didn't really matter.  In the same vein, for a game that spends so much time on colorful veneer (caveman-shaped meeples, rustic leather dice cup, art by [person=11825]Michael Menzel[/person]), the mechanics are surprisingly transparent, and are often anti-thematic.  I have three civilization cards.  One has a picture of a large-breasted statute, one has a picture of a fern, one has a picture of a cart.  Yay, I get 9 points!  Why?  How?  Who cares?!  I spent a gold, a stone, and a wood to build a building.  Yay, I get 14 points!  What kind of building?  Who cares?!  What does it do?  Gives me 14 points!  Yay!

Are we having fun yet?  For me, if a game presents no challenge, it provides no fun.  Stone Age is not entirely devoid of challenge, but it so exposes its simplistic mechanics that what results is little more than a mathy puzzle begging to be calculated.  In the process, the game also diverges from its theme in a way that's at times quite jarring.  I could see this as an intermediate step for new gamers transitioning from [thing=13]Settlers[/thing] to [thing=3076]Puerto Rico[/thing], but I'm not entirely convinced such a step is needed.  Stone Age is not a meaty game.  It is not a thematically cohesive game.  It is consequently not a particularly enjoyable game.  Instead, it is yet another entrant in the so-light-it's-kinda-pointless genre of games that I'll probably never understand.

RATING: 9.5
Fantastic Worker Placement game.  Plays a little long for my liking, but very easy and plenty of decisions and routes to victory.  A+

First game took a little over 2 hours, but I think now that we will start grabbing civ cards a lot earlier the game will finish a lot sooner as well.  The 2 hour game length is a little underestimated.  I am taking out time to learn the game, and the break for fireworks, but still feel we played for more than 2 hours.  It is a great game though and we didn't even notice how long we played for.  With future games we should figure how to get closer to the 90 minutes marked on the side of the box.  

Nice balance of strategy and luck make for a well rounded game.  Theme even works as well.  It could esaily be pasted with something different, without much effort, but still is good.  (7/4/09)


Wow, six months later we see how much we LOVE this game.  One of our favourites in our collection.  May be a 10, but definitely can be said to be a 9.5  Love the strategy, love the luck.  I don;t know what I was thinking about the pasted on theme.  I am kinda right but I still love the theme and how it goes with the whole game.  Brilliant. (2/5/10)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Three placements are far more important than the others, which gives the beginning of each turn a scripted feel. The rest of the game is just collecting resources and trading them in for victory points, which is kind of dull and mathy because of how the huts pay out.

As for the dice rolling, rolling good feels like a little bonus that will come in handy on later turns, but rolling badly, like under six with four dice, is very very frustrating.

RATING: 7
Agricola Lite is right. Still, though, in this case that's not really a bad thing. 90% of the fun without the fiddliness. Loses some depth, obviously.

Stone Age is pretty standard worker placement, but its simple ruleset and the dice make it a good one. Seems like this would be a good step up from things like Settlers for people new to the hobby.

I have kind of mixed feelings on the dice. They make the game feel more accessible and add some essential variety, but the game does feel sort of long to lose from poor rolling. At least, though, you can increase your chances for rolling what you need. I guess I just haven't played enough to figure out how important rolling what you want all the time (or, more importantly, never rolling what you want) is.

RATING: 9

The game ends when a stack of huts/cards is depleted, and one of my family members enjoys ending the game quickly, regardless of her standing.  It certainly makes things a little tighter.  This is an excellent game to play with kids who feel comfortable playing Settlers of Catan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Stone Age is probably the best introductory worker placement game out there.  It is incredibly easy to teach, the mechanics are smooth, and the choices in the game are not overwhelming.  As in any good worker placement game, blocking one's opponents is a key part of the game, but there are so many ways to score points such that even if one is blocked from carrying out a particular plan, a change in strategy and collection of appropriate civilization cards can still lead to a win.  I especially like the calculated risks one has to take with the dice in gathering food and resources.  Very good for two players as well!

RATING: 8.7
I don't know why I like this game as much as I do.  Everything in it is random.  From what actions the players choose, from the totals of your dice rolls, to what cards come out when you are in a given position in turn order.  I think it is because there is something to be said for a simple tactical maximization game.  The game rewards those who choose a sound strategic path and play towards that singular strategy for the entire game.  Just fun to play and amazingly well produced.

RATING: 7
A middling entry in the overstuffed worker placement genre. Combines worker placement with the other recent euro fetish; dice. 4 player ran about 90 minutes, which is OK, and could play much quicker if everyone just rolled at once resolving stuff. Not altogether unpleasant. 

Update: I have to say, this game has grown on me tremendously. After playing dozens of dicey euros, there are very few I would rather play than this. With experienced players, this takes less than an hour. A perfect length for its weight.

People who think luck plays a large part in this game should play some online. A lot deeper than it gets credit for.
