RATING: 8
one of the most balanced games I have ever played. and it has dice!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is seriously the best game for introducing people to the worker placement genre! At least before Lords of Waterdeep came out, which I also highly recommend for new gamers! After I've played it many times, I have actually upgraded my rating a bit as it's also a pretty good game with experienced gamers.

There are many different paths to victory, though some strategies seem to be weaker than others; the tools strategy hasn't won a single time in my games, whereas the food strategy (focusing on the food track) and the starvation strategy are both strong strategies to choose as is focusing on buildings if you can get the x3 huts civilization card. The green civilization cards with the inventions have been okay but haven't been gamechanging. Overall though I think there are many strategies which work almost equally well, at least they have done in our games. The expansion adds even more variety and strategies to pursue.

Furthermore, as in most other good euro games, there are a lot of things you want to do on your turn - but you aren't allowed to do so because the places are either occupied by other players or you simply don't have any meeples left, and this makes the game one of my favorite games with new players! 
However, it's also great to play with gamers (though it isn't a game I would play very often as it's a bit too simple now that I've been introduced to better WP games like Agricola). 

Even though there is a lot of dice rolling, it isn't totally random; you can mitigate the rolls with your tools, and even if you don't have tools the number of die rolls shouldn't affect you that much during the game unless you're really unlucky. I really like the civilization cards and the huts and like how you have to evaluate the value of the cards - not only what they're worth to yourself but also to the other players, so you might want to grab that cheap green civilization card even though you don't need it, just to avoid the other players getting it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Okay but worker placement doesn't do much for me. Grabbing the single farming space as early and frequently as possible would appear to be pretty vital if you want to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
a really fun gateway game awesome board artwork a really good worker placement game for the whole family
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I AM LOVING THIS GAME---raised my rating as the fun and the multiple paths to victory are making this a game I eagerly anticipate. So well executed. 

It doesn't hurt that people pick up the basics of the game fairly smoothly---easy to teach. Gateway Worker Placement of choice for me. 

A NOTE ON STARVATION: I wish people called it the 'BEGGING' strategy rather than the  starvation strategy. The idea that starving, emaciated players can out-produce your well-fed tribe members is tough to accept in such an otherwise surprisingly intuitive game. Besides, they aren't starving---they're BEGGING! Also, it's clear to my gaming sensibilities that the penalty should be two per unfed person.

* * * * * 

Update 04/09: feeling more mathy lately than when we first started playing. Which is okay, but I remember enjoying the game more when I understood it less. It's fun to talk 'pip' optimization with the gang, but it sometimes feels like we're playing 'Who is the best bargain hunter.' Not nearly as cold as Puerto Rico can---in all its brilliance---sometimes feel, and I am now okay with the fact that the best players don't always have to win. There is a lot of randomness that matters here. The best/most experienced win enough, but it's healthy for people to have hope when they play.

Update 10/11: This game has transcended into the 'reunion game' I play with some of my students who graduated when they stop by for a visit. I still love teaching this one to new people, and it has become the 'comfort food' of gaming for some people I always love to see. Therefore, I love this game---it has transcended what is strictly within the box. And I am glad to see that it has been given a fair amount of respect and has a solid place within the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Stone Age is one of my family's favourite games, though given the theme and the fact that two members of my family are anthropologists may explain that slightly.

Stone Age is a worker placement game (like Carcasonne).  Players control a stone-age tribe competing for dominance.  Points are acquired through buying cultural artefact cards, building structures, making tools, agricultural progress, and increasing your population.

Players go around the board placing workers in various locations.  Each location allows the player to produce one of five resources (food, wood, brick, stone, or gold), increase your population, improve your tools (which makes resource-gathering easier), farm (producing a constant stream of food), spend resources on a building, or buy a card.

The mechanics are quite simple, and the entire game sticks to the theme of stone-age tribes fairly well.  Gameplay does not take a terribly long time, which makes it work for a broad age/skill range.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game fills some nice "slots" in the collection. It is enjoyable with two people. It's low on the conflict level, so you really can't hurt other people's feelings. I like the game, but there's a slight sensation that creeps in where it feels too mathematical. 

Some people may disparage the dice, but I think that's a very effective tool in the game. It's nice to have a little bit of "push your luck" element and adds to some of the tough choices.

Revised comment: dropped this down to a "6". It's a fine, game, but it's a bit "polite" and I find myself reaching for other titles instead. It's still a good choice for those that are conflict-phobic.

OK, another revised rating: bumped it back up to a 7. It's a solid game, and there are tension in the choices, despite its polite play. My problem, I think, is that I keep using it as a two player game. With more people, I think the tension becomes much more interesting with each worker placement more crucial.

Nope, check that: dropped it back to a "6". It's a great entry for worker placement games, but I've got plenty other games that are getting my attention. I'm willing to potentially trade this.

Update: Traded it away, along with Cold War: CIA vs. KGB to swap for Manila. It's not that Stone Age is bad... it's just that I own other games that I'll always reach for first. The fact that my wife was lukewarm to the game sealed its fate. And, something will always bug me about spending a gold/stone/brick to build a hut that mathematically equals the same points I just went and fetched. What's the point of all that piece swapping again?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gateway worker placement, place workers and roll dice to determine how many of each resource you get. It's very easy to explain and the concepts are simple to grasp. You need to balance getting food to feed your people each round and resources to buy either huts or civilization cards which score you points. In our 2-player game we seemed to alternate a lot between increasing our food and going to the love shack so the first few rounds felt a little scripted because of that, however once we had plenty of people we were able to move the game along rather quickly. I ended up getting a number of brown civilization cards scoring 105 points in end game scoring to win. The downsides to me are the fact that you can really strike out in getting resources if you roll poorly and not knowing what huts are coming up beyond the few displayed means it may be tough to gauge what resources you should go after on your turn to prepare for future rounds. I would always be happy to play this, I just wish there was a little bit more to it or a little less luck.

RATING: 5

RATING: 9.5
Stone Age is easy to learn and simple to play. It has a nice balance between the tactical depth that should be in any worker placement game, and strategic planning. It is easy enough for my wife to play (thank you Tabletop), and yet it has some great depth to it. The components are also wonderful: the player and game boards are very good looking, and the cards and chits are of good quality.

After many plays, I still can't get enough of this game. It might not be as complex and interconnected as other worker placement games like Agricola, but its simplicity makes it very accessible and quick to play. I cannot recommend this game enough. Every board gamer should have this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I was supremely disappointed by this game. I liked it up until the end of my first (and only) play. Perhaps it might have been my high expectations that made me dislike it all the more, but I will probably never play this again. The starving strategy made me stop and think, "hey, maybe it *is* overrated", and what really ruined it for me was the utter lack of sense of scale. The civilisation cards, for instance, are quite overpowered, but they still lack consistency. There are just too many of them, some too strong, and one offering 3(!) points in a game where scores often reach into the hundreds. 

I can agree with another user who remarked that it is very annoying to not know your position on the score track until the end (since the cards can turn everything upside down). The luck component seems unnecessary. I will, however, gladly concede that the game's components and artwork are outstanding. 

Traded it for A Castle for All Seasons, which I think is a much, much better game than this.

RATING: 8

There is not really any major new innovations here, but I don't really care as it is fun to play, is easy to teach, has little downtime between turns, and a pretty short playing time. Also, it comes with a dice cup!

RATING: 9
Classic, wonderful game. I love the artwork, components, theme, game play--basically the whole experience. There are many avenues to win the game, but winning strategies definitely seem to be centered around getting cards. I love the lottery card where everyone gets something but the player of the card gets first dibs. There's plenty of dice rolling but luck doesn't completely determine outcomes. I would place Stone Age in my top 5 or 10 most cherished games. If I had to scale my collection down to just 10, Stone Age would, without question, make the cut.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the most beautiful board of any game I own and I enjoy looking for little details when waiting for other players (which never is long). The leather dice cup is posh and appreciated.

One mentally slow man I played with was amazed at how anyone could absorb such complex rules, but my gripe is the opposite, which is that the most complicated the game gets isn't complex enough to engage my mind for playing it as often as I'd otherwise prefer to. Mentally slow players aside, I consider this a great gateway game.

Experience with this game taught me that a score track that circles a game board is a suboptimal and even boring thing for any game to put forth as the goal. I want my effort at playing the game to be for accomplishing something. Building something. Destroying something. Not moving a number. This game isn't boring, because the options and actions are interesting. I'm just saying the goal could've been better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Wanna have ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.2
To justify my 4.9 rating: It's actually a pretty good game, but the depth isn't really there for me. As a Worker Placement game, it's the first one I would introduce people to, as there's not a whole lot else going on. (The second one would be Lords of Waterdeep or Caverna.) That said, the randomness of rolling dice for resource gathering, coupled with more randomness in how the cards and buildings come out, keep it below a 6 for me, and it would be a 5 except for there being so many other better options out there.

So, in summary: Good game, would play, but only if the more meatier games weren't available or if I were teaching someone the genre.

RATING: 5
This game took forever to play,  we had to abandon it after a few hours. It got very tedious. 

It was fun to collect wood, clay and stone,  but after a while it seemed that there was no real difference which resource was picked up,  because when converted to points via cards, the number of points turns out the same.

Furthermore, the turn order seems to matter a lot.  Whoever plays first effectively plays the entire game with an extra man than whomever starts last, because the first thing the player does is 'make a baby' and it can only be used once per turn.

Hence the final ranking in our 4 player game ended up being the same as the turn order.

boring.

RATING: 8
Update: dozen or so plays in, I still really like it. But it's certainly more of a gateway game than anything else. but I'm fine with that. I still like Ticket To Ride too.
----
1st few plays have been really really good. Looking forward to getting my own. WAY better than the last Tummelhoffer (St Petersburg). Has the "place yours dudes" thing like Leonardo and Pillars, but much more streamlined than both, and for my money, really focuses on the fun. There's lots of dice rolling love, so if you're allergic to dice, stay far far away. For everyone else, it's a blast. There's not too much of an economic ramp, so there's not too much difference betwen getting screwed by the dice early versus late, so people who don't get the dice love early don't have to freak out. I do have some ideas that will make the game even better. I need to write up something...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
To be honest I never really liked this game much from the start; and as my understanding of it grew, it did little to foster that sentiment. It is often heralded as the quintessential worker placement game: not only attractive to gamers, but also to family enthusiasts. I agree with the latter part of that statement, but I certainly do not with the former.

My main quibbles are a) that the game is too much infused with randomness to make it interesting and b) that there is too little variation to genuinely support more than a dozen games of play: strategically it is weak. First off: the dice. These can be murder from time to time, and there is nothing you can do about it. No, not even the tools help here: the idea is that someone who rolls a crappy result is simply at a disadvantage compared to someone who doesn't for he has to take extra steps in order to get someting done be it to use tools or forego taking a card or a hut or whatever. But don't make the mistake of thinking the dice the only source of randomness: the cards are just as bad. In one game with the expansion I drew 5 of the 9 artefacts simply by taking the top card of the deck. That is 81 - 16 = 65 (!) VP right there. Admittedly, such examples are flukes, which won't turn up in every game. So we get to problem b): in order to establish who is best at Stone Age would require many sessions so that skill trumps randomness. And that is the rub. Once you've seen a building strategy, a card strategy, a starvation strategy, or a rush strategy the rest is basically variation on a theme with varying amounts of these strategies rolled up into a single approach. Think the refrain of [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EK_LN3XEcnw]this catchy tune[/url]. This will become boring rather quickly. At least to me. I will play a few more times for variation's sake, but after that I will be simply 'done' with Stone Age.

Now the family gamer on the other hand has a nicely illustrated game with a clear worker placement mechanism and a cool bit of dice rolling to look forward to. Resources enter the game in a nice way, and are spent in interesting ways. Combining the various aspects may actually be a challenge. For her, the game is a good investment. 

Still, I rate games based on how they make [i]me[/i] feel... So Stone Age doesn't reach much higher than a 5. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Acquired July 2008.

Love worker placement games.

I was going to avoid this one because I have so many worker placement games.  Caylus, Pillars, Leonardo, AOE III.  Then I played it.  This is the best introduction to worker placement games currently available for families.  

Additionally, this is a great math trainer for my kids.  The constant division needed to determine your resources is great practice for them.  The only thing I wish is that it continued the division higher than 6.

Another nice point about this game is that there really isn't a bad choice.  There are many ways to go with your workers and every game I've played has been very close.

This game works very well as a two player game too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
This worker placement game combines several winning elements seen in other games.  In particular you have gathering of resources of various values.  You use those resources to gain victory points either immediately (from the huts) or at the end of the game (from civilization cards).

I do appreciate that it's hard to know who's winning, as the endgame bonuses shift rapidly with each turn.  But the importance of rolling dice adds a random element that will turn off serious strategists.

A perfectly pleasant game, but it doesn't rock my world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My first work placement game. Although easy to learn, it offers surprisingly high game play variety and different strategies how you could win. Great in 2, 3 and 4 players.
Great art and wooden parts, also leaden cup for dice throws is very cool. 
Also although the dice are used a lot there, the luck factor is very light and usually the better player wins.

I cannot recommend this game enough as the gateway work placement game, but I still enjoy playing this despite the 600+ games under my belt. I feel very relaxing when playing this game.

What I like:
- I simply enjoy playing this, this game makes me smile
- Great artwork, great components. It is pleasure to look at board. Even the leather cup is great (and it doesn't smell in my czech version)
- Although the dice are major part of the game, I feel that the luck never beat the strategy/tactics. Stronger player win (almost) everytime
- Several viable paths to choose, and no one is the best (although somebody says the starvation strategy is the best, but I disagree)
- Overall, classic easygoing worker placement game suited well for the game beginners but offers a great amount of strategy for gamers.

What I dislike:
- I don't know what to think about expansion, I heard some mixed feelings. Despite the fact that I am a completionist, I decided not to include this as I am afraid it could potentially ruin the clear experience from the base game
- I play this game regularly with my mum and I win all the time, which is sad sometimes - she loves the game, but she would like to win from time to time.

RATING: 8
This worker placement game seems really easy to get started with, in the sense that learning the rules is easy.  I like the different approach used by Stone Age versus Notre Dame.  In Notre Dame, all players can generally share every location.  In Stone Age, players taking spots removes those options for the other players.  Stone Age feels more directly interactive, but Notre Dame feels like it has more options to explore.  All I can say is that I like them both.

RATING: 6
Fun enough, but doesn't really grab me. I think I'd enjoy a similar sort of game where the infrastructure spaces were more numerous and more varied, but not so fantastically good... but balancing that out could be tricky, as either infrastructure would become mostly-useless in mid-to-late game, or its effects would have to shift as the game progressed... and either way you'd need larger tribes to take advantage of the extra spaces; between all that you've probably just tacked 30-60 minutes onto the game. And the scarcity does work well insofar as you have to roll with what's available to you, rather than always pursuing a similar strategy, so.

After playing Imperial Settlers I think I may want to sell this. No wait. I give it too high of a rating so I sort of don't. My wife wants to sell it lol. And I am Jones Theorizing it due to Tzolkin and Imperial Settlers and that is a problem really as we don't Jones Theory as much.

Stone Age seems a bit too samey and controlled when played with two players.

Yet she wins a lot by playing one same strategy.

See I disbelieve it will always work.

I need to fight more for the right stuff first then eventually we will get to thin point margins based on cards and buildings maybe.

11/9/16 Even with 4 players playing the ipad app the game  just isn't all of that good. It is too basic. I would sell it if the expansion doesn't improve it for two players. I'm done with this game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Components: Lavish. The board is beautiful, the iconography good, and having the resources be in distinct shapes is a great plus. As a vegan, I would not have purchased this game if I had realized ahead of time that it contained a leather dice cup.

Experience: It started out slow during my first few games, but that's not the case anymore. We hit the ground running, throwing everything we can at cheap resources and technology. There is a lot of math, more than in any other game I've played; players are constantly adding, dividing, and multiplying.

I find it very satisfying to gather a lot of resources. There are always fun things to do with my villagers. The variety of huts and cards makes for interesting scoring possibilities. Dice rolling is fun. Always tense. A lot of different ways to earn my points, and to react when opponent's block my preferred actions.

The conversion of villager actions to pips on a die, and resource value to points, is mostly transparent, offering a clear cost & benefits analysis in most cases (though the cards complicate things). More than half the points come from the cards, which also confer other in-game benefits, so buying cards is definitely the way to go.

A bit too competitive with four players.

First Played: 2009-07-23
Last Played: 2012-05-22
Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

Plays (10):
2 players: 4
3 players: 5
4 players: 1

RATING: 7
Agricola-lite. Much less pressure to keep from starving. You never starve unless you are pressing your luck, or unless you choose to. As such, it is more family friendly and less brain burning. It is fun to roll the dice and use tools to change the outcome or apply more tribe members for a guaranteed payout. Great luck-of-the-dice mitigation in this game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Stone Age is highly intuitive to play and develops naturally.

A fun placement game that's shorter than Caylus and Pillars, but enjoyably strategic with multiple ways to win. The board is beautiful and the components are great. Other placement games force you to collect things in a certain order, but not in Stone Age, you're free to collect things in the order that you want. You're also free to choose the amount of luck in the game because you choose the number of dice. 

Stone Age is a smooth game, stripped of excess, and highly replayable. Plays great with 2.

RATING: 6
Pretty much standard worker placement.  The value of the field space and the "family growth" spaces are obvious, and they're first picks most of the time.  The randomness of either the buildings or the cards would be fine, but the randomness of both seems a bit too much.

Mainly, however, I don't perceive that there's much tension in this game.  And unlike, say, Trajan or Ora et Labora, there's not a lot of satisfaction in continuously scoring points either. So it lies within an "unhappy" medium.

RATING: 3
Entry-level worker placement. Played this at a public board game event with two people who would not stop talking about random off-topic stuff, completely forgetting rules which seem absurdly easy to pick up if they were paying the slightest of attention to actually playing. What could have been played in under a hour took over two, and was an absolute slog to play through.

I realise that's a problem with the people I played with. Maybe if I played with people more focused on playing with a bit of banter it would be more interesting, but I doubt it. Decision making is pitifully lacking in this game, the complete lack of player interaction is not appealing in the slightest. A good indication of what I should expect from worker placement games in general.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
2-4 players, light-medium, 75-90 minutes, worker placement

Having played some 70 games, I can fairly say this is one of my favourite games.

Stone Age is a so called worker-placement game, which sets in the Stone Age. The goal of the game is to collect resources (wood, brick, stone, gold) to build huts and buy development cards which help you collect victory points. It is of course vital to feed your meeples every turn, if you cannot than you will lose 10 victory points each turn. As soon as the huts or the development cards run out, the player with the most victory points is the winner of the game.

I personally think the theme is very appealing. The board looks very nice and the resources components (all wood) are very nice as well.

Setting up the game only takes a few minutes, so you're ready to play in no time.

Stone Age plays fast and rather easy, everyone can play this within a few minutes. There is little down time and not much chance of AP. The (7) dice add some luck to the game, but in a good way as you have to use these all the time, so the luck component should even out. Also, the starting player moves per turn, so everyone gets the chance to choose first.

The routes to succes can differ, there is not one single strategy. After two games it becomes rather clear what works and what doesn't, so the advantage for an experienced player is limited to one or two games. The development cards are key to winning the game, but everyone is aware of that, so that's fine as well. On occasion, not feeding you meeples could be worthwile, when there are very strong cards or huts for grabs, but so far I've not played the game with the starvation strategy and have won probably >90% of all games I've played.

I've played a dozen games now, with 2, 3 and 4 players including a number of first timers. It plays well with any amount of players, which I consider a bonus as not many games do. Although the first game may take well over 2 hours, with experienced players you can play a game within the hour.

There is also an expansion available which allows you to play with 5 players and which adds trading goods. Personally, I prefer the original and have traded away the expansion. 

I'm a big fan and want to play this again soon! I have not found any downsides to this game yet. I rate this game 10/10!

Please check my review at:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/14576397#14576397
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
WP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great family game.  Stone Age stands up as a solid game with good choices available.  It's a very good balance of fun mechanics without being overly complicated.

Replay is good with this one, and it's always a hit.  The rules are simple.  The boards look good, and have all the reference information you need.  

This has been perfect for introducing family and neighbors to the hobby.  The dice really allow you to mix players of different skill levels.  For beginners I usually leave out the civilization cards until the second play.  It makes it pretty dry for me, but that gets them excited for play #2 where it is the full game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Adding the tension of dice rolling to a worker placement game like Caylus works really well here.  If this game was trying to be heavier than it is, then the dice would be annoying.  But as a light game, you play the odds and hope for the best.  You rejoice when the dice give you an unexpected gift (like three sixes on a dice bar when you're third in line) and you lament when the dice work against you.  A lot of fun to be had here.

Revisited after many years and much better than I remembered. The amount of luck in it, which I felt was a defect, is actually a feature: it requires calculated risks. In Stone Age, the players live in this time, just as our ancestors did. They collect wood, break stone and wash their gold from the river. They trade freely, expand their village and so achieve new levels of civilization. With a balance of luck and planning, the players compete for food in this pre-historic time.

RATING: 9
Combines the fun worker placement of Agricola with the rolling for resources aspect of Catan (but without quite as much randomness). I really like this game, and even though the direct player interaction is minimal, it feels like you're constantly giving people the screws by taking what they need (and vice versa). The need to feed your people is there, just like in Agricola, but it's much easier to do, and the penalty isn't as high if you can't manage it well enough.

RATING: 8
+New Huts expansion (Spielbox), +Style is the Goal (zman)

Finally got my brother and sister in-laws to play this with me and they said they'd play it again. Hooray.

So, despite having only played it twice over a three year period, I have enough worker placement gaming under my belt to justify a rating and comment. It's as everyone says: Stone Age is one of the best examples out there as an introduction to the worker placement mechanic for those looking to play a step up from the gateway level (although Lords of Waterdeep now seems to be the more popular choice). Stone Age is relatively simple when compared to other games with the same defining mechanic, but the diversity of civilization cards and building tiles offers enough variation in strategy.

RATING: 6
[Sep 2016] - 7 (1 play)
I had no comment written at that time.

[14 Jul 2017] - 6 (1 play)
I'm dropping this game after a year of not playing the board game or iOS version any further. It's a good worker placement game that has a bit of luck with the resource production dice. It's just not a game that I've played since a year ago despite having ample opportunities to play it again. The strategy seems to predictable to make this a fun game to explore. Each resource spot has an ideal number of workers +/- 1, the flow of when to grab workers, resources, food and then points is also set. No matter what the other players do, sticking with the formula leads to decent results. With so many good games out there, I'm just not interested in playing this game. I think my prior high rating was more a rating of the people I was playing with instead of the game itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Two big problems:  1)  You're crazy if you don't take a farm when you have start player.  And almost as crazy if you don't take tools when you have 2nd pick.  (There are a couple exceptions to the second part, but farms are really the must-grab).  So already you've got obvious first moves two rounds of the game.  
2)  The mechanics are very wash-rinse-repeat.  You're collecting stuff but not really building toward anything, so even at 75-90 minutes the game feels too long.  This can be easily corrected by removing cards and tiles, but problem 1) remains.
I feel like this is a pretty mediocre game rehashing old mechanics.  I'd still play it but wouldn't ask to.
ETA:  I play this online at Yucata a lot now and like it more than I used to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like it, but I'm not really sure if I want to play it. Somehow the strategy and gameplay seem too simple and random. 

Only few viable tactics make it feel a bit simple and my thought process usually goes "if a isn't available, pick b, if b isn't available, pick c". No long thought processes like in Agricola.

With random I don't mean the dice, they're fine, but the civilization and village spots make me cry. Some cards are superior and sometimes it feels there's not much you can do with how they come up.

It's very good gateway game thought and was simple to learn! It's the longest game we've played with our casual group so far and the first time took 3 hours. Never thought they could take it but they did and everyone was "where did the time go, eek!" There's potential in my gaming group and this is the game that made me realise it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Stone Age is yet another place-your-worker-to-get-resources-and-special-abilities, spend-the-resources-to-get-victory-points, in the line of Caylus, Leonardo, Pillars, Agricola, kingsburg and so long and so forth.The new twist is that resources are not assigned in an exclusive way, rather players get them through dice. Additionally, workers are not returned in a predetermined order, rather on the player's choice. Stone Age is streamlined and quite simple. There is almost no structure or narrative flow in the game, and turns do not differentiate a lot among them.

RATING: 8
Doel van het spel:

Het spel eindigt als aan het begin van een ronde de beschavingskaarten niet tot 4 kunnen worden aangevuld OF als één stapel hutten is uitgeput (huidige ronde wordt nog uitgespeeld). De speler die na de eindtelling de meeste punten heeft, wint het spel. 

In geval van gelijke stand: Huidige score + aantal gereedschap + stand op het voedselspoor + aantal stamleden. De speler met het hoogste totaal wint het spel. 

Voorbereiding:

+ Leg de voedselfiches (jachtvlakte), hout (bos), leem (leemgroeve), steen (steengroeve) en goud (rivier) op hun desbetreffende plaats. 
+ Iedere speler neemt in zijn kleur: 5 stamleden, 2 markeerstenen (veld “0” van het voedselspoor en het scorespoor), 12 voedsel en 1 spelerstableau. De jongste speler krijgt de startspelerfiguur. 
+ Sorteer de gereedschapsfiches (1/2 en 3/4) en leg ze op hun desbetreffende plaats. 
+ Schud de beschavingskaarten en leg 4 kaarten open op het speelbord 
+ Vorm een x-aantal stapels (4 bij 4SP, 3 bij 3SP en 2 bij 2SP) van 7 hutten en plaats ze op het speelbord. 

Speelverloop :

1/ Stamleden op het speelbord plaatsen 

Te beginnen met de startspeler en daarna met de klok mee, plaatst iedere speler één of meerdere stamleden op de cirkel(s) bij één locatie. Deze fase gaat door totdat alle spelers hun stamleden op het speelbord geplaatst hebben. Het is niet toegestaan om stamleden bij een locatie te zetten, waar je in een vorige beurt (in de huidige ronde) al stamleden hebt geplaatst. Je mag in deze fase niet passen. 

2/ Acties uitvoeren 

Te beginnen met de startspeler en daarna met de klok mee, voert iedere speler alle acties uit van zijn stamleden. Hij mag de volgorde van de acties willekeurig bepalen. Zijn alle acties van jouw stamleden uitgevoerd, neem ze dan terug op jouw spelerstableau. De volgende speler is nu aan de beurt.

Locatie – cirkels – actie:

Jacht – oneindig – De speler neemt voor elk stamlid op de jachtvlakte, 1 dobbelsteen. De speler telt alle geworpen ogen en mag ongebruikte gereedschapsfiches erbij optellen. De totale waarde deelt hij door 2 (naar beneden afgerond) en dat is het aantal voedsel dat de speler krijgt.

Bos – 7 – De speler deelt de totale waarde door 3 (naar beneden afgerond) en dat is het aantal hout dat de speler krijgt.

Leemgroeve – 7 – De speler deelt de totale waarde door 4 (naar beneden afgerond) en dat is het aantal leem dat de speler krijgt.

Steengroeve – 7 – De speler deelt de totale waarde door 5 (naar beneden afgerond) en dat is het aantal steen dat de speler krijgt.

Rivier – 7 – De speler deelt de totale waarde door 6 (naar beneden afgerond) en dat is het aantal goud dat de speler krijgt.

Gereedschapsmaker – 1 – De speler ontvangt 1 gereedschap. Leg of draai een fiche zodat jouw gereedschapswaarde stijgt met 1.

Beschavingskaarten – 1 per kaart – De speler neemt zijn gekozen kaart en betaalt de kosten (kader boven de kaart). Het bovenste deel van de kaart moet je direct uitvoeren (zie kaartenoverzicht).

Hutten – 1 per stapel – De speler neemt zijn gekozen hut en betaalt de grondstoffen op de hut. Verplaats je markeersteen op het scorespoor een x-aantal punten vooruit (zie hut) en leg een nieuwe hut open.

Akker – 1 – Zet jouw markeersteen op het voedselspoor 1 veld vooruit.

Bevolkingsaanwas – 2 (in 1 kleur) – plaats steeds twee stamleden  op deze plek en neem dan een extra stamlid uit de algemene voorraad. Dit stamlid mag je gebruiken in de volgende ronden.

3/ Stamleden voeden 

Iedere speler neemt eerst zoveel voedsel uit de algemene voorraad als zijn markeersteen op het voedselspoor. Daarna moet iedere speler 1 voedsel afgeven voor elke stamlid op zijn spelerstableau. Als een speler niet voldoende voedsel heeft, mag hij het ontbrekende aantal betalen met grondstoffen. Kan of wil hij het benodigde voedsel niet met grondstoffen betalen, dan verliest hij direct 10 punten (je kan niet onder de “0” komen). Ook al kiest de speler om 10 punten te verliezen, hij verliest altijd zijn resterende voedsel. 

Nieuwe ronde:

Schuif de de resterende beschavingskaarten naar rechts en vul terug aan tot 4. Spelers draaien hun gebruikte gereedschapsfiches terug naar hun beschikbare positie. Geef de startspelerfiguur door aan de volgende speler (links).

Eindtelling:

Groene achtergrond: kwadraat van het aantal verschillende symbolen + kwadraat van het aantal dezelfde symbolen.

Zandkleurige achtergrond: afhankelijk van de kaart krijg je punten:
+ aantal boeren x de stand van jouw markeersteen op het voedselspoor.
+ aantal gereedschapsmakers x de hoeveelheid gereedschap dat jij bezit.
+ aantal hutbouwers x het aantal hutten op jouw tableau.
+  aantal medicijnmannen x het aantal stamleden in jouw bezit.

Totale score = huidige score + punten van beschavingskaarten + 1 punt per eenheid grondstof.

Belangrijke regels:

+ Let op voor de aparte spelregels voor een spel met 2 à 3 spelers! Zie spelregels. 
+ Als je gebruik maakt van een gereedschapsfiche (actie jacht, bos, steengroeve, leemgroeve of rivier) dan draai je de desbetreffende fiche 90° naar rechts. Deze fiche kan je in deze ronde niet meer gebruiken. 
+ Er is geen limiet aan het aantal beschikbare grondstoffen. 
+ Als een speler de grondstoffen niet kan of wil betalen bij het kopen van beschavingskaarten of hutten, dan laat hij de kaart/hut liggen en zet hij zijn stamlid zonder gevolgen op zijn tableau. 
+ Een gereedschapsfiche moet in zijn geheel bij een dobbelsteenworp worden opgeteld. Het is niet mogelijk om een deel te bewaren voor een andere worp. Je mag meerdere fiches bij een worp optellen.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[2009-12-24 Rating: n.a. -> 7.5]
Overview
---------------
Stone Age is a worker placement game in which each player acts as the leader of a small tribe. Each round, players take turns by placing at least one of their tribe members into one region of the board. However, there are two restrictions when placing a meeple:

1. You can’t place a meeple into a region which is already full.
2. You can’t place a meeple into a region into which you already placed a meeple in a previous turn of the current round.

After each player has placed all their meeples and beginning with the start player for the round, each player resolves his placements in any order they want. The regions on the board can thereby be differentiated into three categories:

1. Regions with Permanent Benefits: These regions grant you a benefit that will last until the end of the game. The following regions have a permanent benefit:
a)  Farm: After each round, you have to pay one food for each meeple in your tribe. By     placing a meeple here, you get one farm permantly. Each farm feeds one of your meeples at the end of the round.
b) Hut: Place two meeples here to get a new meeple which can be used starting next round.
c) Tool: Place a meeple here to get a new tool. Tools can be used to alter your dice rolls in resource regions.

2. Resource Regions: These regions allow you to get resources. To get them, you have to place at least one meeple into one of them. For each meeple you placed into a region, you can roll one dice. You add up all the pips on the dice you rolled to get a number of resources. You can modify your result by using the tools you got from the Tool-region (see 1c). The following resource regions are available:
a) Food: Recieve one food for each two pips you rolled.
b) Wood: Recieve one food for each three pips you rolled.
c) Brick: Recieve one food for each four pips you rolled.
d) Stone: Recieve one food for each five pips you rolled.
e) Gold: Recieve one food for each six pips you rolled.

3. Civilization regions (aka. the key to victory): The board has two regions where you can trade your resources for victory points and, to some degree, get a minor one time benefit. These regions are:
a) Civilization cards: Each round, four cards will be placed on the board randomly. They cost between one and four resources. Which resources you use to pay for them is completely up to you. First, each card grants you a small one time benefit like additional food or some resources. Second, each card has a multiplier or a symbol on it which will be resolved at the end of the game. There are multipliers for the number of farms, tools, meeples in your tribe and houses. So if  you have a tribe consisting of 7 meeples and you do have a corresponding multiplier of 3, you get 3 * 7 = 21 Victory points at the end of the game. 
The symbols are used to create sets. At the end of the game, you count how many unique symbols you managed to collect. You multiply this number with itself and the result of this operation equals the number of victory points you get. Example: For five unique symbols you collected you would get 5 * 5 = 25 Victory points.
b) Huts: Depending on the number n of players there are n hut piles. If you want to build a hut, you have to place a meeple on it and pay the cost for this hut which is printed on the card. Huts score points equal to their cost. For example a hut that cost 3 Gold gives you 3 * 6 = 18 victory points.

The game ends after the round in which one of the hut piles is depleted or you can’t place four new cards on the board. When this happens, you add up the victory points you got from multipliers, huts and symbols plus each unused resources you still own. These, with the exception of food, are worth one victory point each. The player with the most victory points wins.

Comments:
--------------
* The use of dice and the theme help to get this game to the table even if there are non-gamers present. While the dice introduce luck into the game, they hide the fact that Stone Age is a quite brutal optimization game and give it a much lighter feel. While non-gamers may not be able to see the optimal move every time and therefore aren’t that competitive, they nevertheless have a lot of fun rolling the dice and looking after their tribe. This is partly achieved by the fact, that you score most of your points at the end of the game using the cards you bought during the course of the game. So while playing Stone Age, you have to pay close attention to know who is in the lead. This is something non-gamers mostly don’t do. As a result of this, they have the feeling that they are doing okay until the game is over.

* I’m not a big fan of the end game scoring. While it helps to hide the real nature of this game from less experienced players, it also results in some disappointed looks on the face of the new players at the end of the game. When teaching this game, I ALWAYS explain the end game scoring in great detail. Nevertheless, at the end of a game new players are nearly every time surprised by the amount of victory points you can get by just buying multipliers. So the first game of a new players nearly always ends with mixed feelings.
Another drawback of the end game scoring is that it doesn’t deliver you with an immediate feedback. When learning this game, it took me a lot of plays to see which actions are actually the best ones in certain situations. In order to judge the value of a placement, you have to do quite a lot of math in your head. But it took me quite some time to reach this point. The online implementation of Stone Age at www.yucata.de was very helpful during this process as it shows you your current score in great detail, giving you an immediate feedback.
So, all in all the end game scoring is a mixed bag for me. On the one hand it helps getting this game to the table, on the other hand it makes it so much more difficult to learn the strategy.

* I like the dice in Stone Age. Sure, sometimes they can ruin your plans. But on the other hand, they prevent the game from becoming a pure math exercise. Additionally I really enjoy the risk management aspect that is introduced by them.

* Stone Age puts constant pressure on you. As in every worker placement game, you are faced with a dilemma each time you have to place your meeples. Do I claim this region now or later? Will someone else have used it by then? I do really enjoy the tension that comes with this kind of decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent worker-placement, with enough going on that you can feel like you're developing a strategy and making real decisions, even though an inordinate amount of the longish running time goes to dice rolls.  There's a reasonable amount of interaction going on just based on locking people out of spots you want to place your meeples, though I think it could maybe have a LITTLE more back-and-forth stuff in the mechanics.

The art's attractive, but I wish the board design gave more room (or even just organization) to handle all the bits that start to pile up everywhere, especially on your own tableau.  Feels messy and the fear of some bricks knocking someone out of their score track position is palpable.  But these are small gripes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Solid older euro. Gamers will nail the optimal strategy in three or four plays, at which point it comes down to who rolls higher dice. It's still fun though, and good for teaching kids multiplication tables.

EDIT: I think I'm gaining an appreciation for games that don't grind to a halt on the altar of their own complexity. Plenty of tough prioritizing in the worker placements, but none that can't be made with a shrug of the shoulders and a toss of the dice.

The only knock on this game is that there is no 'building strategy'. You have to prioritize cards and fill in with buildings where possible. If you're playing with first-timers, this should be explained with the rules to avoid an unsatisfying experience.

RATING: 7
This is probably one my favorite worker placement game I've played.
The components are pretty standard - not too flashy, but well made.  The game moves along pretty well, and there's always something to do. Not a lot of player interaction beyond your choices interfereing with other player's strategy.  I was a bit put off by the theme - prehistoric games usually don't do it for me - but this wasn't too bad. The mechanics and the theme seemed to go well with each other.  I just wish that designers would make these games for more people.  4 just usually isn't enough for our game group.  Which is too bad, because the four of us who played this for the first time really enjoyed it.
OK, this has fallen into the same category for me as Age of Empires 3.  I can't seem to win at either game, although I like Stone Age better.

The iOS version is very good.

RATING: 6
I admit that I bought Stone Age in anticipation of Agricola. I was so enthusiastic about the impending arrival of the well-heralded worker placement game that I bought another worker placement game to prepare myself. Luckily, Stone Age failed to disappoint me. While being lighter than Agricola, it still moved along briskly, provided a number of fun and interesting decisions, and overall proved to be a good game. It was no Agricola, however, and as soon as I bought Agricola I ceased to be interested in playing Stone Age. 

That changed recently, as I introduced the game to my mom, and decided that this would be an excellent game to play with her and my sister. My mom isn't hugely interested in the game (she likes Blokus and Zing! better), but my sister likes it quite a bit, so I play it with her and Becky, when we visit each other. I suspect that this will be the main instance in which I play this game in the future, as I am more likely to bring out something a bit heavier with my "gamer" friends.

RATING: 5

Almost entirely lifted from other games we've seen in the past three years.  The good thing is it all works, is made in Europe (quality bits), and looks stunning.  The bad thing is it's entirely unoriginal, takes too long, and feels like too much of the same thing.  Happy to play it, but feels like a quick knock off of other similar games.

Although you are competing for worker spots, I don't feel much tension when playing this game. That's only a slight negative to me (and a positive for my wife). Once you have the basic strategies figured out, victory is based more on luck than skill, but that doesn't bother me (for this game) because it's just plain fun to play.

RATING: 7.2
Trying to decide how I feel about Stone Age. It's fine for an intro to Euros, or a quick, light game, but there are a couple things I don't like much:
- It's impossible to plan for good multipliers or civ tech cards, unless there's a very strong opening draw.
- The game doesn't feel like it has much of a "story arc", as it's kinda flat throughout the game, and many of the choices are only marginally better than the others.

[b]1.4.10 Update:[/b] Rating goes up after another very enjoyable play.

[b]1.5.11 Update:[/b] Over a year later and this game is still just as ridiculously fun, and continues to lend itself to a wide demographic of gamers. Rating moves up to 9.25!

[b]8.12.11 Update:[/b] Man, I love this game. It just keeps giving me what I want in a gaming session. Awesome. I've been toying with promoting this and today I will! This moves into slot #1, unseating Puerto Rico, if only because it hits the table way more.

worker placement & dice rolling   35,189     2.9x
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A solid worker-placement dice game.  This was overplayed for a long while, but seems to have subsided a bit.  
It has an interesting flow.  The game might go long, and investment in cards may be key.  Or someone might grab resources and drill a stack of huts, preventing the cards from reaching their potential.  Of course, a lot of it is dependent on the die rolls, and consistently rolling high can put you ahead of the curve.  Those who feel that the luckless Caylus is the pinnacle of worker placement may hate this twist, but I don't mind it.  
The way the cards & huts come out gives the game enough variation that I can forgive the somewhat scripted start.  

Only thing I'm not sure about is the whole 'starvation strategy'.  I've yet to get an answer I'm satisfied with as to whether that's intentional or not, and whether the 10 pt penalty is flat, or per person.  I've only played a couple games where someone tried it, but it seems powerful enough that the only person who has a chance of stopping the starving player is the one to his/her left, who's snapping up all the food/agriculture they don't take.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first worker placement game. I love the board for this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
I love worker placement games, and most involve very little luck. Until now I thought that was a good thing.  This game is a perfect blend of luck and skill, which elicits a much more emotional response than most worker placement games.  Taking calculated risks provide a strategic element that can bump you ahead or blow up in your face.  The game provides you some risk mitigation with tools, which helps you deal with unlucky rolls and keeps the balance of luck to skill in check.  The only downside is it feels like collecting culture cards just destroys any other strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
8 Plays:

This is a great game. I love the dice rolling luck combined with strategy and all the ways to score. The expansion is underrated. Plays great at all player counts.

RATING: N/A
Comment: Played my first two-player Stone Age last month. I know it's good with two (people have been saying this) but if you're okay with luck, then I guess this will be fine for you.

When happened in my game was that, the actions seems a little scripted in my opinion, especially in the village. Also, me and my opponent kept fighting for civ cards (which is a good thing)(either blocking or buying), and whenever he becomes the first player, some pretty decent cards appeared on the first two spots (like the field/green background cards or the the double/triple multiplier). He got to buy them cheap while I have to struggle a little and hoping the good ones also come out during my turn.

I know the cards are drawn randomly but it can happen that luck is not on your side.
So I'd say I prefer Stone Age with four players and not two.

It seems to work out alright, but still tweaking it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Fair.  A solid game, although not as accessible to non-gamers as I initially thought.  Worker placement, as a mechanic, is conceptually really weird to non-gamers.  I actually think it is more accessible in Caylus (although the rest of the game is not) due to the latter's clear and sensible one-worker-per-space rule.

Once they get over the hump in this, it's okay.  Good playing time and beautiful art make for a nice experience, but something's still lacking -- probably in the huts, which are a phenomenally bland, unthematic, and transparent way to do the whole "turn stuff into points" thing that so many Euro designers are into.  If the game had ditched the huts entirely and just focused on civ cards, it probably would have turned out better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

石器時代
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a light-medium weight worker placement game.  You play as a prehistoric tribe and utilize your tribe members to gather resources, construct huts, farm, make tools, or procreate.  The person who develops their tribe the most through huts and civilization cards wins.

The game does utilize die rolls for resource gathering so there is definitely a good dose of luck involved.  But I feel the game offers a fair amount of ways to mitigate luck.  The game rules are pretty straightforward and easy to teach.  Scoring with the civilization cards is the only part that may be a little confusing, but one play-through is all you need to understand it.  In addition, the game board is beautiful and I love the fact that they use thematically shaped pieces for the resources instead of just having different colored cubes.

I consider this my go-to gateway worker placement Eurogame to introduce people to the genre.  So far it has been pretty successful.  Highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you want a gateway game that's fun to play with more experienced friends you can't go wrong with this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is fun game and a lot of dice usage when you are collecting your resources. It is quite light and a good gate way game. Feeding your family in this game is not as hard as other games, such as Agricola, and so you don't seem to have to panic. The harvest is not the only thing it shares with Agricola, you also have to place workers. The components are lovely and the game comes with a really nice dice cup. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Easy to learn and entertaining. A lot of luck needed with the dice to win. But I like the casual vibe of the game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Stone Age is like worker placement 101, an excellent intro to the mechanic but ultimately not as exciting or fulfilling as the Agricola's and Le Havre's of the gaming world.  However, with the right crowd it can be good fun and the mystery scoring of the cards at the end means everyone feels they have a chance right to the last.

RATING: 6
This is an excellent introductory worker placement game.  There are a lot of random aspects to the game, such as cards, order of the building tiles, and lots of dice rolling but for some reason I'm not bothered by the randomness in this game.  It's a pretty quick game, the rules aren't overly complicated, there are many paths to victory and the components/art/theme are amazing.  Of all the euro's that use dice in an interesting way, I think this beats Yspahan and Kingsburg.  Try it online through BSW if you're still on the fence about this one. Eventually was replaced by Troyes.

RATING: 8
This is the game that got me hooked on strategy board games. I had already played games like Settlers of Catan and Dominion, which are fun, but Stone Age is what really led me to discover the wonderful world of strategy board games. It has a great balance of strategy and luck (too much luck for some people because of the number of dice you roll), and it is easy to explain so it's a great game to bring to the table for people who aren't as familiar with strategy board games. Interestingly, if I go too long without playing Stone Age I find myself really craving to play!

RATING: 8
Played final prototype at Hans im Glueck game evening before actual publication. Solid competition game with interaction through competition. Unusually for Hans im Glueck it uses dice as a statistical mean, but this works ok and doesn't distract from the game which is essentially a resource management game where one can try out various very different strategis. It seems that these strategies have to be very doggedly followed to have some effect, there is little fluctuation once you decide what you want to strive for, but the easy game flow and nice theme make up for this slight critique.

RATING: 6
Mildly interesting worker placement game with multiple paths to victory.  For me, fails to evoke the theme.  A bit fiddly and with significant down time.  Luck may play too large a part to satisfy some players.  Overall, overstays its welcome by about 30 minutes if your game takes the 90 minute interval stated on the box.  In this niche, I prefer Saint Petersburg (http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/9217/saint-petersburg), which plays faster, is less luck dependent and has art that I find more pleasing.

RATING: 10
Upgraded the rating to a 10 (from 9).  The more I play it the more I like it.  Insane replayability.  I've been playing it over Dominion online, even great 2 players.

For a dice game this has suprising depth.  The dice tend to average out in the long run, every once in a while making or breaking turns, means you can't totally rely on your plans coming through.

I've played this game a couple dozen times, and it is still interesting.  It is light and fun, but still engaging enough to keep people interesting.  

It has taken the place of Settlers for my default dice introductory game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Stone Age looks pretty basic, and to a certain extent it is, but I enjoy playing when I'm in the right mood. The self-tailored end game scoring associated with the civilization cards is brilliant and helps create strategies for players to pursue. The 'town' actions are too scarce and tend to create scripted moves during the beginning of a new round. Overall, there isn't enough complexity for me to invest much table time, but it is a satisfying every now and again.

RATING: 7
I was reasonably satisfied with this game. I don't think the worker placement genre benefits from the addition of dice randomization though.  

After a few more plays I would suggest you do not look at the dice as a randomizer, but as a risk managment affair. Hopefully you are rarely putting yourself in situations where you need a certain roll to turn out one way or another. Hopefully you are taking risks on speculations that will help you acquire more resources as the game goes on. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very pretty and semi-complex, balanced game that one can learn and understand on their first play. It almost feels like a lighter version of Agricola. I like that it gets more tense each round (although some moves seem pretty obvious and predefined), and that there are different ways and strategies to collect victory points. At first sight I thought the dice rolling would bother me, but that isn't the case - the dice rolling plays just a small part in the whole puzzle.

RATING: 7
A typical theme-less Euro but reasonably fun. I like the uncertainty of resource production and trying to find the right equilibrium between having more workers and having enough food. The game also moves along at a good pace - not too much AP for a worker-placement game. 

However, several things detract from the enjoyment of the game. 1) Too long with four players. The 60-minute time stated in the BGG entry is clearly not meant for a 4-player game. 2) Players must have a reasonable idea of the importance of what's being collected or a runaway leader will develop.

RATING: 8
A VERY FUN prehistoric-themed game with a combination of several mechanics:

A very cutthroat worker-placement, because the food track and tool are very useful. A set-collection mechanic from the civ cards. And building game where each building gives a certain amount of VPs.

Played it twice now, and it's still very interesting to play again. Comes with a leather-prehistoric looking-dice shaker. Very fun but still tactical and strategic. I can't believe I can enjoy playing dice like in this game because I usually don't really like 6d dices..

Best played with 4 people. 3 people is still acceptable, but with 2 people gets a bit boring..

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game hits a sweet spot for me. I really like how the dice rolling mechanic works to get resources of different values. Also, I feel like unlucky rolls are mitigated over time by smart meeple placement and developing tools. The blocking tactic is here as in most worker placement game but it doesn't feel too harsh here; I usually feel like there are other good sites to place my meeples that will give me an advantage on future turns. The components are gorgeous. The game scales very well from 2 to 4 players. I guess my only small negative is the down time. There is nothing for you to do while other players are carrying out their actions. But the game is good enough to make up for that, definitely! 

Style is the Goal expansion included. What a stupid name.

RATING: 6
Man oh man, do I hate worker placement games.  I'm trying to figure out why, beyond the obvious truth that I utterly suck at them.  I think of a game like In The Shadow of the Emperor, which I like a lot, and think 'well that has limited action options too'.  But then again, those actions have been priced by their inherent value, while in Stone Age, action selection seems to be very subject to simply who is seated first when the best thing is clear.

This type of game is certainly thematically suspect.  Am I to believe that there was only a single copulation hut in the pre-metallurgic era?  Seems inconvenient.  Am I to believe that Stone Age denizens chopped wood and mined gold so that they could collect series' of pictures?

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great worker placement game, not as heavy as Agricola.  Count on up to 30 minutes per player. The artwork on the board is fantastic (reminds me of Pillars)!  The theme is more appealing than I initially thought - it's basically a hunter/gather type community.  It is a typical euro game in many respects (think: St Petersburg, Notre Dame, Pillars of the Earth, Age of Empires III - meeple placement, resources, victory points, buildings, short term and long term rewards), but it does have some unique elements, and the components are fantastic - I'd have to regard it as one of the better and more enjoyable ones out there.  Many say that the gameplay and mechanics are most similar to Pillars of the Earth and Agricola, as discussed [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/322197]here[/url] and [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/313367]here[/url], but it has the advantage of being accessible enough to be played with non-gamers.  Replayability could also prove to be an issue, because in the early games players are likely to compete for the same placements?  
Two player game works very well (you can block what your opponent is aiming for), although going for food production & extra people seems like an essential strategy to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a good lightweight worker placement game that marries light strategy, worker placement, interaction, and dice. The interaction is great in how you can take things from people, even take a spot that you don't intend to activate (unlike its contemporary Kingsburg); this facet provides tension. 

The strategy of the game is not very deep, though. You simply pick a VP ladder and climb the heck out of it while rolling well (you hope). The resources are practically the same resource, just a different grade of it. I’ve played a couple dozen games of it on table and online (where most of my plays were actually). 

I enjoyed my plays of Stone Age and could play online as a diversion, but for a dice strategy game, we now enjoy Troyes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nice and easy dice & worker placement game that actually gets me on a good mood. Ready to give it more tries.

RATING: 8
iOS Version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Yo dawg, I hear you like set collection
so I put set collection in your set collection so you could set collect while you set collect.

Everything in this game is about matching your sets.  Buying those boat advancements give you additional victory points at the end of the game.  Sometimes those come from the number of workers you have.  Sometimes, they're from your tools.  Maybe you're going to collect technology this time?  Who knows!

Beyond the set collection, the resource management is incredibly flat and fair.  Gold is worth 6vp, because you need 6s to get it.  In that sense, it's always a better choice to take cheap wood than expensive gold.  However, the civ cards need gold, so you'll have to get some of that too.

Great trade-offs and balanced game play.  If someone suggested Lords of Waterdeep, I'd ask for this instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It was fun, and there are various routes you can take, but it's another use-meeples-to-get-resource-to-trade-in-for-VPs type game. Not bad in itself, but it's treading a well worn path. You have to keep your meeples fed, which worked well enough, but the combinations of choices to get VPs became a little boring over the game. No interaction except for taking a position before the player after you gets it, and there's a lot of dice rolling which does introduce a significant elemnet of luck. Not chance, luck; lucky rolls get you a lot of food or resources, which you can then cash in on your next turns, freeing your meeples up to do other owrk of national impostance. Bad dice rolls mean you have to send them back to do it again, and your game subsists instead of growing. But it was fun. I'll play it again but I may mark it down, to 5 even, if the dice luck is too important.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of my all-time favourite worker placement games. Tactical and yet plain simple fun. Gateway game with lots of theme and great quality components. I've played this with my parents, just saying!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Yet another "worker placement" game.  It features a fun dice mechanic that's not overly luck dependent.  The score ranges are CRAZY!  First place can be in the 300's while 2nd place in the mid 100's.  This is due to the multiplier score bonuses from the cards you get.  The cost of these cards reduce in the next round as previously unwanted cards are shifted to the side.  The feel of the game isn't much different than others, but I think the game stands strong on its own because of the clever scoring method and the neat dice implementation. Grade: B
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
OCT 2017: 11 plays plays listed here, and I haven't played for more than 5 years! This game has aged well, I think. In fact, my rating has jumped back up a bit. There is just enough tension the various parts of the game to make it a fun game if played at a good clip.

2009: Played 10 times, with 2-4 players. Like it a TON more than Pillars of the Earth - which it is very similar to - because the things that you acquire in Stone Age can be used in more ways than the things you acquire in Pillars. If Stone Age is replayable, I will bump it to a 9. My only concern is the repetitveness. The "lather, rinse, repeat" remark is spot on, so the question is, do you like doing what you do in this game enough for that not to bother you? Ticket to Ride falls into that camp for me: same couple of actions over and over and over, but you have to play a bit of defense, and work hard to keep your options open and have a variety of different big ways to accumulate points. If Stone Age has those qualities, it is a solid 9, if not a 10. I have a feeling it IS going to be that good. I'll update when I get 5 more plays in. /EDIT/ It's a 9 now. So many strategies can work, and that was my main concern. /EDIT/ Nope. Too repetitive. Ratings History: 8889998777 (Bday. Sold.)

RATING: 8.4
Quality board game.  Wooden pieces in different shapes instead of cubes painted different colors.  Leather dice cup.  Gorgeous graphics.  And the game plays well with numerous ways to score.  Learning curve is easy and rules are few and well written.  In fact, the board leads you through your turn so that referral to rules was minimal.  Looking forward to more plays.  Several avenues to winning.  The more I play it, the more I like it.

RATING: 8
A brilliant re-hashing of familiar game mechanics which works perfectly.  The game features many ways to advance your position but each player should keep an eye on who's picking up what in the cards.  End game bonus counts can skew the scores wildly.  A measure of your success can be gauged on how much effort is spent in hoarding food; if you're always forced to send lots of meeples to the food store, you're doing something wrong.  Great fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
For the most part this is a solid game, and with the right people in the right environment I enjoy it. There are several game design decisions that are a major drawback for me, though. The randomness (die rolling) for just a few things seems a little out of place when most things are not random. The outcome of some cards/card types is overly determined by the order players are sitting around the board. And finally there's a major, in my opinion, flaw in how feeding (or specifically, not feeding) works. The penalty (or, as explained by the designer, the trade) for not having sufficient food in your supply (or resources, should you chose to convert them to food) is 10 points, regardless of if you fail to feed one person or ten. While strictly considering this rule's impact on the game it may be fine (ie, it's a strategy that is within the bounds of the rules, and there are strategies to combat it), to me it just doesn't make any sense and further ruins a game that already had a few minor strikes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The game, for a light game with some good strategy, is excellent overall.  It's fun rolling the dice and they add ups and downs to deal with, but there are enough dice rolls that the luck evens out by the end.  My only problem is that while there are enough decent strategies to choose from at any one point in time, none of them ever seem to end up being the wrong choice.  It's like after you've played a few times, you can't really mess up.  The one exception being when people rush the buildings.  Then you better be building yourself or you'll have a problem.  Games are usually decided by a narrow margin in my experience but you never even know the game is that close because there's usually a lot of multipliers out there worth a ton of points.

RATING: 8
I really prefer this game with 2-3 people. 

Playing 4 player, I fell a little out of love with it. Seemed more tedious than fun waiting for people to finish resolving their turns. 

It's a good gateway, and I love the economic aspect of this game. I've got lots of friends who really love this, but for newbie gamers, I always seem to want it to be better/more interesting/exciting than it is and am always afraid that I've bored their pants off. Waiting for people to resolve their turns can get a bit tiring. 

I do, however, really love this game for 2 and fills the 2nd tier gateway niche really perfectly. I think it's a must have.

RATING: 7
Nothing revolutionnary in this game. The luck factor keeps it from being "solved", but it also turns it into a somewhat simplistic game. It's another one of these games where every road is equally worthwile, as long as you stick to your plan. All in all, an interesting way to spend an hour.

On the downside, I'm not a fan of the division-and-rounding that you keep on doing in this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.01
After 20 games of Stone Age (2/3 of which were played with the expansion), I'm ready to say: Great Game! I reviewed it in detail here:

http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/851956/stone-age-expansion-my-first-worker-placement-gam

But to summarize:

Stone Age is a worker placement game that perfectly satisfies our family's love of light-to-medium gateway games like Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride. It manages to achieve a healthy balance between luck and skill, presents several interesting choices per turn, and is very re-playable thanks to the different hut/card ordering each game. It also has less screwage than most other gateway games (especially with the expansion), which especially suits my wife's temperament. And most victory points are hidden all game which means you'll happily play your game in ignorant bliss as you achieve your mini goals and build up your economic engine, not really knowing for sure if you're winning or losing.

It's the combination of all of these elements that makes this a great gateway game.

It veers towards medium on the light-to-medium complexity scale. And that means it's a little more complicated and a little longer and a little more math oriented than other popular gateway games, and worst of all it has more down time. But that's more than made up for by frequent interesting choices, less screwage and not knowing how badly you're losing, all of which is even more true with the expansion.

In other words, this game is fun to play, even when you lose. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Secret Santa 2012!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many people seem to think Stone Age is a dice game. It's not. While it's impossible to win the game without using any dice at all there are various other factors that have a lot more influence on winning or losing than the dice (event cards, for one). Stone Age allows different strategies, and in most cases the amount of luck that is there can be reduced by other means. It's somewhat hard to explain to non-gamers in part due to the different strategies, but the rules are pretty simple and easily understood by more experienced players. Most newbies like it, too, once they get the hang of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Stone Age changed my opinion on the new crop of worker placement games.  Before Stone Age I had my fill with Caylus, AoE III, etc.  They either failed to excite, or they just were laborious to a point of exhaustion and never quite provided the rewards in respect to the work involved.  I had also found the systems in place to be rather clunky, and the designs a little unpolished.  Well then came Stone Age, after a good while of avoiding such games, and to my surprise I adored it.  The design was clean, and the play was smooth.  The randomizers (dice, card/building distribution) added replay ability to the game rather than providing the feeling of something off, and unbalanced to the point of breaking it in any ones favor (AoE III).  It is in no means a heavy game, nor is it a complete wash in terms of decision making.  It in fact reaches a nice balance between weight and length, and could even be offered up as a gateway while providing a good challenge for seasoned gamers.  
The production values are amazing, and leave one wondering why the price point is lower than most of it's brethren that have lesser components.  All in all, Stone Age is a strong addition to the worker placement genre and has enjoyed numerous plays, with many more to come.

UPDATE:  with the arrival of Agricola, and plays of both Cuba and Pillars -  Stone Age has lost a little of it's shine, but I still find it to be a solid, and fun design.  In many ways I think this could be a replacement for Settlers in turning people on to modern Euros.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game. No posts to his wife did not win :-). Beautifully framed, the rules clearly written. We should not gape with green cards development :-). Never regretted buying this game.
