=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2-4 player worker placement game.  Medium weight.  Light to medium luck.

Like the title applies, Stone Age is a game set in prehistoric times where you control a group of homo sapiens who are tasked with resource collecting, improving agriculture, and building infrastructure.  In order, players will place variable amounts of their workers across the game board, where spots are available.  The main mechanism resolves these placements by rolling a number of dice corresponding to the number of workers placed in any one area; hence, the more workers placed in an area, the better the chance you have of generating more resources.  Civilization and building tiles can then be purchased via resources accumulated, which is the main way to generate victory points.  Naturally after all this is done, you still need to make sure you have food to feed the family.

Gameplay in Stone Age is not overly complicated; the crux of the strategy is balancing your worker placement in things you need, while mitigating or preventing what your opponents can do with their workers.  I would suggest one play through is enough to become familiar with the game and how civilization and building tiles effectively generate points, so the learning curve is not very steep.  This is a very good introductory worker placement game because it highlights a few key things important to any advanced WP game (say, Agricola) but is not overly punishing.

Where the game really takes off is with 4 players.  Playing with 2-3, the game rules dictate a few placement rules which make it more restrictive, but Stone Age shines when the whole board comes into play with 4 players.  In fact I may have not recommended it at all... until I played with 4.  In doing so and opening my eyes to the beauty of the game, I can wholeheartedly recommend Stone Age as a well rounded entry level game.  If you are completely against any sort of chance (dice rolling, in this case) in this sort of genre, you may want to look elsewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Another worker placement game.  The twist here is that rolling the dice determines how much (if any) of a resource a particular work gets.  Though luck does have its influence in the game the relatively short duration of the game combined with the frequency of dice rolls and the usually less than catastrophic effect of any one dice roll means that the dice rolling mechanic doesn't irk me like it might in other games where dice rolls determine the number of resources you get.

RATING: 8
[B]Stone Age[/b] [I]Michael Tummerhoffer 2008[/i]
The best introductory game I had ever played, Stone Age fully derserves its high ranking position. The game is quite easy to explain, fast paced and has quite a lot of interesting options during its gameplay. Stone Age is in my book the introductory game to keep if you only want to have one in your collection. Good replayability, nice components and some deepth. These are the good qualities of this design. It works perfectly ewith non gamers and it is interesting enough for gamers. Didnt like the expansion though, since it adds complexity that the game does not need at all.

RATING: 6
June 08 - 2 plays at AGE - Darn it!  It *IS* good! One of my few "first time I play it and it gets an 8/10" of the Expo.  Great mechanics in this worker placement Euro and the theme was fun as well. I was "baby man" and had great food problems... :)  The end game scoring is FANTASTIC as in my first game I was behind about 40-50 points, but won by about 10 in final scoring.  In our second game, we had no idea who would win until the final tally.  (May get more obvious with more plays, but it avoided 'screw your neighbour tactics, which was good).  Tense, as there is almost always 2+ things you want to do, and you KNOW you won't be able to do one of them by the time it comes around the table again.
Love it 2-player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stone Age works well as a two-player game for my husband and me. With no conflict other than competition for resources, the game offers a peaceful experience of exploring ways for a tribe to survive and thrive. The rules are not too complex, and the game lasts about the right amount of time for us--about an hour and a half from setup to takedown (even though we are both prone to over-analyze our options). It has some luck, but the most skillful player has won every game we have played so far. The integration of the theme with the game is nearly perfect, and the component are beautiful and a pleasure to handle.

RATING: 5
I've been eyeballing this one for some time, and finally took the plunge. People are right about the smell of the dice cup...man does it frigging STINK.

Well, for what it is and what it accomplishes, the play time is far too long.

I should know better than to buy euros that are rated highly on BGG. I just don't seem to fit the mold of what constitutes a fun (euro)game on this site. It looks neat but for how simple the rules are, and the number of things you can do on a turn, why the hell does it take over 90 minutes 2-player?

This is one that I don't find very much fun at all....at least the theme is different, but as usual, like 90% of the top games on BGG, I find it dry, dull, and boring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game. Similar in some ways to Puerto Rico. (players take turns to choose an action. No direct conflict. All actions have a powerful opportunity cost to yourself and other players.) Everyone has to be on their toes and remembering the cards that everyone else has collected though. In this way dissimilar to puerto Rico, and a slightly larger, but very fun, element of luck. If you aren't comfortable with these memory or luck elements to the game, you may not like Stone Age. Much easier to learn and play than Puerto Rico, and prettier. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
[gameid=34635] is a good worker placement game that has the bonus of being accessible to newer players. Beautiful artwork, easy to get into, and fun to play. It also scales very well from two to four players.

There is a bit of downtime while you are waiting for the other players to carry out their actions, but it isn't excessive.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Stone Age is an enjoyable but disposable game that will probably see three or four plays before I move on. It would have more staying power if it were shorter, but our games have lasted longer than the advertised 60 minutes.  I think the game's wonderful aesthetic appeal is a large part of what is drawing me back for repeat visits, because honestly this is a game without a lot of spark or nuance. It seems very weird to me that all the resources are basically interchangeable, and worth exactly the same in terms of VPs/pip.

[Update] Yup, I think I've played four times now. While I wouldn't object to playing again, I would definitely attempt to steer the selection to a different game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Just a big fan of this game. Some of the moves seem very simple (use the Love Hut, increase your Agriculture at every chance, always buy the one resource card, etc.), but the game takes on its beauty when playing against human opponents when they thwart your strategy. Yes, the dice can cause you some issues from time to time, but I never feel like the game hinges on luck, rather I was too stupid and didn't send enough workers to get resources, which fits the theme. Yes, technically the game can be "mathed" out by figuring out what your best placement is on every turn, but that is usually not a game breaking flaw. My biggest complaint with the game is that the board could be bigger, a LOT bigger.

RATING: 7
Another game in the vein of Pillars of the Earth. There are no flaws in "Stone Age" (except that historical one that your men can dig for gold), but then, the feeling of the game is "been there, done that". Therefore I state it's a good and solidly designed game but don't expect any breathtakingly new if you already know Pillars, Caylus etc. You mainly roll the dice for resources to turn them into victory points. If Stone Age was released two years ago, it would be a major hit! But now it's only one of many games that uses those mechanics of placing your workers on actions. Maybe it would have profited if there was beside the economic development and the set collection for VP also something like a threat to prepare like the rats in Notre Dame or the enemies in Kingsburg.

RATING: 8
Our gateway game ;) highly recommended!
It's beautiful, well designed with couple way to win, nice dice rolling mechanism (lot better than that in Ghost Stories for example) with just a little interaction which doesn't make game agressive but challenging. It's so positive game where you can see you tribe growing and developing. Result isn't known till end of play which makes it exciting. I only miss more complex buildings (which could do anything like making your worker more efficient) and after playing more game I think it's a little bit too long for this level of complexity...but again: perfect gateway which has brought us to games like agricola, caylus and so on.

RATING: 7
Good game. A typical resource conversion game with a standard worker placement mechanic, in a simple and straight-forward format. The dice rolls, however, create a lot of chaos and unpredictability in the resource flow. If this game had truly been a 60 minute game (or max. 60-75 min with new players), my rating would have gone up and I would have considered it a terrific candidate (perhaps one of the best) for transitioning new gamers to more advanced resource management games. At present, I think it overstays its welcome a little bit, and the repeated dice rolls become a bit tedious towards the end. But it's still a fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My introduction to the worker-placement genre.  You can start the game with a certain strategy in mind (e.g. focusing on getting lots of tools or additional workers) but this might change depending on what cards or huts are available.  Lots of tense decisions to make...you might really need that 3-cost civilization card, but you also need to have a way to pay for it.  So do you go for the card first and hope your opponent(s) doesn't hog the wood?  Or do you go for wood first and hope your opponent doesn't catch on to your desire for that particular card?

RATING: 6

I think this may have been a good game for its time, but I don't think some of the mechanics have aged well compare to newer game like Agricola. RATING: 8

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I found it to be simple and smooth.  I think family and other non-gamers might play while being able to follow and stay interested.  Looking forward to playing again.  Prefer this to Agricola which has become the worker placement standard.  The production quality, artwork, and gorgeous bits all put the overpriced Agricola to shame.  By comparison, SA is a value.  

It does seem that 3rd and especially 4th players are at a significant disadvantage, as they aren't able to start farming until 3 or 4 turns in.  Thus they must either choose the starvation path or waste more meeples hunting than the other players.  If playing with inexperienced or especially non-gamers, let them go first.  If playing with people who all know the game, recommend some house rules to help out the non-start players.  Not sure how to balance this, but maybe adding 1,2,3 or even 2,4,6 food to players the further down the turn order.  Not playtested, just an idea for now.  

Still, if you can play games "just for fun" (I can) don't let you put this off this delightful and beautifully produced Euro.

RATING: 6
It worked well enough, but like many games coming out recently, I didn't feel like it offered anything particularly new or exciting. It also seemed to take too long for what it was. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very good worker placement game. The unique element is the number of dice you roll is equal to the number of workers you place on a resource location.  This adds a 'press your luck' element that is different than most worker placement games (ie, if I need one stone, how many people do I need to place there?).

I think it is more of a Family game than a Strategy game as decisions are more tactical and your strategy is determined by the multiplier cards you buy. I can see why deep strategy players don't like it. It does seem 'samey' thru the game, but now that my family knows how to play, the game we just finished was very tense throughout the game.

Some people didn't like the smell of the cup, but mine smells like leather, so I don't mind it. (purchased the 2013 Z-Man version)

I also bought the Rio Grande 'Style is the Goal' expansion and all the parts fit in the main box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Having said that I do like the bonus cards and huts that add a random element. Also, is it me or is the score track nowhere near long enough (it goes to 100 with scores over 200 seemingly frequent)?

RATING: 8.72

RATING: 9

I also like the idea of playing in 'rounds' with resetting everything and starting again each round.

RATING: 8.5
What a fantastic worker placement game. I had only played Catan before this, and it never really hit the spot with me. I can't quite figure out the strategy yet, but I think that is what makes for a great game. It keeps you wanting to come back and see if a different strategy will get you into that winners circle. The bits and art are also great. I love the game board. One of the better ones that I have ever seen.

Update (Jan2012): I have now played games with 2, 3, and 4 players. It scales really well, but I think I enjoy it with 3 or 4 the most. This has become a favorite among my friends and tends to hit the table more than other games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
When the worker placement mechanic was still new, I thought it was a little derivative of "The Pillars of the Earth" - an impression strengthened by the board art and style. A few years and dozens of plays later, it is just my favorite worker placement game. It is also one of the lightest, due to plenty of dice rolls, but luck is kept at a tolerable level and there are ways to minimize it. There certainly could be a little more theme in the cards and buildings, and using random resources to acquire them does feel a little abstract, but it still is an excellent and somehow addictive game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I am a big fan of this game. I am always weary of dice in games that last an hour or more, but I have found that any bad luck with the dice can be mitigated with a combination of tools and strategy. The game is much simpler than something like Agricola in the number of choices that you have available on a given turn. Depending on your audience, and what you are looking for this can be a very good thing. It is easy to teach, and doesn't suffer as badly from situations where someone is an expert that no one can compete with because they know all of the cards, etc. I generally play with 2 since that is my "group" size, but I have played the iOS version with 3 and 4 on multiple occasions. I think the game scales very nicely with 2 and actually like playing it that way. I believe it becomes more tactical and less random with fewer players since you can directly respond to your opponents strategy. Final note, there are multiple paths to victory in every game. I have won games, and actually been beaten by the best AI in the iOS game when he (or I, since I also employed the strategy after losing to it) did not build a single building. I have also built 8 buildings in a 2 player game and won. I win frequently against my living and iOS opponents without getting a single extra pawn, but can just as easily win with 9 or 10 out. The path to take always evolves depending on what your opponents do and what options are presented to you on your turn.

RATING: 8
D.A

Es un euro, de colocar trabajadores, gestionar recursos y ganar puntos, pero uno un poco mas suave dentro del genero, que otros ejemplos del mismo. 

En este, se obtienen recursos mediante una combinacion de emplazar trabajadores y tirar dados (viene a ser lo "eficientes" que han sido los trabajadores obteniendo los recursos), sobre un mapa donde hay ciertos limites para emplazar los trabajadores. y luego con los recursos obtenidos se compran determinados objetos, que son los que proporcionan los puntos. 

Un juego con una jugabilidad muy agradable, sin ser por ello menos variado y desafiante, muy rejugable, visualmente por encima de la media en el genero. 

En mi opinion, un excelente juego.

RATING: 5

To be fair, Stone is awfully pleasant--a solid worker-placement game. But it's not as good as Leonardo, Age of Empires, or Pillars of the Earth given its length.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tentative rating. I'm sure that after more plays I would either be dazzled by the array of strategic options or disillusioned by the overpoweredness of a single one. This game is almost Agricola's evil twin. Both involve using workers to gain resources and then having to feed your workers. In Agricola, you feel you can never do everything you want to do and you are always on the verge of starvation. In this game, feeding the family is almost an afterthought, and you can score points in almost every category by the end of the game. I'm not sure if this is better or worse, but at least this game doesn't hurt your head as much or take as long. May be a bit too random for the amount of thinking here too, but that could just be an odd first impression. Bottom line, it's an intriguing mix of a bunch of different games that really do work well together. But it certainly doesn't break any new ground.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
over played it online
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After one play, I'm not very enthused by this game.  I don't hate it, but I don't really want to play it again.  This is possibly because at heart, it's a dice game -- rolling badly throughout the game can just kill your score, and that's no fun.  As many players have written, your score depends on how efficiently you convert die rolls into points.  The building tiles are worth as many points as the number of pips on the die rolls that you spent to get the corresponding goods.  Of course, if you can get goods by other means (such as by buying cards which provide resources to you, or benefiting from other players who buy cards with "resources for everyone" dice rolls on them, or by using tools to improve your die rolls), all the better.  Shrewd choice about which cards to buy is also important, so at least there is some strategic element to the game.

In my first game, I played the "don't bother to feed your people and lose 10 points each turn" strategy, and won by over 30 points (with a total of 177 points).  The strategy succeeded because I could completely ignore actions that would help me generate food, freeing me up to roll for more resources than other players.  I also chose breeding hut more often, and got all 10 meeples out, which allowed me to do even more every turn than other players.  Furthermore, I got 40 points at the end of the game because I bought cards that added up to 4 points per meeple, and 33 more points because I bought cards that added up to 3 points per completed building (of which I built an astounding 11).  It's possible that I was able to succeed with this strategy because I got to go first in the first turn; maybe going 4th (out of 4) would have made this strategy not-so-viable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is really like a simplified Pillars with dice, but some of the challenge has been suppressed, while if you want to know the score of the other players, you'll need to recompute everything each time they draw a civ card, which feels a little cumbersome for a light game, but is the only way to play competitively.  You'll build small huts and each time you'll wonder why they serve no purpose besides the points.
The dice rolling for collecting ressources is fun, but much too important.
There are only 2 distinct strategies.
It is not a bad game - far from that; the components and the brightness of illustrations, the dice make it a pleasant experience; anyway, I would rather play Pillars, where the game starts slowly and builds up to the end, whereas in Stoneage every turn feels the same. 

After the few first games, Stone Age has just become dull and the inherent randomness is felt more and more.

RATING: 8.5
Outstanding game, what a Euro should be!  Yes there are dice, but you can reduce luck by managing your resources (sending more workers).  Except for a few typos (like the use of Tools) the rules are clear and concise.  Mechanics and gameplay is clean, yet there are multiple ways to victory.  Game scales well with 2-4 players, although I suspect it is best with 4 (played a 3-player game and it remained close!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My wife and I absolutely loved this game.  The idea of gaining points through the purchasing of cards and multiplying this by other “investments” you make throughout the game (like adding babies, adding to the food supply, etc.) is a very clever mechanism.  In addition, you can score points through hut building, which makes some interesting choices when playing the game.

The components of the game are very nice, and I especially like the nice Stone Age themed dice cup that is provided (along with everything else that goes with the theme).

I can tell this is not one of my favorite games for my son, but I am not really sure why.  He is usually really good at figuring out games like this, but for some reason he has trouble with this one.

Oh, and one interesting tidbit for our particular situation:  We had been using tools completely wrong, and let’s just say it made tools less valuable.  Even with misplaying it like this, we really enjoyed Stone Age.  Now that we play it correctly, it is even more enjoyable (and my son won our first game playing it the correct fashion, so this may help his enjoyment of it in the long run).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[Initial Impression: 6]
Interesting in that it feels somewhat different mechanics-wise from many other resource collect/trade games. Suffers from having too much information be hidden, so that the final scoring is all-important, yet mostly mysterious. I do like the controlled use of dice, as you can overcome the luck factor by using tools to modify rolls and by dedicating more workers to the task (hence rolling more dice). Several different strategies are clearly possible. Kind of fun, but feels extremely light in comparison to other (superior, imo) games of this genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
After Settlers of Catan we used to play this game a lot. I fount an unboxing video on youtube and immediatelly fall in love with the artwork. I started to play it at yucata.de and than followed at boardgamearena.com. We bought the original box and played it in person too. But after a while the game just got a little boring and it is rare to play ot nowadays.

Pros / Cons:
-I absolutely love the theme of the game.
-This is the most beautiful artwork that i have ever seen.
-The idea of the tool to manage luck is very cool.
-You have multiple strategies to play with, go for population, or just go with tools etc.

-But after playing this gem for such a long time we get enough of it, it was an outstanding step of our journey.

RATING: 6
"Spreadsheet Game". It's a derogatory term that successfully applies itself here. This game requires no interaction with your fellow players. It's a race for the VP and it's pretty straightforward. There doesn't seem to be anything truly unique about it...

If it aims to be a gateway game, it is successful, but less so than Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
1-2-13
For a long time, I really liked Stone Age.  There was something about it that I couldn't justify a 10 though.  Now I own a copy though, and am able to play it more frequently with 2 players.  It's surprisingly good with 2 for a Eurogame, and as such, I've updated my rating to a 10.

The different strategic choices to make are intuitive and varying so no game plays quite the same.  Dice can certainly jerk a person around, but the built-in factor of a worker count helps equalize that, or give you some control over your risk and luck tolerance.  I've learned to appreciate the tools much more.  The different objectives on each of the cards helps to keep you engaged, whether trying to track the symbol sets or simply chasing after the multipliers.  Of course, great artwork and a fun theme help too, as does ease of teaching and play.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played this again after being introduced to it six months ago. I recall why I don't like this game as much. It is a dice rolling, "Yahtzee on steroids" contest. You will do well if you can consistently roll high totals with your dice, sort of like Kingsburg. The place your workers mechanic is simple and straightforward a la Leonardo Da Vinci. The theme is sort of light, but makes for good fun as you nurture your "cavemen" meeples. I don't mind this once in awhile, but otherwise I can't shake the fact that it is Yahtzee-esque with a theme pasted on top of it.

Update: After being 'forced' to play this three times, and finally winning a 4-player game by a squeaker, I'm reconsidering this game (perhaps it is the 3-player game that I can't stand). It's still totally dependent on your ability to roll high totals. However, what you do with those high totals seems to be the key to winning the game. The points turn into specific resources, which in turn can be converted into victory points through a variety of ways, but everyone is competing for those limited ways; blocking seems to be a necessary tactic. It seems focusing on one path is doomed to fail, while an aggressive and balanced approach may be better--this game rewards gambling: if you're lucky, you will do very well; if you're unlucky, you will be punished; and if you take the 'safe' route, well, you'll do so-so. I'm still figuring this out, but the comments about it being broken because it is based on luck seems on target, although I can see that getting lots of tools should remedy that somewhat.

Update (2/28/09): For my 4th game, I went all out for tools and the tool multipliers, plus went for 7 meeples early (which I thought was the optimum number for a 4p game), but ignored farms, and went half-heartedly for civ cards (in the past, I'd go all out for civ cards). The guy that went for farms and meeples with multipliers won decisively. The other player that went for converting good rolls into resources, and then into huts, tied with me for 2nd place. The winning player got 7-8 farms, which allowed him to get 9 meeples. With some tools, he was able to go after gold, and convert on several 1-7 huts. I'm finding this game intriguing, realizing that die rolling isn't as important (except when all players are of equal skill), as I initially thought.

Update (4/24/09): Another player went for 10 cavemen and multipliers and managed to get 200+ points in a 4P game. Another player went for farms and multiplies and did the same. I went for tools (and managed to get my first '4' tool ever), but fell far behind--all those tools need to be used to get good stuff, which I did not convert enough of.

Update (5/3/09): Okay, I admit it--this is a great game. The randomness belittles the marvelous interplay of players' actions, resources, and how they convert them efficiently into victory points.  There is substantial player interaction, since the resource collection spots, the farm, the tool shack, the "love" shack, the cards, and the huts are limited. I'm torn every turn, as I want to do everything, but have very few workers to do it with, while trying to thwart my opponents, or mitigate their counter-plays. I'm upping it to a solid '8'. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
規則:
1.建築物一疊七張 四人四疊，三人三疊，兩人兩疊
2.起始5個人，12個食物
3.已放過的區域不能在之後再補放
4.食物不夠，一定要全部付完後不夠補資源，可以選擇不付資源扣10分(不管少付多少)，分數會低於0
5.文明卡補不滿或是建築到底，遊戲結束
6.每個資源一個一分
7.2~3人時，中間只能有兩區被占領，3人時，採集去只能有兩個人放，2人時一個
8.拿兩個任意資源的文明卡，可以任意時間使用，用完蓋著
3人規則:
 生人、升田、工具 每輪只能進去兩個建築，第三棟不可進入
 同一種資源最多兩位玩家進入
 (2位玩家一種1人)

 所有資源都是一次性進入 不可以補進　
沒食物付要扣１０分　資源可以一換一抵

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Collecting resources by placing workers on the board. The more workers placed in a spot, the more dice you can roll (1 per worker) to increase the amount of resources yielded.

Resources are spent on huts (straight points) or cards which do various things. Good intro worker placement game.

RATING: 5
An inferior version of Pillars of the Earth (which itself was an inferior Caylus) with die rolling used to randomise the number of resources you get. There's a little scope for risk taking in where you place your people given the resources needed for a building and the need to gather food, but Pillars is much more thematic even if it is just as repetitive. The idea of sex behind the hut is cringe-inducingly funny though, I can't believe the publisher didn't spot that before this came out.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The luck factor in the cards and huts actually far more effect on the game than do the dice. The cards in particular are VERY important and all players need to realize that.  The game becomes much more interesting late, when there is some tension about placing on a card vs. getting more materials or improving the value of cards you already have, but compared to other worker placement games, you have less information about what is good for your opponents and what is good for you, and most of your options are a little easier to get.  So, there's less tension, less basis for making decisions, less excitement.  (4 plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
IMO, this is the game that deserves the raves that Agricola receives.  The same type of game (worker placement/resource management), it manages more player interaction and more elegant design/gameplay.  It shares the luck factor (dice instead of initial card deal), which is it's one weak point.  I'll take the balancing of rolls over time over the "your stuck with these cards for the game" factor anytime.
In addition, this is an excellent gateway game for those you know will have some interest in Euros.  I've yet to have someone turn their nose up at this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A fun, lightweight worker placement and resource gathering game. Scratches some of that Catan itch but, to me at least, in a much more satisfying way. The luck-driven dice rolls can still make a turn hit or miss, but tool development allows some mitigation of that. Stone Age, and Lords of Waterdeep, both make excellent intros to worker placement and both work well as gateways. I'd give the edge to Stone Age only because the LoW theme can be a slight turn-off for some players (despite being barely skin deep).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Indifferent - unless 2p/3p online. I'm too good at this :>

Player hundred of this. Mostly 2p online. 

With so many point-salad games out there, I admire the overall structure of the game, very clean & pure(I have too many words for this, better just skip them here). In short, as concise as old school German, there is enough "meat" for a Euro gamer.

Despite the dice rolls, I am sure the luck is not an issue. it's strategic enough for 2p/3p, at least for one's first 30 games.

As most worker placement games, scalability is an issue: more downtime and less predictability(less strategic) with more players. I would rate 9 for 2p, 8 for 3p, but 6 for 4p.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played July 10th, 2008. Taught in 10+min, played in about an hour with 4 players. The game has a great luck/strategy ratio. Each player starts out with 12 food and 5 people. Your task is to manage your resources to gain the most VPs. Resources are food(2 value), wood(3), clay(4), stone(5), and gold(6). Each round players can send a number of people to do ONE of certain tasks (gain resources, have a baby (requires two people; only one player can do this), increase food production (one; one; permenant food increase), develop a tool (one; one; helps gain future resources with one die pix per), build a hut(1 per hut; worth VPs; cost certain resources), or do trading (1 per trade; worth resources and VPs; cost 1-4 resources). After all player choose one, then may choose another single task for a number of workers. Keep going as long as someone has workers. Next the each player takes their actions, starting with the start player. A die represents each workers sent to gain resources. Roll each dice and sum the pix and divide by the resource you are trying to acquire. Rounding down, that's how many of that resource you get. After all players have gone, each pays one food for each worker they have. If you don't have enough you must pay one resource of your choice or pay 10 VPs. The game is over when one of the piles of huts are gone or the trade cards can not be replenished. I'd recommend this as a gameplay, especially if you know someone who has it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was our first 'Euro' game. Was a great introduction to gaming and we still enjoy playing it.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Superb worker placement game with exceptionally strong production value, particularly the stunning colorful gameboard illustration of primitive men deployed in myriad activities in different landscapes like forest, hills, river, village, etc.  This game has a very elegant, smooth design.  It has a pleasant, brisk play time of about 1-1.5 hours.  It has a few well-balanced paths to victory.  There's something that is just really fun about taking turns, placing workers while trying to plan a clever sequence of actions.  Some players might not like the luck factor of rolling dice for resources, but I don't mind it a bit.  Player interaction is limited in this game to competing for limited spots on the board that workers are placed on in order to perform actions.  It is fun to anticipate where other players want to put workers and screw them by putting your own workers there to put the kibosh on their plans.  There will be opportunities to attempt a risky sequence of actions in order to earn a big reward, like placing only one or two workers to harvest gold that will be needed to build a building on the same turn for example.  This game deserves to be held in higher esteem and gets overlooked more than it should.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

2010 She is eight years old now and we play the full game, it is to short she thinks :) Changed rating from 7 to 8.

2011 This game gets better and better...rating up to 9.

2013 Still a favorite of our daughter. Very good familygame.

RATING: 4.9
May08: I know, what the heck?  I played another worker placement game, by the makers of St Pete?!?  None-the-less, I did actually enjoy myself somewhat.  I do not need to own it by any means.

It suffered a couple flaws for me:

1.  All the resources were very "samey".  They converted back to points at the very same rate they were acquired.  Boring.

2. Many of the early moves are scripted.  Makin' babies and tools and food are just so powerful most of the early decisions are moot.


So, overall, I'd be willing to try it again.  If I did, I think I'd go for an all card route and see if it can be busted up just like the aristocrats in St Pete.

RATING: 7.8
Красиво оформленная "евро". Ребёнок может освоить отдельные положения теории вероятностей: сколько надо разместить рабочих в локации, чтобы получить определённое количество ресурса (определяется по результату броска кубиков).

По стратегии, необходимости анализа ходов однозначно проигрывает "Агриколе". Но есть свои прелести: оформление, элемент случайности, ниже порог освоения игры.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very tight and competitive worker placement game, with enough luck thrown in with dice rolls to mix things up without undermining the engine-building present in the game.  The game has a very simple premise - make resources to buy building tiles which score you points, easy!  But there is added depth with bonus cards, the constant need to feed your workers, multiple alternative scoring opportunities and, of course, the dice rolling.

The game plays beautifully with all numbers of players as the rules impose some limitations on worker placement with fewer players, meaning the game stays tight.  Easy to teach but cutthroat, highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
My first encounter with this game wasn't the best one and I had my first opinion clouded by bad dice rolls.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A beloved worker placement game that I enjoyed, even if strategy became very solidified and apparent every game after a few runs with more experienced players.  I don't understand the appeal of this game on BGA - it is fun enough to be sure, but after each game I felt drained as I believe it is slightly too long for what it brings to the table.  

Something I don't see mentioned enough is how mathy the game is.  While you can break down any game to math - I find myself seeing this game simply as an interactive math puzzle.  If you approach the game this way vs. people that do not - the game won't even be close.  Even with the frustrating RNG in the game, math wins every time.  My friend laments my approach to the game, but hey - Stone Age begs you to look at it this way in my opinion.   If I feel like number crunching and min maxing - Stone Age is the way to go, but bleh - that's no fun.

RATING: 8
A good introduction to worker placement games.  It's one of the lighter ones.  You are a tribe of cave men, and you need to collect resources to feed your people, multiply, build huts, and increase the culture of your people.  You can roll dice to see how many of each resource you collect.  You can also build tools to help you gain more resources.

RATING: 7
Stone Age has become the fallback option of every game night.  It's a worker placement game boiled down to its best features.  There's dice for people who like rolling bones, a detailed scoring mechanic common to most Euros, plenty of strategy and beautiful artwork that's appealing to people new to boardgames.  Best yet, Stone Age is relatively inexpensive and quick to setup/clean up.  Highly recommended.

RATING: 5.5
The designers forgot to improve on the 2 most needed areas if they were going to improve on Pillars, game length and luck. In fact, this is worse in both areas so now you have another really lucky derivitive game that runs FAR too long, especially with 4 players (luck factor is close). I will never again play with 4 unless some cards and buildings are removed to shorten the game. 

The game itself is decent other that what I mentioned, I do like the multiple paths and mutliple ways to score both good strengths. I think it is best suited to 2 players although a shortened 3 player game might still be okay and faster BSW plays would also be okay. 

Turn order is not compensated for and should have been, 1 extra food for 2nd player, 2 for 3rd player etc, 2 player doesnt suffer from this. Decisions are mostly very obvious (especially 4 player again) which also hurts this game but there is a little angst present as you want and need everything and know you wont get it. 

Great components, almost suited for gateway if shortened, repetitive, avoid if hate dice rolling (some luck can be mitigated but not all)

RATING: 7
Certainly seems like a better entry level worker placement game than Waterdeep, but it's still not very exciting. The dice are mostly not bad because you're going to be rolling a lot of them and hut building in general feels pretty reactionary since you don't know what's going to be on offer next turn necessarily. The cards actually are particularly bad about this. If you go for people and no people cards show up then you're in trouble. And I really didn't like the cards where everyone gets something, way too swingy there. But ultimately for a game this light I can look past all that. Doesn't really do anything too new or exciting, but if all you want is an entry level worker placement then this is probably the game for you. There are actual strategies that can be implemented and some real decisions to be made, which is pretty good for a light game like this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game.  After playing for the first time, I had the same feeling I had after playing Ticket to Ride the first time: this game has some staying power.  The dice can be really harsh at times, but there are ways to mitigate bad rolls (an aspect of a lot of games that I love).  The game also flows very smoothly.

I'm not sure I like the worker placement aspect though. I feel that what I want to do in a round always seems to get taken before I can get it. I need to think about strategy a bit and play a few more times before coming to a final rating.

UPDATE (after 4 plays): something clicked with me last game. I saw something regarding trading in resources for more resources (getting more for less) that I didn't see in my previous plays. It's easy to trade resources for VPs one-for-one, the challenge is finding ways to do it more efficiently.  Not sure why I didn't quite realize this before. This one "click" alone has caused me to rethink the game and I *really* want to play more. Upping the score to 8.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Relatively simple but very enjoyable worker placement game.  Each turn you put one or more of your workers in a place that gets you resources with dice rolls or special benefits.  You always need to worry about getting enough food and/or farms to feed your mob.  You get points by buying huts with the resources and buy buying one of a few cards that are available each turn.  Multiple paths to victory and challenging options while not blowing up your head.  Dice rolls add fun element of chance but without the sense that you've lost the game because of a single bad roll.  I do have a sense there are better strategies than others though, so not necessarily fully balanced.  I was very unimpressed by the tech card approach.  But every path can be countered by other players if they have an equally good sense of how good they are.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Stone Age is a fun (if sometimes frustrating) entry-level worker placement game. The luck-pushing elements seem out of place, but they do add excitement and accessibility to the game for new players.

RATING: 8
This is one of my favorite games in my collection.  It was one of the first gamer games I owned and I believe it will indefinitely stay in my collection.

When my wife is down for a game, this game often finds my table.  It is also a great game to introduce people to who have an interest in games but haven't really played any.

The art is beautiful, the mechanics simple and smooth, and while there is some luck with the dice, I feel that it has a lot of appealing strategic variety.

RATING: 6
Final thoughts: It's light, good fun and I enjoy it. Sometimes I am tempted to get a copy for myself.
-------------
Update: A handful of games later, and Stone Age is moving towards a "don't buy" for me. I like parts of it, and good strategy still eludes me (and yes, that's good) but the game feels awfully repetitive.
-------------
Update: My second game was less confusing, but the winner still pulled off a victory in a way I hadn't seen coming. I guess that is really a good thing... ;-) Anyway, while some aspects of the game are frustrating, others are quite enjoyable and I am eager to play again.
-------------
Worker placement in the stone age! Players place their meeples to gain resources, food, more meeples, tools, buildings and special cards. At the end of every turn, meeples must be fed (but they can eat wood, clay, etc. if no food is available ;)), so a certain focus on food production seems necessary - although not all may agree. Resources are used to buy buildings and special cards, which in turn yield victory points - buildings right away, and cards at the end of the game.

My first experience with the game was mixed. The game was reasonably fun but it had a lot of randomness, and the fact that the winner almost tripled his score by playing special cards at the end of the game felt a little, em, overwhelming and confusing (what's the point of scoring small amounts of points during the game, if the winner turns out to have about 135 points of hidden VP?).

Anyway, a solid game feeling like a mix of Pillars of the Earth, St. Petersburg, and Agricola (!) but not a game I am sure I really like. On the other hand my first game, while not very fun, had me thinking about it a lot afterwards. The same happened with Agricola, and I ended up liking that very much...

I generally like games that escalate somewhat, making it seem like the game situation changes as you go along, and making the endgame markedly different from the beginning. Stone Age has a bit of escalation, mainly in terms of players getting more meeples, a higher food level and more tools as the game goes on, but whether it's enough to satisfy my craving for a game with development, I don't know yet.

But as I wrote, Stone Age had me thinking, and I would certainly like to try it again.

RATING: 7
After playing a few times it's starting to grow on me...


7 is about the limit here.

It's biased a bit more to the luck based side than I prefer, though the quantity of dice rolling mitigate that a fair bit.

It feels a bit too abstract, and the decisions are pretty simple, as in determining the highest value to yourself.  Near the beginning, the choices are obvious enough, and near the end, they are obvious enough, too.

A little bit of right player binding here - the person sitting to the left of the newbie will tend to do better than the others playing.

RATING: 6
2012-09-14

Initial Rating : 8.0 (December 2010)

Having played Agricola and knowing Stone Age was a light-medium worker placement game (with dice to add insult to injury), I totally expected a negative reaction towards the game, however after some plays I really like it. Compared with Agricola, the game IS pretty light, but it still offers lots of interesting decisions AND it is very fun to play.

The rules are easy to teach, so my family can play with me and the dice adds (unexpectedly) a new layer of strategy. I generally dislike dice games, but in Stone Age you have to play the odds in a fun way. 

Perhaps the playtime is long for what the game offers, the theme is pretty weak for my taste(still better than Agricola) and the art and components are beautiful (except for the smelly cup although I have a friend who likes to smell it :S)

In conclusion, Stone Age is a game I enjoy playing right now with my light weight games oriented friends, but not a game I will request often so I have to downgrade the rating to a 7.0

Current Rating: 7.0
[hr]

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There seem to be two major objections to dice among Eurogamers.  One school of thought hates having a long game decided by a couple climactic die rolls - the small sample size effect.  Another objects to the random incomes in games like Settlers of Catan, in which hexes depend on specific die rolls to produce.

Stone Age mitigates both of these concerns.  Because of the sheer quantity of dice thrown throughout the game, there is at least a perception that the randomness evens out.  And because income is determined by spending dice pips instead of locking in specific numbers, there is no Settlers condition in which a party is screwed by a particular number "never coming up."  The dice in Stone Age are fully realized as game elements to manage, and not chaotic forces executing a disproportionate impact on the game from beyond any player's control.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8

RATING: 5
(Yet another) Euro efficiency optimiser. Spend actions (workers) to buy resources (or more workers), combine the resources to buy tiles worth VPs or cards that either give you in-game engine advantages or more VPs at the end based on sets of cards collected. 

Player interaction is limited to taking resources/tiles/cards before your opponents. Learn the tiles/cards and how to efficiently build your engine to win.

In fairness it's not my favourite type of game but my heart sinks everytime another one of these comes out - enough is enough!

RATING: 6
MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is mostly an unremarkable worker placement, collect resources to trade for victory points game. What makes it a bit different is that the workers placed do not automatically give you the corresponding resource, but influence the odds of collecting that resource. Resources are gathered by rolling dice, and the more workers you place in an area the more dice you get. So here you have a dice game that gives you a fair bit of leeway to strategically influence the probabilities. It's an excellent use of dice in a genre that generally eschews such random elements. Unfortunately, once you have the resources, you are pretty much just trading them in for points one way or another. The in-game scoring is a bit jerky, coming in 10-25 point bursts. The end game scoring can potentially have massive multipliers that are difficult for players to track in game, so what seemed like a close game in the playing can end up looking very lopsided once the final scores are tallied. The game scales okay, but I think would be best with a full compliment of 4. This is probably a good one to introduce worker placement to non-gamers and the dice probably give it a broader appeal than superior games like Caylus and Agricola. 

Great use of dice. Pretty fun. Bland mechanics. Problematic scoring. Also, the game runs a bit long for as light as it is.

RATING: 6
Another relatively new game that is way overrated, IMHO.  There seemed to be a run of die-related games in recent years, of which Kingsburg is probably the best.  The jury is kind of still out on whether a deliberate starvation strategy is a consistent winner; I kind of think it may not be if other players are alert and know how to counter it.  There's quite a bit of luck in the order in which the cards come up, and I have rarely seen a game end with the cards running out as most players seem focused on scoring the huts.

RATING: 8.5
A great family game.  The only thing that prevents it from being a great gateway game is the playing time.  For new players, a four-player game is easily 90+ minutes after the rules instructions.

A classic worker placement game with several viable paths to victory. Some complain of the "starve your people" tactic.  That can easily be house ruled.  I suggest that in addition to losing 10 points, you also lose one worker - after all, you did starve your people.

A great game that we recently brought out of mothballs.  Committed to getting this to the table more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not impressed after one play. The implementation of the theme is abysmal in this game. There are cards to collect for no reason, and there are a ridiculous set of materials that are gathered and then made into generic huts (e.g. a hut made of Gold and Brick... riiiiiight). Gameplay wise, the huts themselves do nothing. They are worth points according to the resources gathered. In turn, the resources have straight-conversions to points in direct proportion to the effort made to get them, which is a technical way of saying the resources are completely indistinguishable. They offer no difference in pay-off and thematically are not required for different or even appropriate projects. The dice... *yawn*. They've been tamed enough that you wonder why they're even there. 

I would describe the experience of "Stone Age" as disheartening. Slick production values with no coherence. All style and no substance. 

Update: I tried this again two years later (August 2010), and though most of what I said above still stands, I can at least see grant Stone Age the Best in Show if things like Pillars and Vasco de Gama are the competition. The raw pip-to-point conversion and paper-thin risk management are at least reasonable given the time and pacing, but the real insight from my second play is that the spike of randomness isn't in the rolls, it's in the cards. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game. There are several broad strategies and lots of room for creative repositioning. Many decisions rely on what your opponents have done and you are constantly trying to make the best out of the current situation. 

The worker placement can be interesting since you must weigh the value of placements against what others may value. The game also does a fantastic job of integrating the randomness of dice, and there is a very useful (though naive) equivalence between a pip and a point. This lends the game to a very clean zeroth order analysis which can be very useful when evaluating different strategies and opportunities in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I would have given this game at least a 7 if it were the first worker placement game for me. But I already know a few others like Pillars, Agricola or Maestro Leonardo. There's something to the worker placement mechanic which makes these games feel repetitive quickly - even on the first play. Stone Age certainly offers room for clever play as the experienced player in our round demonstrated. There are enough dice rolls for luck to even out and luck can be mitigated by investing in tools. The dice do add to the game for me. But in the start the worker placement is formulaic and in the end it is too long for the limited variety it offers. I don't feel the urge to progress on the learning curve. Probably, that's the key point what bothers me about this one compared to other worker placement games. I feel that you can "learn" this game while for example in Agricola you will always find new situations and in Maestro Leonardo you have to focus more on what others are doing and adjust your strategy accordingly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice simple introductory worker placement game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
15 April 13 Love this game! Because it wasn't in the top 10 we held off buying it. Some comments put us off too - just another worker placement game. After playing this several times - 2, 3 and 4 player - I can assure you this is not 'just another worker placement game'.
Yes you place workers but it is just so interesting that it captures your attention for the whole game. 

Our group likes the fact that you can get blocked but not easily. Essentials - food - you cannot get blocked from and you can resolve your actions in any sequence you choose. This means you can be clever and get cards, buildings and materials by resolving in imaginative ways.

We all love placing and then resolving. Because you roll dice for resources and often for cards too you never know how much you will get. You can mitigate against bad dice rolls by developing your tribes 'tools'. Each tool adds +1 to a roll; you can develop up to a whopping 12 tools!

The end of game scoring is a blast too. You collect multipliers via the cards along the way which remain hidden to everybody else. You're never too sure how much you'll add to your end score.

I can't believe this isn't in the top 10 it is so good.

PS Get the expansion too. It's brilliant!

14 Feb 14 - Okay, so it's getting a little 'rinse and repeat'. Basically I know I'm going to collect and do a little bit of everything. If you don't, you will lose. Not jumping for joy when someone wants to play it anymore. The Jewellery expansion does give this some legs but not much. Down to an 8 I think.

26 July 14 - Boring. I'm just going to collect a variety of huts and cards. That's it. That's the game. Whoever collects the best (depends on luck too) will win. Will only play now if everyone else wants to. Otherwise, no thanks. Down to a 5, I think. Kemet anyone?

RATING: 7
should burn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
NIS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A lot like other worker-placement games, but with one main difference: a little bit of luck factor thrown in with some dice rolling. The luck issue is not a huge factor, however, as you can use tools to offset the role of a die. This game can be a little difficult to figure out who is winning until the very end, which can be viewed as a positive or negative depending on your preferences. I like playing this game due to the fact that it is easy to teach, quick to play, and relatively fast to setup and put away (for a worker placement game). However, I prefer Agricola and Pillars to this one if given a choice on what to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Although it can be really luck dependent, I think its a very challenging game with a huge amount of replayability and if its put on the table, I'm happy to play it.

RATING: 4
I'm sure it's partly because I lost fairly badly, but I didn't really cotton to this game. My chief complaint was the extensive downtime during the resolution. It really made what was kind of a cute game into a drag for me. It may have been a failure of vision or flexibility on my part, but whatever I tried to do didn't seem to work because of my place in the turn order. While I have nothing against dice or some random elements, the combination of dice, cards (both the huts and the resource/VP/multiplier cards), and turn order left me at the game's mercy. Like I said, probably some sour grapes here, and everyone else seemed really to like it, but I suspect it'll be a flash in the pan even for them. Personally, I wouldn't play again easily.

All right, I played it one more time. It's better faster, but still not very entertaining.

RATING: 7.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
When you first encounter the game, the dice seem like a deal-breaker.  It also seems way too similar to games like Pillars of the Earth, with a theme just as lame.  But the game holds together remarkably well.  The dice seem to, for the most part, even out, not making too big of a difference.  The game also feels different than Pillars of the Earth, a little more cohesive with more variability.  I especially like how each player does their entire turn at once, seemingly reducing downtime.  I have two gripes with the game.  First, it seems like the player going last in a four-player game is at a serious disadvantage.  Second, the game length is a little too much - at 60 minutes I would be playing this all the time, but it seems to last around 1.5 hours.  Hopefully the game length will come down with a few more games under our belt.  Also, who designed the box insert?  I had to laugh looking at the box upon receipt.  Even after punching the cardboard the box won't close. 

Anyway, enough whining - Stone Age is good plain fun, a satisfying experience that should be approachable for new gamers yet still challenging for seasoned gamers.  I hope there is no optimum path that is discovered.  The starvation strategy seems strong, but not necessarily overpowering, at least not yet.

Update: After more play, I find myself liking it less each time.  It takes too long, feels derivative and I never have the desire to play it.  Traded away.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Probably one of the favorite worker placement games I've played in a while.  Lots of rolling, but I don't mind it too much.  Yes, bad rolls can hurt you, but I just didn't seem to mind it as much.  I found that preferable to trying to get bread baked in Agricola and having that slot keep getting filled.  It felt like even if one strategy got blocked there was usually a good second choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have a love-hate relationship with this game. I don't like dice rolling...and in this game, consistently shitty dice-rolling means you lose.
However, it is also a worker-placement, resource collection game, which I do like. But what really works well is the coupling of huts and cards. The random nature of the cards is such that one strategy will not always work (compared to, say, Puerto Rico or Dominion, where a superior strategy will always dominate).  This game was hard to find when we were looking for it...so, if you do find it, snap it up and you won't be disappointed. (Also, the episode on Wil Weaton's TableTop, on the Geek and Sundry Channel where they play Stone Age is quite amusing.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A very weak Euro based loosely on Pillars of the Earth. While there is a semi-decent game in there, my rating is based on the fact that there are many, many games which capture the essence of this game, but do it SO much better.

Gripes: firstly, the dice for resources was a horrible idea, and we noticed that one lucky dice-roll was all that stood between the top 3 players. For an economic management game, thats just stupid. Secondly, in the early rounds, all the players were forced to either take a tool or increase their food. There is no other way to play it. The smart play is just to get these things as early as possible. And finally, the game just takes too long. For such a random luckfest, it overstays its welcome by at least a half hour.

Better alternatives to playing this game: Yspahan, Pillars of the Earth, Caylus or St Petersburg.

RATING: 8
A great family game with beautiful art. 
Honestly, this game is probably in the top three or four games I own as far as presentation. The board is a work of art.

The game itself is simple enough to be played by a 10 year old (requires basic math skills, especially division). At the same time an experienced gamer will find enough choices and strategies to keep it interesting.

Easy to learn and lots o' fun. What more could you ask?

RATING: 8
A simple worker placement game with a lot of different strategies and possibilities. A very interesting points counting mechanics, which uses multiplication and thus favours players who collect the same type of cards. Dice are used often, however they are not the main part of the game. Their effect is quite important, but it is possible to plan the situation a little. The game becomes less dependent on the dice in the end.

Paprastas darbininkų statymo žaidimas su gausybe įvairiausių strategijų ir galimybių. Įdomi taškų skaičiavimo mechanika panaudojant daugyba, tokiu būdu suteikiančią privalumą renkantiems tos pačios rūšies korteles. Kauliukai nors naudojami dažnai, nėra pati svarbiausia žaidimo dalis. Nors jie lemia nemažai, bet tokius dalykus bent šiek tiek įmanoma planuoti. Į žaidimo pabaigą priklausomybė nuo kauliukų mažėja.

RATING: 3
After multiple second chances, I continue to hate this game. The end-game point swings are ridiculous. It's absolutely impossible to formulate any kind of strategy during the game. You could have perfect card synergy and still loose by 2 points - and when in-game scores are in the 30's and end-game scores are routinely over 200, there's simply no skill involved, and it's frustrating. It ends up being a worker placement game that somehow manages to have all the skill and luck of Yahtzee. Yeah, I went there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is a clear 10 for me in its online BSW format (and I don't make this statement lightly - check my ratings). In person I would give it a 9 or 8 because it is a bit too slow for frequent in person play. At half an hour the game is the best yet created (for my taste) - at 90 minutes it is also good but there are many games I would choose first. Since it is available online and I have learned so much from the game I am finally going to give it a 10 (it was only a 6 after my first four plays).

What I love about the game is that every decision is interesting and fast. The probability elements are perfectly implemented. It is clearly a game of skill - a few people have played hundreds of 3 player games with win rates of 80%, and yet average players can share a table with very good ones and have a chance at winning. Contrary to many comments I have read I am certain that it is a very deep game - I am still experimenting and learning new things. The game is fantastic for 2 or 3 players - 4 player has fewer interesting decisions and a lot more downtime but is still playable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great worker placement game and more fun and easier to teach people than Agricola. Dice rolls and card selection allow for the game to not be decided by the first few opening rounds which places it above Agricola for general appeal.

There is a theme breaking rule in the game I dislike: if you can't feed your family you only get -10 points. Personally this breaks the feel of the game as you can now out reproduce everyone else without enough penalty. But I have won a few times using it so I guess it gives more options to the game.

I don't know what reason exactly? RATING: 7

A clean elegant design. There is certainly luck, but it's all based on easy to assess probabilities there is nice tension in how you mitigate this. It also works well with 2, 3, and 4.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was another game I thought would be a great gateway game and would involve a lot of dice rolling.  It certainly did the latter part easily, however it didn't bring that "take that" factor as well as Kingsburg does it.  During my hunt for reviews, I basically broke down and bought both Kingsburg and Stone Age at the same time.

When I first got the game, I was already spoiled by playing this online.  The games were quick, it was easy, and allowed a lot of "planning" ahead of time.  When I got the board game it felt laborious and not so much fun.

The failing point for the most part for me is the fact that you KNOW what the best moves are, but cannot capitalize on it purely because of the turn order.  Also, when playing with mixed skill groups, the turn order being static hurts game play a lot because a bad move by a novice can aid a vet player pushing them far ahead.  While sitting next to a vet would mean you always get second best 3 / 4 turns (unless you go first).

The hidden point system was an up point in reviews I've read, and it certainly is.  Ironically this game provided the tightest games in most of the board games I've owned.  In my first few plays with my group, our games were separated by no more than 4 points between the top two players.  This ended up being the same way through our first four games with exception of the first being a learning game.

Still, the game scores probably wouldn't be so close if the players that were new didn't make the less optimal moves to aid players making the most optimal moves.  So I have to decrease my score to a 7 just cause.

7 for me is still a SOLID GOOD game, but I have more fun / enjoyment with other games so far...  I would still play the game if called for easily.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I've played this game 5 times, 4 players every time.  It's really fun.  It's an excellent gateway game for worker placements - that can eventually lead casual players to play more difficult worker placement games like Agricola.  Casual players can easily pick it up, rules can be explained within 10 minutes, and gamers will still enjoy the strategic depth.

There's some die luck involved, but generally will not affect the result (even though it might seem like it always does when you get a bad roll.)

RATING: 7
The Good: Gorgeous board, very nice components. Many different paths to victory. Dice do introduce some luck, but it is not too much. The dice keep it from becoming a much heavier euro-game.

The Bad: This game runs way too long for what it is. The dice do introduce some luck into the game, which some may not like. 

The Ugly: The lid does not fit on the box correctly. Although I was able to figure out the rules in the end, there are sentences that just do not make any sense in the English language. It is obvious that no one bothered to even casually read the rules before they were published - what was Rio Grande thinking ? Also there is a two page add-on to the rules that for some weird reason is separate from the rule booklet.

RATING: 7
We've played this twice now with the family - parents plus two boys (12 and 9) and enjoyed it quite a bit.  The game moves briskly, so everyone stays involved throughout the game.  There are a number of choices to be made each turn, some of them difficult, but it is not overwhelming to the younger players.

I find that in addition to the mechanics listed on the game page, this game has a touch of the role selection mechanic like in Puerto Rico, as only one player can be the toolmaker, farmer, or baby-factory in a given turn.

RATING: 8
Standard Euro-game worker placement type of game.  Very enjoyable to play two player or up to 4.  Easy to learn as well, so good as an introduction game for the new or non-gamer in your family.  The game is also top quality production-- nice solid components, great artwork and even a real leather dice cup. 

My only negative is that there is a possible path to victory that involves never feeding your people and just take the -10 points per turn penalty.  I suggest a home rule of increasing that penalty by another -5 points each time an individual player has to pay it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stone Age is a beautiful worker placement game with draft, set collection and risk mitigation elements. Let’s break down that sentence.
Beautiful: The printing Z-man did is the best I have seen in any game. The colors are rich on an unmatched scale. The art is also amazing, detailed, realistic and a bit cute.
Worker Placement: The turns are set up so that each player has very little time to wait between their turns because turns are separated into phases where each player gets an action. Each action gives the next player something else to react to without overwhelming them with too many options. This means player’s minds stay engaged without triggering analysis paralysis (AP).
Draft & Set Collection: Players have multiple ways to increase their score depending on how much they are willing to pay … or how little they believe their opponents will pay.
Risk Mitigation: There is not much engine building here. Instead, players have ways to minimize the variances of the dice. This is done via tools that can be used to increase the result of a dice by a number equal to the quality of the tool. Also, a farming track provides food for you tribe so more workers can be sent to collect resources, further mitigating the risk of die rolls

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game.  Lots of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I get why people like it but as someone who has now played a ton of worker placement games, I just feel like there are so many better ones out there.  Ninjato often gets compared to this game (maybe wrongfully so) and that is one I like better as its not as dry as this one.  I personally find Stone Age much more routine and mechanical especially since many players go for the same opening move each turn. If you haven't played a resource collection game before then that part is neat (though I'd recommend Kingsburg for that instead) but I also find the gameplay repetitive in going for the VP tiles and ultimately I just felt the game didn't hold interest after repeated plays.  I've played this one ALOT as it's many groups favorite or at least a game everyone knows when no one wants to teach or learn something new.  I'd literally almost rather play anything else at this point but if I do play I don't dislike the game or anything like that.  Basically its the perfect definition of a '5' in BGG terms.

REPLACED BY / RECOMMENDED INSTEAD:  Ninjato, Kingsburg, Carson City, Alien Frontiers, Lords of Waterdeep

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like Stone Age a lot. I think that it is a fun game in its own right, and also a great way of introducing people to the worker placement mechanic before moving to a more complex game like Dungeon Lords or Agricola. The luck is not unbalanced and fits the theme. The artwork is beautiful and also fits the theme and the bits are fun to play with when it’s not your turn. There is a decent about of strategy as far as planning each turn and planning your scoring for the whole game. Trying to beat out an opponent for a particular card or hut can cost you elsewhere so you need to prioritize your actions each turn, and come up with alternate courses for if your opponent beats you to your goal.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stone Age is probably the best in worker-placement games.  Solid on theme and top-notch components and artwork, a very light civilization-building theme that doesn't get in the way of the game play, fairly easy to learn but with slightly complex scoring rules.  

So why is it up for trade? Well, the problem with every worker-placement game is that it has to have a theme that grabs you - otherwise, it's an exercise in management and scoring maximization, and if your other players see it that way they won't enjoy it.  So it's between this and Lords of Waterdeep for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
:star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (70 plays January 2014)

It is little too lightweight compare to others meaning the depth of game play is bit swallower than the others. I don't see I will ever play this again over other worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun and extremely well-designed game. The board and components are gorgeous. It's strategic enough to keep serious players engaged, but simple enough to be accessible to children. My only complaints are that it doesn't punish you for breaking its theme (the starvation strategy should not even be an option), and I'm not a big fan of the endgame scoring. It's too easy to think that you're doing fine and then get blown away at the end. Still, Stone Age is a solid gateway Eurogame.

RATING: 7.5
Excellent worker placement game where you want to do more actions than you can every turn.
The different paths for victory points seem very balanced.
This game can lead to some analysis paralysis which is typical for worker placement.
I personally think the dice rolling in this game is a good mechanic, but if you do not like a game where a bad dice roll or card draw can potentially sink your turn, then this game is not for you and you should try Caylus or Agricola instead.

RATING: 8
Good game, unless you don't allow starvation.  Without the possibility of starvation, breeding is not a reasonable action to take.

Generally a decide then roll game with dice, but there are so many many many rolls, and the rolls are simply cumulative pips (as compared to binary success/failure) that it balances out fairly well in the end.

RATING: 6

Is also a good math exercise for younger players. I think the focused approach is better than the shot gun approach to maximize resources as well as a good balance using both huts and cards to obtain vps. Expansion of your clan will depend on the scarcity of food, but statistically, each extra person should increase your productivity for lower cost resources.

RATING: 8.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's difficult to give a small explanation of this amazing game, but I'm still gonna give it a go. You both start out with five workers, or 'your camp'. Each turn you divide the workers across the board. Each worker resembles one action or dice throw, depending on were you put them. Examples: Throwing for raw materials, building huts, buying cards etc. The cards and huts give you points and can be bought for raw materials you collect. At the end of each turn you also have to feed your workers, so make sure you also make sure to occasionally put some workers on the savannah (to hunt) for food. The cards you buy and choose (yes, they are face up for you to choose) can be used for different strategies to collect the most points and win, so there is not ONE way to win. Altogether a very fun game and very quick to understand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.9
I liked the dice mechanic. It adds some manageable luck to the worker placement genre. That mechanic is something a lot of people have problems with regarding this game.

The problems I had with the game were it's progression and tempo. The game shines as a 3 player game but it just takes too long. Even as a 2 player game it feels like it drags on too long. Furthermore I don't really get the feeling of progression as I want out of my games. It just feels like I'm grinding out victory points for an hour and a half. 

It's one of the few games I think is more enjoyable to play online than on the tabletop. 

Artwork is well done. Michael Menzel makes beautiful illustrations and the components are out of wood and decent. However I felt the theme didn't connect with me at all and didn't elevate the gameplay in any way. 

Finally I think the scoring mechanic is overly complex for what the game is. It's a fairly easy game to teach people but it's going to take them 2 playtroughs to understand the scoring.... which honestly is the whole strategic aspect of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Stone Age, the players live in this time, just as our ancestors did. They collect wood, break stone and wash their gold from the river. They trade freely, expand their village and so achieve new levels of civilization. With a balance of luck and planning, the players compete for food in this pre-historic time.

Players use up to ten tribe members each in three phases. In the first phase, players place their men in regions of the board that they think will benefit them, including the hunt, the trading center, or the quarry. In the second phase, the starting player activates each of his staffed areas in whatever sequence he chooses, followed in turn by the other players. In the third phase, players must have enough food available to feed their populations, or they face losing resources or points.
