RATING: N/A
Civ cards: extra sets are also squared (according to HiG).

"Hunger Strategy" (NOT "Starvation Strategy"): viable strategy approved by game's designer. (Not having enough food means people must beg for it, losing prestige in the form of 10 VP; or, the -10 VP come from a lack of comfort/contentment/security as a tribe miserably scrapes by with the bare minimum of food necessary for survival; or any other plausible explanation.) At no point does the rulebook mention "starving"; players who take issue with this strategy are making a thematic assumption unsupported by the game's designer (and publishers).

Each resource (not food!) on a player's board at final scoring is worth 1 VP.

Scores can go into the negative.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really like and enjoy playing Stone Age. It's not too complicated, I would say light and ideal as a gateway game. The design of the board, the components and especially the dice cup sell the theme. Although my son isn't nearly old enough to play this game, I can imagine that it would be an ideal family game that could even help children practice their devisions and multiplication tables. 

Essentially its a worker placement game where you send your tribe of hunter gatherers to find or produce resources. However, you have to throw a die for each worker you send to a location to determine how much of the resource they've produced. There is some element of luck, but by producing tools you can mitigate the effects of a poor die role. 

As I said, I really enjoy playing it, but only as a 2 player game. Once I played this with four people and it took forever. It almost put me off the game in its entirety. There is way too much down time when the action phase is resolved. So a great game for 2 (or maybe 3 players), but it outstays its welcome with four.

05/2015 Rated it an 8/10.
08/2015 After a very long four player game I adjusted the rating to 7,5/10.

RATING: 6
A játék szép, ráadásul hiába komplex, kifejezetten könnyen tanulható: az első játék felénél már mindenki tökéletesen ismer minden játékszabályt, és az olyan szépségekkel foglalkozhat, mint az előre tervezés, stratégiázás.

Részemről örülnék, ha egy kicsit hosszabb lenne. Hárman játszottunk, és amiatt lett vége, hogy elfogyott az egyik kupac épület. Több játékos esetén még hamarabb elfogyhatna, azaz még kevesebb kör alatt, két játékosnál viszont talán kicsit hosszabb lenne a játék. Az épületekből 7 kör garantált, de akár több is lehet, ha nem szerez meg valaki minden körben ugyanazon épületkupacból egyet.

Szerencsejáték, igen, de valószínűleg mindenki hasonló arányban dob jókat és rosszakat, szóval annyira nem vészes. Inkább csak könnyedebb, lazább lesz tőle a játék: lehet kicsit bosszankodni, ha rosszakat dobunk, illetve örömködni, ha több hatos is sikeredik. Nem szabad véresen komolyan venni, és akkor nincs gond, ráadásul a témához is illik a szerencsefüggőség, hiszen valóban szerencsefüggő például a vadászsiker, vagy hogy mennyi aranyat sikerül a folyóból kinyerni.

A játék kellemes, a többiekre nem kell túl sokat várni, az interakció mértéke átlagos: jobb szeretem ha direktben lehet a másikkal gonoszkodni a saját érdekemben, de azért elég nagy a többiekre hatás is. Ez ugye főleg azon múlik, hogy az elején a többiek elől elfoglaljam a legjobb helyeket (eszközkészítés, földművelés), később pedig az épületeket és a civilizáció-lapokat. (A kezdőjátékos körönkénti változása ezt elég jól kiegyensúlyozza, bár minél több a játékos, annál kevésbé, de ez nem vészes negatívum.) Szóval ez indirekt egymásra hatás, ami ugyan nem az igazi, de legalább nem teljesen passziánsz.

A játék könnyű és jó, kiegyensúlyozott is a kockák ellenére, és lazán hozzáállva igen kellemessé tud válni. A győzelemhez több út is vezet, bár a sok épület és az épületenként három pontot adó civilizáció-lap túl erős kombónak tűnik.

Akarok még vele játszani, de így az első játék után nem érzem azt, hogy ezt mindenképp szeretném megvásárolni. örülnék neki, ha megvenném, játszanék is vele, de nem kihagyhatatlan darab.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stone Age is a solid worker placement game that has just enough strategy so that gamers can enjoy but also enough luck (dice rolling and cards available) that it does not punish new players that much. The game is fairly easy to explain as you can divide the actions into four primary groups (resource collection, village spaces, hut building, or card purchase). One thing to note is most new players do not fully appreciate how valuable the card bonuses are. I would say that is the hardest part to teach as it is confusing to explain. This is one of my sister's favorites which surprised me because she is not a big fan of other worker placement games (aka Agricola).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Finally I found a game similar to Catan but heaps more fun than it. In Catan, you roll dice for resources and then use said resources to buy points. In Stone Age, you use workers to gather resources and then use dice based on amount of workers placed to see how much resources you get! There will be blockage happening but there is always something else to do and the starting player rotates each round as well. All in all, I believe that this is a more fun game than Catan to teach new players.

RATING: 8
Bought this on Faye's recommendation and so far it's one of the best in our collection. I love the resource management and it has a very good balance of luck and strategy. It's the first game we break out with friends who aren't used to longer, strategy-based games. They always balk during the long rules explanation phase but afterward they invariably confess to having a great time with it. I like that it's never quite clear who the winner will be until all the final victory points are totaled.

RATING: N/A
Players: 2-4
Best: 4
Time: 60-90 Min
Type: Family,  Strategy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
To be frank, I expected to dislike this one. It combines a pair of trendy ideas in Euros – worker placement-based resource management and nouveau dice-rolling – that have not succeeded in converting me yet (although Macao shows promise on the latter front). Amazingly, Stone Age works for me, although it doesn't rock my socks off.

The reasons why this game has succeeded where so many popular predecessors – on the one hand, Caylus, Pillars of the Earth and Leonardo daVinci, on the other, To Court the King and Kingsburg – have failed are numerous and interrelated:

   1. It is a well-developed, polished design. So many of Stone Age's near-contemporaries – including the major worker placement games – have rough edges and quirky rules that feel unnecessary. Bernd Brunnhofer, the designer of Stone Age and lead developer at Hans im Glück, has a lot of experience at ruthlessly cleaning these sorts of games up, and his experience shows here. Even though there are several subsystems at play, Stone Age plays effortlessly and, except for a few of the symbols used to keep the game language-independent, the learning curve for Stone Age's rules is about three rounds (and a game lasts several times that). By comparison, Caylus is a rattling clunker.
   2. As a true middleweight, it doesn't feel as bad getting hosed by luck once or twice a game. Compare, if you will, with Ra, where you are sure to see a "perfect" lot ruined by an awful tile draw before you can do anything about it a couple times a game, not to mention the end-of-epoch drawfests. Here, a card you want will sometimes come up at an awkward moment, and you will get hosed by the dice a few times. Each action is such a small part of the game, though, so you can normally take it in stride, and make up for it later.
   3. The Civilization cards add an element of strategy that so many worker placement games – even Leonardo daVinci – sorely lack. While it is not on par with Princes of Florence or Race for the Galaxy in this regard, they differentiate positions enough to add replayability. They also serve to make the player interaction less about getting to the good stuff first than it is in most worker placement games.
   4. The dice make resource collection more interesting than slapping a guy down on the appropriate space, which I find dull. Instead, Stone Age offers a cross between risk-management and resource management. Can I get away with one less guy on the river so I can claim another building? Will four men get me enough pips to feed all of my workers? The decisions are meaningful and can be quite tough. The price of two or three really bad rolls out of 30 or 40 in a game is worth it for me.
   5. You get to choose the order in which you execute your actions, instead of following a game-designated script. This should be a minor point, but it feels like it makes a world of difference. It gives you flexibility when planning out your turn, and it lets you adapt to the unexpected. Ultimately, one of Caylus's "great innovations" (the road) was a stultifying straightjacket, and it took Brunnhofer to show it.


Stone Age is not the best game ever to come down the pike. The dice do what dice do, Central Limit Theorem be damned, and, except for the times when a card comes up that duplicates them, the actions in the village area of the board are too clearly better than the other actions at the start of the game for my taste. It's good enough to happily play it any time I am asked, even if it is not a typical HiG big box game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Perhaps suffers from the fact that I like to play heavier games now. However, I think I like Lords of Waterdeep more because while Stone Age does have buildings and cards come up in different order, Lords has not only different buildings but also the actual Lords themselves which makes you go after different quests. Also Stone Age makes it too obvious that you are going for set collection, which really abstracts the theme. The dice rolls for the resources with mitigation with the tools I could take or leave. I do like that you can get more workers though at the expense of greater upkeep. Overall a good introductory worker placement, but definitely nothing mind blowing.

RATING: 5
Don’t get me wrong. I like Stone Age. But I don’t get why people like it more than many other worker placement games. It’s not really a good gateway game for me because I think that an experienced player will demolish a new person every time, which is what happened to me the first several times I played it. I win almost every time I play now because I’ve mostly figured out the balance between boats and buildings. I absolutely demolish the app API at its hardest setting every time I play.

UPDATE: I think I've reached the point that the game is semi-solved, and I don't like being able to mathematically model a game in my head while I'm playing it.

RATING: 7
An OK game in the line of Pillars of The Earth and other worker placement mecanism (Caylus Magna Carta). It plays quickly and managing the risk in dice rolling is fun BUT I can't stop to think the game is a bit flawed. It seems that for the first 5-7 turns, the turn order is always: 1- Hut (to make babies) 2- Farm. There is almost never a better choice. I find it strange that a game like that seems almost scripted. In the end the game is a bit bland for me even though the components are REALLY good. In fact I used the clay, the wood and the rock in my agricola set!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I had been thinking about buying a lighter worker placement game, for those times when all of Agricola or Caylus are not what is wanted. Having dithered over Egizia and this for a while, I ended up plumping for the cavemen over the Egyptians. It helped it was just sitting there in my FLGS waiting for me.

It serves its purpose admirably. The basic scheme is collect resources and turn them into points, with the added wrinkle of feeding everyone and decisions over expanding your capacity to gather via tools or simply more villagers. I was slightly worried that the dice rolling would sour things, but quite the reverse - they give it that little buzz of excitement that dice rolling always gives but the game is straightforward enough and laid out well enough that you usually are going to get something even with a relatively poor roll (unless you are gambling on a single worker to get you gold). Indeed, I found it quite relaxing to play but with enough to think about that I wasn't bored. That is also from only one play - we'll see if I still say that in a year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
fun quick game where you really should keep track of what the other players are doing or you will loose.

RATING: 9
Great game. No one strategy to winning. Rating after 4 plays. This game keeps getting better.

RATING: 6
If there's a "classic Euro" I feel like I'm done with, this is it.  Liked it a lot at first, but the appeal slowly drained away.  The games just felt the same.  The discovery of the starvation strategy is what sealed the deal for me, however.  Whenever someone employs it, it all but ruins the game for me.  The great production values and its fundamental accessibility may be its saving graces, but if I never played it again, it'd be no tragedy.

RATING: 8
Stone age is a simple and forgiving feed-your-workers euro. It's a great game. Easy to learn -- given a couple of useful hints, new players (including non-gamers) can have fun with this game in the first play. For a lot of games, the first play is more of a "getting familiar with the mechanics and rules"-experience, but not this one.

After more than 30 plays, the simplicity starts making this game less interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stone Age is a great worker placement game and one of my favorites.  You send your tribe to improve agriculture, get tools, collect resources, add tribe members or get bonus cards which give you immediate benefits or end of game points.  You can also build huts which score points.  

Very simple to teach and definitely family weight.  I really enjoy this game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great worker placement game, definitely a classic euro.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The title has it right--this game takes Euros back to the stone age.  Reimplementation of worker placement mechanics with the introduction of dice.  Bland, pasted on theme that starts peeling off as you play (starvation strategy?!?).  Another Eurogame with solid mechanics, but stays too long on the table, and otherwise fails to stand out from the crowd.  It is interesting that dice seem to be the latest trend in Euros--I think Airships and Kingsburg incorporated them much better.  If there weren't so many other great choices, I'd likely rank this higher.  Given that there are, I probably should rank it lower.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Could you possible develop a game that has less strategy and more randomness?  I doubt it.  

Game might be more fun if every one decides that the winner is determined by a single die roll at the beginning of the game and move on to a better game. "Was that the roll to see who goes first?  No, that was to decide who wins...congrats... well played!"

More fun than a trip to the dentist office, but only barely (Dentist office wins if they use gas).

RATING: 8
Приятная во всех отношениях: отлично прорисованное поле, деревянные компоненты, тайлы и карточки дотстаточной плотности, кожаный стаканчик для кубиков, который можно использовать и для игры в Пиратский покер. В игре несколько стратегических линий, ведущих к победе, поэтому у каждого игрока есть возможность набрать как можно больше победных баллов. Очаровывает новичков.

RATING: N/A
See my comments about Notre Dame for how this game fits into a learning path towards Puerto Rico and Caylus.

The game play and gorgeous board really pulls you into the theme.

NB: This game seems to be favored by a lot of folks over Agricola because it is shorter, lighter, less game pieces, less weight (physical and mental), less restrictions, more forgiving and overall scratches the same itch. I can easily see this being favored by younger players.

Great analysis for winning strategies INCLUDING  a link to a math analysis with graphs Etc. https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/434835/winning-stone-age-strategies

RATING: 8
This is a really nice game!

~ Easy enough that I can get my family and other casuals to play it.
~ Fairly fast games (about an hour).
~ Highly varied strategies - there's a large set of viable strategies that you can either plunge exclusively into or mix according to temper
~ It looks great, which matters when you want to get new players to try it.
~ Lots of dice, but in the end they don't determine the winner - it is still the best player that win.

RATING: 7.5
Me: 7
Wife: 8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The more we play this the more we enjoy it! :o)
We were very wary of the dice at first - we do not like dice rolling to be the key to winning as it can easily make someone feel lost from the start after bad rolling.  However, it works very well in this game.  The idea of sending out your people to fetch resources and not knowing exactly how much they will return with makes sense thematically.  Sending out extra people and having tools on hand to adjust means you aren't entirely subject to luck!
Having secret points to add up at the end of the game often means we don't know who's actually winning which is all the better! ;o)
This gets played often and I'm sure it will continue to get played lots as it's pretty easy to teach and everyone seems to want a second game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game remains an elegant and appealing choice. High production values, coherent theme, quick and easy to play with choices to be made at every turn, many of which have an effect upon opposing players (by blocking them from performing the same action). I can't see myself tiring of this game, even if an array of shiny new worker placement games with much deeper strategies have joined the fray since its release...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fails to generate any excitment. I really don't care if I win this game or not.  Nothing wrong with the actual design though.

Update: Still don't get this game.  The only actual flaw is the fact that there are only 2 essential spaces to grab, so first and second player always take them for at least half the game.  If moves are no-brainers like this then there's something wrong with the design.  This also means that players later in the turn order are at a significant disadvantage.  Otherwise, it's an OK game that I just don't like.

RATING: 4
The theme is not very well supported by the game mechanics (why do we buy huts with different resources?, what are the civilization cards?), plus several mechanics are quite gamey (why can only one player reproduce per turn?).

The game itself does not have major flaws and doesn't take too long, so I can get talked into it occasionally.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of my total favorites - great worker placement game that requires a balance of gaining VP's with feeding your family (like a simpler version of Agricola).  Love this game.  One of the things I love about this game like other Days of Wonder games is that you can see [part of] your VP progress on the perimeter of the board as you're playing, but other VP's are hidden.  Don't love that the end game scoring is complex, so it takes a bit of work to compute (like 7 Wonders).

RATING: 7.5
great worker placement
just the right amount of conflict for space
looks great, nice components, easy to learn but still a meaty game.

I have yet to come across another game that scratches this same itch.  worker placement, open feeling options, resource management, gateway game, it just has such a nice balance of all these little things and adds up to a great game.  I really want to find a very similar game just with a bit more depth/replay-ability.

I wish there was more complexity as far as they typical top three choices is getting a worker, going up on the food track, and getting a tool.  I've rarely seen those choices not be worth it until the last 2 rounds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really fun game!  I like the fact that you can start out by just playing to your own advantage, but then can grow into (a bit) deeper strategies, such as preventing your opponents from getting items that will help them with their own chosen paths to victory points.  Still a pretty light game, though.

Awesome production and thought went into the actual physical components too!  Wooden bits, nice art, thick card stock, and a leather dice cup!

Those who love Settlers may really enjoy trying Stone Age too.  Fresh new mechanics and game play, yet maintains elements of luck and dice rolling.

This is, in my opinion, THE game to own if you're looking to fill the "Light Worker-Placement" void in your collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Wow, too much randomness to be fun for me.  Between the dice, the cards, the objectives... bleh.  

I don't enjoy games where multiple players race to be the first to complete an ever changing set of objectives.  I also feel like the graduated cost system of the cards doesn't work.  I feel like it should be a futures market, but from the midgame on, every round saw three of four (usually four) cards being purchased, so it was just random chance when the next cards came out as to which were expensive and which were cheap.  Not my kind of game.

1 play, 4 players

RATING: 9.7
It's simple to teach, which makes it a great gateway game.

The components are beautiful, and the theme is prevalent throughout. My only complaint about the theme is that it feels like, if you can't feed your meeples, you should lose the number you can't feed (and have to get them back via the love shack) rather than losing 10 points. 

It plays well at every player count. I play games primarily two player, but my husband and I also get together once or twice a month with friends to play. Games that can handle two players well, but can also expand well to play four, are a treasure.

It has just the right amount of player interaction for my taste. You can take a space that someone else wants, but you can't destroy something they've been working for the past half of the game to build. We like player interaction that doesn't feel "mean" and Stone Age provides just the right level of player interaction for us. 

Beyond that, I just enjoy the worker placement mechanic. Games where I can gather and build things really appeal to me.

I expect this game will stay in our collection permanently for those reasons.

(Also own Stone Age: The Expansion.)

RATING: 8
Outstanding theme, nice bits and art.  I don't mind the rolling for resources - it evens out over time, and you'll have the opportunity to savor a victory over your opponents AND the dice.  You'll also benefit from some incredibly lucky rolls every now and then.  :-)

The one theme-breaker is the viability of the "starvation" strategy.  I don't mind adjusting my play and trying to modify my tactics to make life harder on the player who tries it, but if someone suggested a houserule where starved people can't work - or perish (*leave the tribe* if you prefer a euphemism) - I wouldn't object.

I have the 2nd edition (with the box that better contains the components).  What is up with the smelly dice cup?  :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are a lot of moving parts, interactions, and icons to learn on the first play, and it comes off as a bit dense, but on play two everything was clear, smooth, and fun. It's a great mix of picking a strategy or two and sticking to it plus needing to be opportunistic -- and knowing when to take a gamble on something.

The way Stone Age uses dice is quite clever. I guessed "Pillars of Kingsburg" after hearing the initial description, but that's not quite right. The game manages chance very well, and you have a lot of control over how your die rolls actually turn out.

Very pretty board, interesting interactions and choices every round. The "power three" (farm, fuck, tool) are usually the optimal choices, in that order -- but not always. Knowing when they're sub-optimal can be hard to determine, and makes for some enjoyable tension.

After two plays, this shot up from a 6 to a 9 for me -- it's a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is a lot of fun to play, not to mention the art work is very well done. It was highly recommended at our local game shop. Some of the mechanics incorporate popular concepts of other Euro games, like Settlers of Catan, Puerto Rico, Carcassonne, etc. So in my opinion the game play is fairly solid. The game is refreshing in that you not only have to keep your guys alive but depending on what resources you go for to purchase huts or cards, the winner is kept secret until the end of the game when all the Victory Points are totaled. Strategy wise, there are a lot of options. I like to build up my food chain and tools as quickly as possible. From there building a healthy supply of wood (cheapest resource) will help you get the cards, which pays off big in the end. Entertaining wise - we'll we've played the game every night since we bought it. We're teaching our kids how to play and will introduce it to our circle of gaming friends. I would recommend this game to anyone - though you'll probably need to pick up a few extra "substitute" game pieces as we tend to run out regularly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2016 Top 100 Favorites of All-Time: #97
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Easily the best light-medium WP I have ever played.

Update: As of 3/17/13, I have probably played this game 15 times. I just don't know what to say. It's obviously dice-driven, but since you can minimize the randomness (tools and worker allocation), Stone Age actually becomes quite mathematical. That is, you are constantly weighing the odds. I absolutely adore this game and I think every gamer should have it in their collection! 

I've recently purchased the iOS version for my iPad. It's good if you are fine with playing against AI, but the online multiplayer is not up to snuff. Carcassonne and Ticket to Ride are truly the gold standard for iOS, but neither can compete with Stone Age as a game.  

Update 7/14/14: Until tonight, I hadn't played Stone Age in over a year. It was great to get this gem back to the table! I absolutely LOVE this game. Admittedly, if I didn't really enjoy worker placement, I don't know if this game would be in my top 25, let alone my top 10. I do believe that anyone can play and enjoy this game. BUT, in order for it to be a favorite, I think you have to enjoy worker placement. After playing tonight, I realized why I like the game so much: it is perhaps the most streamlined example of worker placement out there. This game distills the mechanic so well! It's super smooth and turns are a breeze. Stone Age, at least 2 player, can also be easily played in 45 minutes or less if both parties know what they are doing. All that said, I'm dropping this game down a couple of notches. It's still a "10" for me, because it's perfect for what it does, has great components/art, is a solid gateway game for muggles, and it's really quick. Ironically though, it's the simplicity of this game that pulls it down ever so slightly. Don't get me wrong, you have interesting choices to make almost every turn, but unfortunately, those options are severely limited. Plus, the first few turns are rather scripted. Your best first move for the first 3 turns or so is moving up on the food track. Experienced players are literally just trading off for this position through changing turn order. This is unfortunate, but the good things about this game overshadow its shortcomings so considerably that I'm willing to overlook it. I will never refuse a game of Stone Age, and I will often recommend it. Still, it has (after 24 plays) sadly dropped from my #2 game to the lower portion of my top 5. 

Update 8/23/15:

I had so much fun playing this with my wife yesterday. We hadn't played in quite a while, and I was itching to get a session in. Stone Age was one of the first gateway plus games that I purchased after I plunged into the euro-gaming hobby (back in late 2012). I wasn't certain that it would hold up against some of the newer games (I've probably played at least 300 games in the interim). I'm happy to report that this game is still FANTASTIC. It really is the king of all worker placement games, IMO. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
2 / 5 - Fair.

The great thing about Stone Age is the way it balances everything: there's no one dominant strategy or path to victory and the game rewards flexibility and good tactical thinking. So it's rather a shame that that's pretty much all I found to like about it. The theme is very silly (metals? In a game called Stone Age? sheesh), interaction is low and the mechanics tired and uninteresting. It reminded me a lot of Yspahan - and I'd much rather play Yspahan since it offers very much the same experience in half the time.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Received July 2008

Fast paced romp with multiple paths to victory. You can block the hell out of other players options during worker placement.

Includes dice as a randomizer accomplishing the same need as that found in Thebes.  As you do with knowledge when digging in Thebes, you work to increase your chances of success but putting more cavemen in an area and then roll the number of dice equal to the number of committed workers.  Also, collecting and using "tools" can alleviate some of the pain of a bad rolls as they allow you to adjust the roll of the dice.

Easy to learn (only three simple steps on each turn).  Took a bit for some of the guys in my group to catch onto the iconography but in general it's pretty consistent and straightforward.

Had to cut slots into the insert to lower the individual player boards which allows the box to close properly.

RATING: 8
Strong game.  Easy to learn, but plenty of strategy options to keep it fresh for a LONG time.  Everything in the game, from board to pieces are very well made and have excellent attention to detail.  Probably one of the best looking games I've ever played.  The only thing that will be a drawback for some is the dice rolling for food and resources.  Sometimes you can get really bad rolls, which can be frustrating, but there ARE ways to control it to a certain extent.  For me, leaning more to strategy, it's a bit of a negative, but it's managable by playing smart.  Plays fast and easy with 2 people, making it an excellent filler game till others show up, then becomes a solid one of the main games for the night.

RATING: N/A
Propiedad del club
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I got this game for Christmas and have played it a ton. I read through the good and bad reviews on here and am surprised by both. 

the bad reviews usually base on 3 things: comparison to another game, complaints about dice, and complain about scripted strategy. I can't comment on PotE as I don't have it. As for dice (which some people also put in as pro), they don't really have much effect. What? Really. Since resources require 3,4,5 and 6 being off 1 or 2 isn't the deal breaker each turn. true, you can get supremely unlucky every single turn, but the reality is that doesn't happen as often as people like to think (the victim mentality). 

Also, it is not scripted and people will not go after the same things necessarily. The changing order turn, the changing cards and blocking lead to different strategies. Since some have complained about lack of interaction, I can only imagine they do not understand blocking - both at the woodpile and the civ cards. Also, you have to plan out how to use all the resources you gather over the next 3 turns, or you find the game has ended and you have a bunch of resources left over which is not as good as having bought huts instead. 

The limited availability of the tools, baby and farm are important, and thus strategy and blocking. Can't explain it all here, but I can say because of all of this, SA is a fantastic game. And it does play in 60minutes if you know what you're doing. The dice are not horrid, and the tools help there too. The design and parts are great and you can explain it easily enough to most people. The depth is there, you just need to play more. 

Edit: Since this review I have obtained PotE and can say SA is better for 2 reasons: 1) time; 2) order mechanic for Pillars sucks. 

Also, SA is a nice gateway game – fun, fast, easy to teach. While I don’t think strategy is scripted I do think options are limited and after a ton of plays, it starts to get boring. And now that Lords of Waterdeep is out, that is a nice replacement. As such, my rating drops half a point, but this is s still an overall great game and great value. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8.5

I know some gamers complain about the hidden cards that can create a run away leader, however I think they add to the replayability of the game. Also, proper use of the cards does require a bit of planning to maximize your end score.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]Stone Age[/i] is my favorite of the worker placement/resource management games.  There are a variety of paths to victory that may be necessary to pursue depending on how your opponents play and in what order the civilization cards and buildings appear.

One of the aspects of the game that I most enjoy is that you do not have to use your workers in the order in which they are placed.  This allows you to strategically use workers to pull off valuable combinations.

The other aspect that I really enjoy, especially in the two-player variant, is that not all players may place workers in each region.  This allows for blocking opportunities and forces you to think ahead when placing your own workers.

**********

I have not necessarily soured on [i]Stone Age[/i], but having now played many other games, it is no longer my favorite worker placement game.  In particular, the lack of blocking in a 3-4 player game makes the game somewhat dull.  Also, the number of paths to victory is lower than in other games.  I would much rather play [i]Spyrium[/i] or [i]Viticulture[/i] at this point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is simple to teach, short to play, very accessible for non-gamers. In addition it remains enjoyable after many plays and in groups of varied levels of experience.  The game has some mild player interaction and therefore provides different ways to victory that are balanced enough to make the game highly replayable despite its lightness. it plays well with two, and I have used it more than once to introduce new players to worker placement with good success.

All that said, the game is a very abstract-adjacent, minimalist worker-placement and while it is a great simple case study of the mechanic it does lack the razor edged perfection (thought it should be noted the game is balanced very well) that minimal designs need to hold player interest over time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7
I wasn't sure I really liked this game at first as there's a lot of luck involved with seemingly few ways that a player can mitigate it, but I've come to enjoy playing it every once in a while.  There are a lot of good gameplay aspects here: multiple paths to victory, strategic decision making, mystery about who will win, etc.  Unfortunately, the different strategies seem shallow and transparent, and the luck of the cards and turn order can sometimes play a significant role in determining the victor.  I rarely suggest this game as I'd rather play Kingsburg for a similar experience, but I'm usually willing to play if someone else proposes it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Game in a Nutshell: Worker Placement game set in the stone age where you collect resources and use them to get cards and tiles that give you victory points.

Played as: 4 player (2 player online)

Pros: Rolling dice (relative to the number of workers you placed) for your resources adds a little spice in the form slight unpredictability. That said, dice don't dominate the game and careful planning should prevail. Lots of different ways to go for points so there's not a strict, "you must do this or get blown out of the game" path player must take. It scales well for 2-4 players. Attractive board and artwork.

Cons: It's a well designed game but nothing astonishingly unique. Perhaps the game is too balanced to the point that just about anything will score you points, resulting in a lack of consequential tension. I found the game to be somewhat mathematical: "this move will get me this many points, but that one will block X from that many points, so my best move is ___". That is especially apparent the less people playing.

Other: Essentially Stone Age is a lighter, more forgiving, and more accessible version of Agricola. I enjoyed this better of the two since it's less fiddly and levels the playing field for a group with different levels of experience.

Best Use: If you want one swiss-army knife worker placement game in your collection, this is it.

RATING: 6
I didn’t get Stone Age at first, but it’s grown on me.  It’s a relatively pure worker placement game with dice added.

I don’t mind dice and chance in my games, but they did seem a little out of place here. I’ve come to accept that the dice have a relatively minor effect, and that without them there might not be much of interest here as the game underneath is pretty dry and mathy.

There are several worker placement games I would rather play first, but Stone Age has its charm.

However, I need more initial attraction to do that. I don't have it, so I won't do it.

RATING: 9.5
Great game! Utilize your "meeples" to breed, build farms, collect tools, buy cards, or roll dice that allow you to collect food, resources, etc (yes, I did criticize dice rolling in the previous rating but here, there is more variety and you have more control). This game holds my interest because there are so many variables in strategy you can use such as deciding to collect the most symbols (which earn you exponentially more points for the number of symbols you have), or collect resources to build huts (each hut earns you points), or collect cards that multiply your score based on huts, fields, etc.
Takes about 20 minutes to explain. About medium in terms of difficulty. I don't think I'll burn out on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid worker placement game of helping your stone age family survive. You send workers to grab resources/hunt for food, rolling dice for each worker to determine how much you get, you make tools to help mitigate your dice rolls, you work on agriculture to lower your hunting needs, visit the shack to grow your family and use your resources to buy cards and huts to score points. An enjoyable game that scales pretty well.

RATING: 9
Excellent; multi paths to victory and you need to both think ahead and keep an eye on what your opponents are up to. I have won (153pts) with a no tool 5 original meeples strategy, a heavy tools effort, seen a maxi meeple and mixed strategies all work. You must and can adapt to circumstances and it remains unclear who will triumph if all are up to speed. Fast, simple and superb.

Dropped a half point after a couple of dozen more plays (NB I don't generally log plays), because I don't feel there is real depth or much direct interaction.

RATING: 7.5
The mechanics reminded me a lot of Pillars of the Earth, with some significant improvements: 
First, the huts give the game much more of an engine-building feel.  Pillars felt like you had almost nothing to work with from start to finish.
Second, the civ cards and buildings were much easier to grasp in terms of cost vs. benefits.
And third, the dice lighten the game up and add some fun.  Pillars was just too dry.

RATING: 10
Perfect worker placement game. Can't seem to get tired of this one.

The pacing of the game is the best in any game. The end can come at you pretty fast, but it's all player-driven so it's up to you to control it.
Really simple and fast worker placement, and then the collecting of the rewards.
Amazing scoring mechanisms (buildings vs. cards).
Excellent push-your-luck mechanisms when you want multiple things at the same time, but are unsure if an opponent will get the one you don't pick first.
Allowing only a few activations in the center area is a brilliant system

The expansion adds great new content and is really enjoyable. I would not say it's mandatory though. I vary playing with or without it, and it's always enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[microbadge=1714]  [microbadge=21390]

[u]08-Feb-2013[/u]: This is a solid, family friendly entrance into the world of worker placement games.  Everyone starts out with a tribe of five prehistoric people who got out into the world to collect resources to improve their society with huts and civilization cards.  Yeah, it doesn't totally make sense, but it works very well in the game.  And as most worker placement games do, you can even increase the size of your family to get even more resources on your turn.  Of course, you do have to feed all of those people too.

I like this one quite a bit.  It's relatively light compared to some other worker placement games like Agricola and Caylus.  My family grasped the gameplay after only one play.  On the downside, our first several plays went fairly long.  We seem to be a slow group in general though.  So I actually removed one hut from each stack during set up as well as 10 of the Civ cards to help speed things up.  This helped a lot, but also left out some of the longer term strategy as the game ended a couple turns early.  Otherwise, a fun, light strategy game that I look forward to playing any time.

[u]26-Jan-2014[/u]:  Stone Age is still a fave of both myself and Mrs Mo.  The girls like it as well, but the shiny, new stuff usually distracts them from choosing this one.

It's an excellent lower-midweight Euro.  One that can be taught relatively quickly and easily.  The art and components are excellent.  It plays well at all player counts...even 1P using the SoloPlay rules.

I'd recommend this as solid family-style Euro and a good one for gamers not looking for a thinky game.

Oh, and just to follow up on my older comments, I've finally moved us back up to the full game setup the last couple time we played.  We are still slow as a group, but the games have been very fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An enjoyable game that plays very similarly to Pillars of the Earth.  I like the easy flow of the game, the quick decision making and even the excitement of the dice.  However, competitive players will find that the game does come with a couple of faults: first there's no balance for turn-order.  The obvious first choice is probably to create a new worker but only one person can create a worker per round.  This means that if you're third or fourth you're always going to be a worker behind the other players for a few turns.  Second, some of the VP point cards are unbalanced.  It would be fine if everyone had an equal chance to grab those cards but they don't.  It depends on when they come up and then once again turn order comes into play.  Whoever goes first that round can plop one of their workers on the superior card and lock it out.  Played with 3 players and thought it was about 30+ minutes too long.  I'm sure the 4-player version is much better, barring the flaws described above, as it will add more competition and harder choices.  UPDATE: I've played this quite a few more times and determined that the luck described above is negligible.  There are some chances to play defense and a number of different strategies.  Added 1 point to rating. UPDATE: this really does have solid replay value.  Adding another .5 to rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/611784/gathering-at-its-finest]Stone Age Review: Gathering at its finest[/url]

I think this is by far my favorite worker placement game right now.  I would rather play this over Agricola any day.

In Stone Age each player begins with 5 meeples and some food to get started.  Each turn is played in a series of rounds.  The first round is for placing your meeples on the different actions available on the board.  You can go get resources, go get food, get more farms, more tools, go to the love hut and get another person, buy cards (mostly for points at the end of the game) or build some buildings that give you points for the resources you use to build them with.  After everybody has placed their meeples the starting player in the round resolves all the actions in the order needed.  So if they placed a meeple on a building, but still need a stone in order to build it, they could try and get that stone with the meeple(s) they placed to gather stone first.  After resolving actions you have to pay one food for each meeple you have.

The biggest reason I like this better than Agricola is because it has more ways to actually win.  While you can get blocked on what you need to do, it doesn't happen too often.  Also, while you need food, it isn't so difficult to get that you feel like all you are doing is getting food.

I think Stone Age is a game I'll play for a long time to come.  I really think it should have been the Spiel des Jahres winner for 2008.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 2-4  It is a different game with a different number of players, but I enjoy them all.

RATING: 6
Comments based on only one play.

When I think of VP engine games, Stone Age is near the top.  Nothing against VP engine eurogames, but it seems like the strategy choices are obvious, leaving this as a game primarily concerned with tactics, timing and second guessing your opponents (i.e. what option are they most likely to choose).  

Also, it is going to be quite difficult to win if your dice rolls are consistently trending below everyone else's at the table.

Not bad, but not great because it seems like the game has limited strategic choices.  I'll still play it, as I like rolling a bunch of dice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For me Stone age is a very interesting dice game with a great theme. Much more interactive than St. Petersburg and wonderful graphics
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was pleasantly surprised how simple it was to learn the game, and even better, how enjoyable it is in 2 player mode -- the wife loves it, which is always a good thing.  While Ticket to Ride is the quintessential gateway game, this is exactly the kind of game I'd follow up with the "beginning" board gamer.  Deeper, more decisions, but not necessarily more complex.  And I'm kind of in love with this game.

RATING: 8
A játékosok egy-egy kőkorszaki törzset irányítanak. A törzs tagjait küldik el minden körben vadászni, nyersanyagokat előállítani, vagy a falu különböző lehetőségeit kihasználni; ezután pedig a nyersanyagok felhasználásával kunyhó lapkákat és civilizáció kártyákat szerezhetnek meg, amik a győzelmi pontot jelentik a játékban.
Nagyon szép a kivitelezés, egyszerű szabályok, gyors szabálymagyarázat - és elég hosszú játékidő. Tetszik benne, hogy többféle lehetőség van a pontszerzésre: lehet kunyhókat építgetni, vagy a civilizációs kártyákkal különböző kombókat összehozni. 
Hiába tesz szert valaki a játék közben behozhatatlannak tűnő  előnyre a sok kunyhó felépítésével, a játék végi elszámolásnál a kártyák kiértékelésével minden megváltozik. A játékidő elég hosszú, de ez játék közben nem tűnik fel, az izgalom végig kitart. Vigyázat, a szerencsefaktor elég magas a kockák miatt!

RATING: 7
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Excellent dice/resource management/set collection Euro
* Plenty of luck, but tools mitigate some of the dice fickleness
* Huts and cards offer multiple routes to victory, but consistency lies in balance
* Plays great with any number of players, with minimal downtime even with 4
* "Starvation" may work against newbs, but vets can speed up the game to neutralize
* Good for dice/resource collection fans, those looking for a quick, light Euro
* Initial rating: [b]8/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Burned out my gaming group on this one, but would still break it out on occasion
* Concerned that expansion may just add more layers of complexity instead of new life
* Entrenched in the collection, but feels more and more simplistic against new titles
* Further rating: [b]7/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Cemented in the collection as the gateway worker placement of choice
* "Gateway" distinction means that it doesn't come out too often with the regular group
* Don't see the need to layer complexity on top with the "Style" expansion
* Advanced rating: [b]7/10[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played once.  A nice resource-acquisition game that combines elements of many others (Caylus, Puerto Rico, Leonardo da Vinci), but it's a bit more luck heavy than most (as the number of resources you get by allocating workers is determined by the roll of dice).  Overall this is a neat game that I quite enjoyed playing, but the first game I played of this took more than three hours, which was a bit much considering that two of the four players felt out of the game for more than half that duration.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update: This is turning into something I like to have if playing with more casual gamers. It it's just me and Ali, I think we both enjoy something a little deeper like Le Havre or At the Gates of Loyang. That said, both those games take a lot longer, which can be tough.

RATING: 6

I haven't lost to my wife yet. So far this is one of those games she likes but hasn't won. I find that buying a lot of cards is a good strategy. I'm good at maximizing my resources. And rolling dice in a little leather cup.

Update: I've lost to my wife.

Stone Age seems to be one of those games that I enjoy playing while I'm at the table with it, but I have no drive or desire to bring it out and play it. Too easy once you figure out what to do: focus on the cards and a few specific buildings. Mostly gather wood and buy cards.

RATING: 4
A stupid worker placement. The dice add a nifty push-you-luck element that kept things interesting, but not interesting enough.

There was also never ENOUGH conflict. The game was almost TOO nice, if that makes sense. I hate to use the cliched term "multi-player-solitaire" but I never felt like I was actually competing with the other players, only playing in parallel.

I suspect it's relative lightness makes it more accessible than Agricola. Still, it's not the best of the worker placement genre. And the mechanics are so played out and overdone that it's hard to sit patiently through.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is considered as 'Agricola Light' for a lot of people and rightly so. There are a lot of similarities between both games and the joy to play the game is comparable. Stone Age does however play much faster and although there are less things to choose from in comparison to Agricola, there are more than enough decisions to be made to make it hard enough to win.

In comparison to Agricola, the dice do add some luck to the game but this can easily be minimized by pulling in more workers on a field or using the devices. It is also a perfect gateway game into more difficult worker placement games.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Certainly not a bad game. Neat components, nice attempt to connect theme to abstract worker placement, fun in chugging dice.
But it's balanced so strangely!
Why don't buildings requiring particular goods give more points than buildings accepting anything, just a sum of the goods value?
Why isn't the set collection, certainly the hardest part of cards to get, worth most points? Why do I need to concentrate more on denying particular cards to opponents than what's best for me?
It could still be used as "intro to worker placement". But sadly it no longer deserves to be rated this high.

RATING: 8.5
This game is lovely to look at and mehcanically very solid worker placement game. Recource collection includes lots of dice chucking but player can increase odds by placing many workers or using tools that increase dice values. I recommend this to be played with four players cause with less people game play feels a bit crippled. 

Stone Age has definitely earned its place in the collection. It is a classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stone Age ist ein klassisches Worker-Placement Spiel. Allerdings greifen das unberauchte Steinzeit-Szenario, sowie alle Elemente des Spiel so passend und stimmig ineinander, dass es an Stone Age fast nichts auszusetzen gibt. Das Spielmaterial ist hochwertig und es ist erstaunlich viel in der Schachtel drin. Simuliert wird das Leben eines urzeitlichen Dorfes. Die Spieler müssen Holz hacken, Nahrung jagen oder Steine und Gold beschaffen. Doch jeder Arbeitsplatz bietet nur begrenzten Platz und so ist es wichtig zu planen, wo man seine Arbeiter einsetzen möchte. Von den erbeuteten Ressourcen, bauen die Spieler Gebäude oder Handeln, beides bringt Siegpunkte. Wer Worker-Placement mag, sllte Stone Age unbedingt eine Chance geben.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Stone Age is a "lighter" Pillars of the Earth, with less theme IMHO.  It takes worker placement from Caylus, Cuba, AOEIII and not least of all Pillars of the Earth, but correlates it to dice.  Like Pillars of the Earth and Cuba, the art work is some of the best in boardgaming.  I like this game more and more each time I play it.  Awards: Ludoteca Ideale (2010); Spiel der Herzen (2010).

Game Played: #20,001.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nice gateway to worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Heavy on worker placement and resource management.  For those that like this focus I'd imagine it is a decent light and quick game.  I don't mind these mechanics, but seek out games that have a tightly incorporated theme and a high degree of player interaction.  

There is very little meaningful player interaction in Stone Age.  I found that the Stone Age theme didn't sync with game play or the design.  Why are competing tribes exploiting the same locations for resources?  What are these mysterious boats that are arriving?  In what manner can these people eat bricks and wood?

Sections of the board within the village are entirely necessary in order to have a chance at competing and thus, in a four player game, fill up with workers prior to the 4th player's turn.  In contrast, there is little tension involved with placing workers in resource sections outside of the city because these typically have enough spots to fit all needs.  As a result, there is a predictable flow of worker placement, from village to huts to cards to resources.  Cards and huts are random and decrease the degree of strategy.  After placement, there is a period of time where each player completes there planned actions while others wait.  Because actions are already out there this part too lacks tension and is uninteresting.

**Update 2 years later 9/17/2015.  Dropped from 5 to 2 rating.  No theme, horrible luck-based/random elements for a worker placement euro, largely solitaire play, incredibly boring.  So many better alternatives out there.  Hope never to play this again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Miles ahead of Pillars Of The Earth. There's no comparison. I never understood the random draw in Pillars or the awfully clunky card-drawing mechanism for resource generation. 

This one takes all the luck of Pillars of the Earth and repackages it into something that you can mitigate or control. It's more informed risk-taking than random chance, here.

In Pillars, it's just dumb luck if your master builders or resources don't come out when you want. In Stone Age, if you don't get what you want, it's 'cause you didn't allocate well.

RATING: 8.5
Sold off to my club to get a newer copy with the larger box size.

This dice allocation Euro is pretty neat. It does nothing brilliantly well as it is a fairly standard 'allocate workers...gain resources and spend them on VP earners' kind of game.

But it is beautifully balanced in relation to the avenues to victory and it scales perfectly for 2, 3 or 4 players.

It's not quite up to Kingsburg's level but it is a quality Dice Euro.

RATING: 9
Update 8/2010:
Got a chance to try this game again.  Even though I still think Pillars of the Earth is a better game, it's only by a slight margin.  This is a fun and enjoyable game.
***

This is a good game with a nice theme that is fun, but a bit to repetetive and predictable for me.

I've only played it once, but that was enough to know that it is NOT better than Pillars of the Earth.  Lighter yes, better NO.

I found the whole dice rolling aspect tedious.  Also adds to game length.  There is no way that this is a 60 minute game with 4 people.  Takes at least 90 minutes.  And if I'm going to invest that kind of time in a game it will be playing Pillars of the Earth, where your actions are less mechanical and you have some real tough decisions and unknowns to deal with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Stone Age is an inherently good game, but the problem is, Lords of Waterdeep exists. Aside from being language independent, this has nothing going for it in comparison. Unless you really like dice, that is. The game's only form of progression is with agriculture and tools, making it easier to feed your people and get resources. Otherwise it's a very static experience that goes on way too long. The whole mechanism involving feeding your people feels really unnecessary, and I think had it been left out, this game would actually be a decent length instead of going about 45 minutes too long. So in effect, the game amounts to who can gather resources and build stuff fastest. This is a perfect example of how flawed worker placement games tend to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Donated to Children's Home
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
I just ordered this and I can't wait.  This game will probably end up being game of the year for 2008.  I reminds me a lot of Caylus, a working mans version of this.  While Caylus is for sure a very deep, heavy gamers game, Stone age is more of a family game.

This game has got so many thing going for it.  There is set collection of the cards, building hut collection, placing workers (like in caylus) and resource management.The beauty of the game is what to do with your 5 meeples?  Do you make babies?  Invest in tooling?  Plant crops?  Hunt?  Collect stone, clay, wood, or gold?  Build huts?  Or grab Civilization cards?

The game ending condition is great.  Its triggered by either not being able to replenish civilization cards on the board or playing the last hut.  From there your victory points get added to the game ending multipliers of the huts, tools, meeples, civ cards (both tan and green).  

What I love about it is that even if there is a runaway leader, someone can come from behind and steal the victory, as you really never know who is leading or winning, until the final tally. And thats what will give this game a high replay factor.  In playing (on BrettSpielWelt) I never feel like I'm doing bad, but always deciding on where to place my meeples next. I feels like the victory points are almost an after thought.

The game components and board artwork is just awsome.  

For some reason to me, this game kinda feels like Yspahan too as well.  Not sure why, maybe its the dice or the individual boards for each player.

Speaking of dice, thats were the tools come in handy.  Rolled a 4, but need a 5, just use one of your tools.  And yes it has dice, but I feel that they are used very wisely.  I don't think someone with a hot hand would make or break you out of a win.  Its more strategy then luck of the dice.

I see that there is a solitare varient for this, which I will try.  You play by yourself with tweaked rules, and try to score 300 points.  

If you like Yspahan or Caylus, this is a game for you.  You will not be dissapointed at all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After 3 plays with 2 players, I see a few things happening:

1) Scores keep going up.  The 3rd game was 300 something to 200 something.  We used up almost the entire Civilization deck and almost every building.  Agriculture was pegged to the top.

There just didn't seem like a strong enough game clock to keep the game short, and so we both optimized and maximized scores.

2) There seems to be an optimal 1st-3rd worker placement.  Agriculture.  Another town option, if available, for your second pick, else a competed-for purchase or wood cutting.  Then everything else. The only exceptions were for sweet Civilization cards that had appeared before the turn, like a 2x shaman or 3x builder card that would pay out 20+ points for between 1 and 4 wood.  

3) Wood is king.  Civilization cards are the meat of the scoring, and they can be purchased with wood, which is easily obtainable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This gem of a game is simple to learn and teach, and plays great with 2 through 4 players. The turn structure is relatively simple, but the multitude of options provides great strategic depth. Yes it is a dice game, but the luck factor is mitigated by well calculated play. Decision making is usually quite effortless, and the flow of the game is rarely interrupted. The only downside I see is the amount of maths that must be performed after each dice roll. The arithmetic is by no means taxing, but over the course of a whole game it can become a bit tiring. Still, with great artwork and high quality components, Stone Age provides a delightful gaming experience that should not be passed up. Oh, and the leather dice cup makes it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Overall Comments: Stone Age is a dice-rolling game to be sure.  A game which rewards those who can estimate the values of the game elements quickly and be able to place their "people" effectively.  As a family game it works really well because of the randomization of the dice and the fun-factor that comes with the "gambling".  This game plays quick and has few rules to bog down the game.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor):9 (all of the parts look and feel good, the parts don't fit in the box though even after popping out the components)
Family: 10 (the light dice rolling has been the reason that it is getting played - an 8 year old can grasp the concept quickly)
Game Group: N/A (not played yet and may be a tough sell due to the random elements)
AP: 10 (really no slowdown, it plays quick)
Solo play: In development (working to eliminate the randomness and increase the strategy elements)

Purchased: 2008
Luck factor (1-10high): 8 (continuous dice rolling which is softened slightly by odds analysis, cards/huts come up randomly)
Recommend expansions: N/A
Age range: 6+ (yes, even the young can get this one)

Reason purchased: Geek reviews and months of culling the strategic aspects of the game, I don't like dice games but there is a need for another gateway game and this seemed to be it.

Pros: plays quick, no AP, simple to understand, interesting if simple gameplay, components look great
Cons: dice rolling, simplicity (a strength and a weekness), replayability, seems to offer up the same challenge each time

Recommendation: I would put this game in with Settlers for the light play and the randomness of getting material.  You can control the material you get a little better in this game than Settlers which makes it less likely that you would get stuck waiting for ???. This is a gateway game that a family can get into and makes a good filler game for the serious gamer.
Replay rating: Moderate
Game value(plays/game cost ratio): Average (I can't play this one too much or it starts to feel stale)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
In the stone age, place workers to gather tools, reproduce, hunt for food, acquire four different kinds of resources, get civilization cards or convert goods to VPs through buildings. On the food and resource gathering, dice are rolled to determine how much you get, with tools adding modifiers to the dice rolls. The civilization cards offer you different strateges to try, such as getting multipliers on people, food, tools or buildings. The cards also give diversity bonuses as well. 

It's a fun and engaging game. The dice factor does introduce an element of luck, and being a worker placement game, it is possible to deny people some crucial spots, which could lead to  kingmaking possibilities.  I would classify it as a light worker placement game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2.5
There is nothing *wrong* with Stone Age, but it sits at an awkward position for me.

Although often suggested as an entry-level worker placement game, randomness from dice and slightly opaque scoring rules mean that I have other games that would always be pulled off my shelf first.

Starvation strategy should probably be mentioned too. It's a common point of discussion of course, and while doesn't "break" the game it's a fairly obvious strategy that doesn't do the game any favors...

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Stone Age is a light worker placement game. It runs a little long, and all players are basically doing the same things, but it is a good gateway for this type of game. It has beautiful artwork and a neat little leather dice cup (that unfortunately should be kept in an airtight bag).

It does have a roll-for-success mechanic for resource acquisition, which I would detest if it weren't for the fact that players can adjust their rolls with tools that they develop over the course of the game. With good enough tools its possible for almost every roll to be a success, but you have to work to develop the tools first.

Scores in this game skyrocket well passed the end of the victory track (100) and can even lap the board twice. There should be some kind of marker to denote 100+/200+ points, but as the majority of the victory points are gained in the endgame tally it isn't too difficult to keep track of them.

Unfortunately, endgame point scoring is heavily biased towards the Civilization cards, meaning that anyone who didn't devote themselves to acquiring them over the course of the game will find their score sorely lacking. This single goal-for-victory path detracks from replayability as each game the same tactics will be necessary.

Dear gawd, does that dice cup ever stink!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gets better and better
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A worker placement semi-dice-fest.  A bit similar to Kingsburg, and I have heard similar to Pillars of the Earth and Castle for all Seasons.

Nonetheless with my first play of this game I was very excited.  I like this game alot because there are SO many ways to win this game.  Each person can have their own little plan, but do not stick to that plan if it is foiled, must be able to swap strategies mid-game if you want to survive!

I have heard it being broken because people just starve their people instead of feeding them.  I decided to say screw that, you GOTTA feed your people, WTF MATE?  So, every person you do not feed loses you 10 pts in my games.  Not sure if this is looked down at or not but who cares.

RATING: 5
Even though I enjoy playing this on BSW, I've hesitated to purchase my own copy -- and it turns out for good reason. Gameplay starts off snappily with little downtime but sags midway through as it tends to get a little repetitive. I caught myself disconnecting during the chore-work parts of the game: turning in food tokens to feed meeple, turning in resources to buy cards, etc. I think it has to do with the fact that this game is simply not terribly deep strategically. More dynamic games like Puerto Rico or Le Havre also have chore-work but don't drag for me -- if anything the chore-work is a complement to the constant deliberating in those games. Nevertheless I find this to be an excellent gateway game.
-------
Style is the Goal and fewer players (2) made Stone Age much more fun. My new upped rating is based on this.

[color=#117bc0][b]Probably rather play:[/b][/color] this with the Style is the Goal expansion and not too many players.

RATING: 6
I like this game for the most part, but two elements knock it down from being a favorite:

1. The dice rolling can be frustrating. There's nothing worse than putting 5-6 meeples on wood, only to roll 1s and get close to nothing, while an opponent rolls all 5s and 6s.

2. I play mostly 2 player and find at that count it's difficult to counter the "reproduce and feed" strategy (e.g. my opponent just gets to 10 meeples and gets to 10 on the agriculture track), without resorting to the same strategy. Really reduces my options on what strategy I want to employ.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Having just a few plays, I can understand why this is still a highly played game.

There are multiple paths to victory - yay!  

I tend to really like games that allow me to mitigate my luck, which this one does with the tools option.  It seems like a little thing, but those tools really add up over time.

I found out in my last play that I had been starting the game incorrectly with no food - wow!  What a gross oversight and what a difference having 2 free rounds makes!  If you are interested in a resource challenge, try starting with no food - the game still works, but you definitely do not get off the ground quickly and it makes the family strategy a lot more risky.

This game has a couple of interesting things about it.  It SEEMS really complex and there ARE a lot of things going on.  But, everyone who has played it does NOT seem to get overwhelmed. Complex and intricate, but attainable.
 
The second is that there is a general feel-good nature to the game. I think my sister's evaluation was correct - it is a positive game - you are always building something and can almost always do something to help yourself regardless of what others do.  Unlike Ticket to Ride, where you somewhat mindlessly do so, you actually get to make choices here.  And that feels good.

This plays nicely as a solo, left hand vs. right hand game.  Probably because of the previous comment - you can mess me up, but only a little.

This game also has a rare quality - it combines strategy and tactics.  Most of the games I've seen are tactical.  This one allows you to pick your overall strategy (family, tools, cards, huts) and then adjust and fine tune as the gameplay dictates.

Why this is not a 10:
-> While it feels complex, it does not have the depth I prefer for a perfect game.
-> The theme works great, but there is no story.  I prefer games that have both.
-> Not quite enough control/take that - I prefer games where I can actually wreck my opponent's plans.
+ This is a fun game to play
+ It combines strategy and tactics
+ Components are excellent!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very solid game in all player counts. Great gateway game. The civilization cards might confuse brand new players, but they'll get it.

RATING: 8
First impression (3 players): I really like how dices are used in otherwise very standard resource collecting/optimization game. In Stone Age you can allocate workers in such way that you don't need to take unnecessary risks with dice. I like the simplicity of game's mechanics. At the same time game offers a good amount of choices to think about and gives a couple of roads on how to generate points.

Stone Age has many similarities with Pillars of Earth but simplicity of the game flow and non-scripted nature of it makes it a better game between the two.

The game probably is best when played with full four players as the limitations of worker placement with three players seem to hinder a bit of some dynamics of the game making it less exciting. It is still a good game even with just three but if it can get even better with four...

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Possibly the most successful attempt so far at implementing dice throws in a tactical game, Stone Age uses them as a way to gather resources for the later gain of points (nothing new so far). The point is that the players start with five workers, each one of them corresponding to one die, which can be spread freely on the different tasks on the board: collecting resources, using them for scores, incorporating new workers or developing tools (extra help for the dice throws).

The game is actually a new mix of old elements, but soaks in quickly in the players, the replay value is high even during one evening, and the balance of all the ratios (pips-to-resources, resources-to-scores) is just perfect. All this makes Stone Age a bet as safe as it can get.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Gioco dalle dinamiche semplici e immediate è un tipico piazzamento lavoratori e gestione risorse. Dopo qualche partita il tutto sembra ripetitivo in quanto le azioni disponibili non sono molte. Il vero difetto  a mio avviso però è la forte incidenza della fortuna che con un tiro di dadi sbagliati potrebbe compromettere anche la programmazione più attenta. Gli azzardi potrebbero costar caro o far vincere le partite. Il prezzo del gioco si è sempre mantenuto troppo elevato. In conclusione lo trovo un gioco godibile che giocato ogni tanto diverte anche ma non un capolavoro. C'è anche la chicca che in caso di mancanza di cibo, alla fine di ogni turno, si possono sfamare i propri lavoratori con legno, argilla, ferro o oro, ma sono dettagli.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I've been trying to work out why Stone Age doesn't quite add up for me, and after a lot of experimentation it occurs to me that the game is almost devoid of strategy. Obviously you NEED a strategy to win, but once you've decided on what it might be, there's no going back; no 'routes around' like in Caylus or Agricola, and - owing to the clear hierarchy of action spaces - only opportunities to screw your opponents time and time over. The random element of the dice is pretty frustrating too: this just isn't how a good worker-placement game should operate.

Further Thoughts - Well, the art is nice, and I don't mind turning my brain off for an hour to play it. But there are still fundamental flaws here.

Cheap         :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Quality
Abstract      :star::star::star::star::star: Themed
Light         :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Heavy
Shallow Curve :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Steep Curve
Elementary    :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Complex
Tactics       :star::star::star::star::star: Strategy
Integrated      :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Artificial
Luck          :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Skill
Active      :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Passive
Short       :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Long
[b]Best with 4[/b]

RATING: 7
This is the best introduction to worker placement on the market today. For that and other reasons (the high quality components, the competitive gameplay, etc.), it remains a solid favorite among my game group and for me as well. Despite what you may read elsewhere by people who played this game once or twice and then dismissed it as low depth or a game with one dominant strategy (though they can't quite agree with each other what that strategy is), this game actually has a solid medium depth to go with it's excellent balance. More plays will reveal that.

RATING: 8
Score after first four game. Was 8.3 at first game, increased 8.4 at second. High replayibility, basic rules, enables good strategies, luck included but has less effect at final degrees in general, 100-120 minutes game time. 

Reduced to 8.1 after 4 plays. Because I am doing nearly same things in every game to win and it succeeds. Collect as much as possible wood buy cards with these woods even they are expensive (especially high bonus ones). But it is still very fun. A good example of good usage of dices and combining a bit luck with more of strategy. I won all 4 games till now so I cannot say dices are very decisive in most games.

I played my 5th and 6th game with my girlfriend. She can have difficulties in learning complicated games and she can get bored in some games but she learned Stone Age easily and liked it very much. Thats why I increase score to 8.2. But I still make same thing in every game and I made 280-320 points with my stabel strategy but my girlfriend only made 150-160.

Reduced 8.0. I still do same to win in every game. Even its negatives I think this game is still underrated here.

I finally lost my 8th game which I was still applying same strategies. This means I should change my strategies game to game more than my thoughts. Score is increased to 8.1 because of that lost and this additional info.

Increased 8.2 after playing its IPAD version tons of time.

Give up playing after some point. So decreased back 8.

RATING: 9
My family's favorite game.  The fact that I can play it with my kids (ages 8 and 11) and that wife enjoys playing it too makes this a winner all around.  
A relatively simple "worker placement" game set in a Stone Age theme.  Set your workers down in the hunting ground, rock quarry, gold mine or one of several other places to earn points.  There's even a Love Shack(Oh,baby)to increase your tribe's size. Most points wins.  Simple, fun, terrific game with amazingly detailed art! 
In fact, we own two copies (one at home, other in the cabin up North).
