=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Stone Age[/b] was sold via auction 4/4/15.

[COLOR=#FF0000]UPDATE: 2+ years later... (rating 8):[/COLOR]

[i]Stone Age is now back in our collection! Worker placement is still a favorite mechanism of mine, but I've culled a lot of the lighter WP games from our collection and in that regard Stone Age is hard to beat. We still also own LoW, but Stone Age offers a very different experience so I'm glad to have them both in the collection again. In the interim I've owned a lot more lighter WP games and none of them have been as good as Stone Age, LoW is the only one that has stuck around, which is a testament to the design.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (6):[/COLOR]

[i]This was our introduction into worker placement games and is probably my wife's favorite game. Personally I prefer other WP/action selection games[i](Agricola, Targi, Snowdonia, Agricola ACBaS and Lords of Waterdeep if I'm looking for a gateway WP game).[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

- Plays great with 2 (probably my preferred player count).
- Plays quick with 2 (under an hour).
- Great family/gateway worker placement game, the dice introduce some randomness into the game so that you can not math your way into winning.
- Rolling dice to collect resources is fun as opposed to just collecting "x" number when you go to a certain location (a la Lords of Waterdeep).
- I enjoy the diversity of ways you can score points [i](set collection, building huts, collecting builders, shaman or farmers)[/i], I like going for the civ cards.
- Beautiful board art and really nice components.

[i]This is one of my wife's favorite games and I have been threatened with bodily harm if I trade this game... until today![/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A favorite. Seems well balanced between strategy/planning and luck/excitement. A great medium-weight game that fills the Settlers type niche. Wife likes this one too!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Stone Age is a worker placement game.  It scales well, and plays very good with 2, 3, or 4 players.  I think the strongest part of the game is the dice mechanic used to gather resources.  It is cleverly done, and you can really can manage the luck element.  There is another mechanic in the game, "tools", which also further helps you to manage the dice rolls.

But the downfall of the game is its limited strategic options.  There are two main scoring mechanics in the game: huts and cards.  If you concentrate too much on one, your scoring potential is limited, and the people who do a better job balancing the two scoring elements, usually win the game.  Consequently, I found that the games started to feel repetitive after about a dozen plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Originally gave this game a 9 but once I fully understood the rules, I changed it to a 10.

While it says it takes 60 minutes, it usually takes us 90 to 120 minutes to finish a 2 player game.

Everything is very high quality and the pieces are well crafted and really add to the immersion of the game.

Awesome resource management game!

However way too swingy end game scoring & lack of depth ends up dragging the game down for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
this is one of my favourite games i love the art and the theme (art has a certain feel to it, altough it is colorful, the colors that were used really evoke the neolithic era for me). also, i feel like i am the leader of a tribe and am sending my people to gather food and materials we need to survive. the game is really not complicated, but has a nice depth and the dice add the right amount of luck, since you can mitigate it a little. scoring is hidden in such a way, that you don't feel left out of the game if you made some bad decisions earlier, but you can have a good guess who is the leader. regarding tactics, it's really about timing your decisions, since you can take something of real value for your opponent and then risk to loose the thing you wanted for yourself, or do it other way around. there are also multiple paths that can take you to victory. i know that there are other worker placement games that received better rating and are more complicated, but for me this hits the right spot, because you can teach new players relatively quickly and still have a good tactic experience.

RATING: 8
Bought this and my family loved it.  My wife and her brother and wife all wanted to play again and the brother said it may be his favorite game after 1 play.  They had to leave and my wife and I played another 2-player.  That rarely happens.  (Though the need for more "mean" play, blocking, keeping track of what cards they already picked up, etc. has become readily apparent after a couple of 2-player games.)

I think the concept and balance are fun--there is some confrontation over stealing desired positions and scoring opportunities, but there is usually something at least decent as another option, so more casual gamers won't be turned off.   There are multiple paths to victory and you don't feel out of the game.  Seems like a fun, much easier to teach Age of Empires or Caylus lite.  I don't usually care that much about how a game looks, but the details and composition on the board are great.  Our dice cup reeks of chemical treatment or something.

RATING: 7
Initially I had fun playing it. Place a few villagers here, place a few villagers there, manage the risk and push the luck with dice rolls. 

In 2er or 3er this game is about observing other player's intention and try to block them, which is more enjoyable.

With 4 players then one benefits from sitting left of an inexperienced player. And the one who goes last on 1st round is VERY HARD TO WIN.

It's a nice game. But it doesn't intrigue me anymore after 9 ~ 10 plays. Simply put, it's not as fun as I thought it'd be. I would've sold it by now if I bought it. : )

Maybe I'd like it better if given chances to play more of it; but kinda doubt it

RATING: 7.5
心得:
算是需要運氣跟策略的遊戲 
分數通常也不會太低
也算好上手
規則:
1.建築物一疊七張 四人四疊，三人三疊，兩人兩疊
2.起始5個人，12個食物
3.已放過的區域不能在之後再補放
4.食物不夠，一定要全部付完後不夠補資源，可以選擇不付資源扣10分(不管少付多少)，分數會低於0
5.文明卡補不滿或是建築到底，遊戲結束
6.每個資源一個一分
7.2~3人時，中間只能有兩區被占領，3人時，採集去只能有兩個人放，2人時一個
8.拿兩個任意資源的文明卡，可以任意時間使用，用完蓋著

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a nice worker placement efficiency game, with numerous ways to score points, the trick being to find a VP path that other players aren't following so you can pick 'em up cheap and without competition. There's the low risk path (straight resource conversions) and the high risk path (card collections). The latter has the New England problem - the final card(s) you need to maximise points may remain in the deck or may come out in a rush where you can't get 'em all, or may emerge cheaply attracting other players into the competition. So there's a lot of the game that's in the hands of lady luck. But at least there's good decisions to make every turn on how to allocate your workers around, when to build your engine and when to grab the points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played a few times.  In great shape

RATING: 10
Delightful. Fun.  Lots of choices, but not too heavy.   Great theme and pieces.  60 minute game. A lot of game for your money.  It could be considered a gateway game to worker-placement/resource-management Euro games, but a lot is going on, which might overwhelm newbies.  Very good 2-player. This one grew on me; at first I thought it was lame, but with persistence I began to see the marvelous subtleties to admit that this is a perfect game.

Families and non-gaming spouses seem to like this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"Solid action drafting with dice resolution. Too long and complex to be a gateway. 2p is pretty cutthroat with denial moves."

What I like:
- Decent post-gateway game (too long and complex for a true gateway)
- Pretty board and creative worker placement mechanics

What I don't like:
- Can run long (90-120 minutes, where 60 would be better)
- Limited strategies, although a variety of tactics
- Probably requires denial blocking to do really well

There is no way I would try this with a non-gamer, unless I had reason to believe they had an aptitude for games. It is a bit of a reach even for casual gamers, unless they have played several gateway games.

I watched part of a 4p game with 2 experts and 2 newbies that took over 3 hours. 60 minutes seems doable with 2p, while 90 seems like a realistic budget for 3-4.

You definitely have to play once or twice just to understand the relative values of food, resources, and VP (not to mention tools, meeples, and food production levels). Some of the icons are pretty opaque.

On the weight scale, I think 2.5 is about right. Heavier than San Juan, similar to Alien Frontiers, and lighter than Race for the Galaxy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game has totally grabbed me by my balls! It's awesome! I'd say this is the perfect (and I mean PERFECT) transitional game from light-hearted family games into deeper hardcore euro-games! If you get someone to like this game and play it well, there is nothing else to stand in the way anymore of a great game of Caylus, or Goa for example!

This game is an amazing achievement! Brilliant to look at and brilliant to touch! Everything is utterly amazing, great components, gorgeous looking board and surprisingly easy rules! This is the kind of game that makes me lurk for hours, days, weeks and months in the shadow just to wait for the next gem to pop up!

RATING: 8
Volt alkalmam számítógépen kipróbálni a játékot számos alkalommal. Ott nagyon tetszett ezért megvettem. A tábla grafikája szemet gyönyörködtető, szintúgy a kártyáké is. A játék alkatrészeinek minőségére nem lehet panasz. Végre egy olyan játék, amiben az alapanyagok nem a sablonos kis kockákra egyszerűsödnek le. Az aranynak aranyrúd formája van, a fa pedig deszkára hasonlít stb. Az ételt kis korongok szimbolizálják. Ebből nem értem, hogy miért adnak olyan sokat, mert a játékot 4 emberrel játszva talán a harmadát ha felhasználtuk. Viszont a nyersanyagokból adhattak volna talán többet, mert volt amikor igencsak megfogyatkozott egy-két alapanyag. Dobókocka is van a játékban, amiből a játékot nem ismerők azt gondolhatnák, hogy erősen szerencsefüggő a játék. Azonban ez nem így van. Igaz szükség van szerencsére is, de az elrontott dobások eredményét nagyban befolyásolhatjuk az összegyűjtött szerszámokkal. Egy valami nem tetszett a játékban. 4 játékossal kissé vontatott lett. Én unatkoztam, amíg a többiek begyűjtötték a nyersanyagjaikat, illetve vásároltak. A játékot 4 emberrel majdnem 2 órán keresztül játszottuk. 2 emberrel is kipróbáltuk. Én így jobban élveztem, és a játékidő is a felére csökkent.

RATING: 7
A worker placement game, but in my opinion, one of the worst. There is a lot of luck due to the dice roll during the acquisition of resources being partially based on dice rolls and a good roll can give you an unfair advantage. Also, the main spots (get an additional worker, gain farm area and get tools) are always the first ones to go after, so you only get them when you are early in the turn order. Not really worth a try as there are so many better games in the genre. It would be best used to introduce new players to the genre.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A really fun "roll dice and collect stuff" game.  Simple to play, but hard to pay well.  You have to judiciously upgrade early (tools, food, love hut) to get an engine going while always keeping an eye out for the good multiplier cards and you have to constantly weigh opportunity cost/risk.  Of course you don't have to do any of this to simply have fun.  I think this game is best with 2.  With 4 the downtime starts to ratchet up a bit when everyone is resolving their workers, but it is not excessive.  The fact that as much as 2/3 of the scoring can be end game scoring can be a tad frustrating; it can be difficult to gauge how you are doing midgame.  But skilled players learn to keep tabs on that as well.

RATING: 9
Un gioco che mette d'accordo tutti: quello a cui piace far ruzzolar dadi, l'amante dell'eurogame, il giocatore assiduo e quello occasionale. A un sistema di gioco non particolarmente originale si compenetra un tema insolito ma azzeccatissimo, e una grafica veramente eccezionale. Le meccaniche si integrano con l'ambientazione perfettamente, e l'interazione è molto alta (ma non troppo da impedire ogni strategia a medio termine). Sempre a proposito di strategie, è così ben bilanciato da permettere di battere più strade per conseguire la vittoria. Uno dei migliori giochi di piazzamento di sempre.

RATING: 7
A decent collect-resources-and-turn-them-into-VPs game.  The components are excellent and the board is beautiful.  However, the game suffers some balance issues, as wood is clearly the best resource.  Collecting any of the resources has the same expected value (1 meeple placement = 1 VP), but with wood you run into less remainder problems, and since it is the least expensive, it's the best for buying cards.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 6
The key to winning seems to be building the most buildings and getting the most point multiplyers with cards, both of which are usually purchased with random resources.

That and the fact that the penalty for not feeding your people is so minor that it doesn't even matter turns what could have been a good game into a mediocre (at best) game.

The dice cup and high production values earn it an extra point though.

If you're looking for a worker placement game done right, get Archipelago instead.

RATING: 4
[c]Rules Complexity:.....:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth:......:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor:..........:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime:...:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness:...........:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Replayability:........:star::star::star::star::nostar:
Component Quality:....:star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction:...:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
"Take That" Conflict:.:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Theme Integration:....:star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:[/c]

Playtime: ~30 minutes per player

Comment: Classic gateway worker placement game. It has dice and it's got quality components. While it's not exactly deep, it's got a little bit of room to stretch your legs strategy wise. Plays relatively quickly and is easy to explain. Downtime can be a bit long with 4 players, but it's nothing terrible. Overall I like this game. Great artwork on the board, too.

Optimal Player Count: 4 > 3 > 2

Plays well with all player counts, 4 just makes it easier to not have to artificially restrict things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
A classic medium-weight euro family game, featuring a worker-placement mechanism. The game is fairly easy to explain, even to non-gamers and you can really have fun with up to 4 players. With only 2 experienced players, the game turns into a deeper strategic game, where the randomness factor is just limited to the dice and the order that the civilization cards will come up. I would thus recommend it either as a 2-player strategic game, or as a 3-4 player fun game.

The component quality in this game is awesome. It can really win over gamers and non-gamers alike.

RATING: 8.5
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Instant hit, even with my wife, which just makes it extra special :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In STONE AGE meeples collect resources that will be used as payment for other stuff that will be transformed into VP’s.

Many compare this game to another worker placement game – PILLARS OF THE EARTH – so I’ll give my view on this as well.

In short: STONE AGE have a bit less scripted game play than PILLARS which is good, but the long-term strategies in STONE AGE – buy and collect different types of “civilization cards” – feels a lot more abstract.

PILLARS gives you a sense of accomplishment. In STONE AGE you don’t – these bonus cards in the end just amount up an awful lot of VP’s and makes a huge impact on the track. Those cards have different icons on it, but you just don’t really know what you have accomplished. 

STONE AGE feels more “busy” and offers at first sight more choices. But in the end it’s just a matter of collecting the right amount of something that lets you buy something. It feels rather interchangeable, although it becomes more and more apparant after mid-game that some cards are more optional than others if you want your civ-card and building tiles combos to boost your end score further.

In PILLARS there’s a greater risk strategies might burst, because you take greater risk when you upgrade your specialists to perform a certain thing. In STONE AGE the upgrades contains of piling up the “tools”. Those let you tweak the dice results and grab more resources. 

PILLARS is more convoluted, but in a good way. In STONE AGE you quietly calculate in numbers all the time. Although the dices, the “love hut” and the collecting food thing save STONE AGE from being all too procedural, I clearly rank PILLARS as the better game.

Need to play STONE AGE more for a more solid rating.

RATING: 7.5
Initial impression... a very light and quickly played civ.ish. type of game.  Almost like a very very light Puerto Rico without all the analysis.

Fun Factor: 7
Components: 9 (Leather cup & wooden dice are nice!)
Theme: 8
Mechanics: 6 (There is a problem here... the decisions are very facile, once you have played several times the strategy is very deterministic-- the choices are made for you once you understand the values of various selections.  I have found placing one meeple on first Civ card to be a slightly better option than everything else. Hence, the game for me is more about choosing when NOT to take the first Civ card in favor of doing something else.)
Theme + Mechanics: 8
Replay Value: 6 (Good replay here as you try to manipulate better and better scores, but see the comment on mechanics- the game gets easier and easier to predict.)
Scaling/Players: 10 (Plays so well with various numbers it amazes me.)
Subjective -0.25 Hit because the interaction is so indirect.  I need a bit more direct contact with opponents! But this isn't nearly as bad as Puerto Rico for indirect strategic play...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an excellent medium-light game. The decision space is more constrained than in something like Puerto Rico or Agricola, so new players are able to grasp the engine quickly, but it still offers depth and multiple strategies. The interesting decisions in the game come from risk management, timing infrastructure vs. resource vs. points acquisitions, estimating opportunity costs, and choosing a development path. It's important when teaching the game to really emphasize how many points can come from the cards, as new players tend to focus on the immediate points from building.

RATING: 8
Classic WP which still holds up. Perfect game to introduce mechanisms used in heavier games, but stands very well on it's own. It's a game that is straight-forward and has a good amount of choices to be made, although the options you should go for are from time to time very apparent. Playing with a new set of players usually result in interesting games, where strategies and tactics diverge wildly (like someone going all in for gold right off the bat!). For me, the randomness of the dice actually add tension to the game which I enjoy. Family friendly.

Not logged older plays.

RATING: N/A
21-1-2011 Reyes tardíos xD
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game; you can play it with old people. Just say it's "caveman bunco," and that'll get their attention.  

If you play it with depression era people, like your grandparents, you can taunt them about feeding their cave dudes. Watch their upper lips quiver. 

"Grandpa, you've got to feed your people, or they'll all staaaaarve!"

Watch him plop all his cave dudes on fishing after that. Leaves the juicy spots open for you.  

Seriously though (because board games are serious business), Stone Age is easily approachable by people of all ages. Nothing too tough about it. If someone asks you to describe it, just say: 

"It's a game about stone age tribes, each trying to outdo the other. You send your little cave dudes out to fish, mine, and make babies. The winner, in the end, is the tribe that's most prosperous." 

If they say "Sounds complicated," just add: "It's really just dice rolling." (that's usually your instant sale right there, if they don't like complicated games) 

The game works equally well on three levels; light hearted fun, light strategy, and for those who enjoy complaining that the choices are all obvious. 

Approach Stone Age like a light hearted filler, and you'll  have lots of fun...while losing lots of games. The board requires much more thought than readily apparent. That's because of a few different factors: The variable mix of huts coming up every turn, your luck with the dice, the turn order, and the playing style of the other players.

While some choices seem obvious on the surface, like taking agriculture whenever possible, astute players may surprise you by doing something else. Still, if you just want to play with cave dudes, while not thinking too deeply, you may certainly play Stone Age like a light filler. You'll have lots of fun, while losing lots of games.   

As a light strategy game, Stone Age really shines. When approaching the game from that perspective, you start thinking more about what your opponents are doing, and less about your own strategy. Why do I say that? Because the game is often decided not by what you choose to do, but rather what your opponents will permit you to accomplish. 

If you want to know what you can do on your turn, then you must learn to predict the actions of the other players. Just picking agriculture or tools at every option won't accomplish that goal. Because...smart opponents won't let you do that. Alternately, even smarter opponents, will let you pick what you want, then adapt their own strategy to both counter what you've done, and ensure their win. 

I'm running long, so I'll wrap this up: I like this game.  It has something for just about everyone. It serves well as either a light strategy game, or a "move dudes around on a board," game. The design is clean, the rules unambiguous, and it handles well around the corners. Highly recommended.

Update: three games in and I have yet to win. I like it more and more and so does my wife.

RATING: 8
Rating based on one play, and I really enjoyed it.  Posting a limited # of pieces on various tasks is the sort of mechanic that I adore, and the entire game is deceptively simple, with just the right amount of conflict.  

*Update* Played about 5 times now.  The "starve" strategy kind of bugs me, primarily because my appreciation of the game is in the process and not in streamlining a way to victory, but this reflects my own bias that folks playing Stone Age to be clever should be playing Caylus.  That said, it's not particularly clever as much as anti-fun.  The first time I heard that you only lost ten points when you starved I knew it was a generous weak point.  To take advantage of that is likely contrary to the designers' intent, which was (I think) more of an effort to keep those newbies whose people starve from despairing. More experienced gamers should suffer a stiffer penalty, like the ten points loss plus returning all food and commodities.  Because of my admitted fuddy-duddy-ness this game is "down" to an 8.

Update again:  Okay, having been "forced" to a starvation strategy (in a 4 player game) and winning I can see its attractiveness, though I still think a stiffer penalty (in terms of commodities or, logic forfend, people) should be put in the offing.

RATING: 8
Great, accessible worker placement game.  It's easy to learn.  Components are beautiful and work well.  It sets up quickly and flows effortlessly.  It's got more interaction than games like Agricola.  The die-rolling mechanism for resources is inspired!  And the flexibility in turn order almost equals variable turn order.  Wow, what an amazing, balanced, elegant design.  And lots of fun.  After several plays, took it down from a 10 to a 9.  I like to play it very much, but the game's largess, which is so welcome to a new player, makes it a little less than a nail-biter. Stone Age makes a great bridge game from gateways to heavy games (particularly worker placement games such as Caylus).  Backup to a 10. I am always willing to play this great game.  It's the prefect weight; I always want to haul it out on game night.
*Sigh*:  finally took it down to 9.  Still love it, but  so many awesome worker placement games have come along since Stone Age...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I really like worker placement games. Stone Age is fun. 

However, the decisions you make throughout the game are for the most part trivial. Your options are either practically equal in value, or obviously unequal. Multiple paths to victory? Not really. Instead of 'If my strategy is X, then Y is my best choice here', it's more 'Y is obviously my best choice here, so I guess my strategy is going to be X'. It's not about making a plan, but about identifying the best option every turn, which is usually easy.

This doesn't have to be a problem. It can be nice that you don't really have to think about 90% of your moves. Plus, the remaining 10% is where you win or lose the game, so it's still interesting. It's deciding who to block, and when. It's deciding if you want the game to end sooner or later. It's figuring out what your opponents want and how you can use that to your advantage. It's trying to guess and manipulate what your options will be next turn.

But all these choices are made in the second part of the game. It's almost like you might as well skip the first half and randomly give people some cards and resources instead. I worry that because strategy is mostly reactive, because you base it on whatever you happen to get, the replayability will be low. For some people, the fact that it's a simple, fun experience, might be enough to play it again and again. But Stone Age is not a game that has a lot to discover, where each play is different and you learn more every time you play.

It's fun, but the design feels lazy. Not much to dislike, but not much to love either. Probably best as a gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
alister
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Besides Tribune, Stone Age is the next best use of the worker placement mechanic which inherently has tension for limited spots; reason for being second best is that being placed for resources can be undermined by the dice. Then Stone Age slides down due to the maths as there are divisions, adding and a 10 point subtracting with multipliers to hurt the exercise. So will never match the joy of Tribune for the best implementation of the worker placement mechanic, for in the city of Rome, the avenues of progress are directed by simple street signs written on the cards or represented by icons on the faction strip.

A more interesting exercise of resource conversion to victory points than Pillars of the Earth as text is replaced by icons.


My concerns about the playing time evaporated due to most of the placement actions can be resolved simultaneously when everyone has their set of dice, with only the "die roll" civ card halting the proceedings.

RATING: 9.5
A great introductory worker placement game.

RATING: 9
This is a fun game. Tough and interesting decision making throughoutand, which gives the player great control over the outcome. I would put this game in the same style and type category as Caylus and Agricola, but lighter, more straight forward, and perhaps with less subtlety. Therefore it is more accessible and shorter than those games. I think most gamers who like the games I mentioned will enjoy this one as well. The BSW online version is a lot more fun to play since it take care of all the fiddly aspects, so I give that version a rating of 9.

RATING: 7
Lands on complexity and length somewhere between Dominion and Agricola. Fairly approachable for newer gamers, but is not an entry level game exactly. We enjoy it a lot, but after a few years of plays it has seemed to distill down a bit from what it started as. Largely it's, who can buy the most cards, more than who manages to just buy the right cards. It gets plenty of play but maybe not as much as either of the otehr two games. A good one to have in the pile to ensure your collection has a variety of offerings.
But just buy all the cards you can consistently don't be too fussy about what you buy seems a decently winning enough plan to roll with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[floatleft][ImageID=300588][/floatleft]I love introducing new games to people in my gaming groups and having them fall in love with a game that I presented to them. Introducing new games is a very rewarding experience and Stone Age was no exception. Stone Age is light and fast with solid mechanisms and it was an instant hit. 

After playing several games of Stone Age I found that wood is more valuable/powerful than gold because it is easier to gather and use to purchase cards. At first this bothered me but after stewing over this for awhile I realized that thematically wood and clay should be more valuable than gold because it would be more useful to people during the Stone Age compared with gold. Well played Bernd Brunnhofer.

RATING: 4
Stone Age offers a similar play-time and ease-of-learning to Endeavor, but where Endeavor has no luck, Stone Age has an awful lot of it. My main problem with the design is that there is no compensation at all for rolling low numbers on the dice. Over the course of the game this will even out to some extent, but I can still see it determining the winner. The different tasks your workers get to perform didn't particularly interest me - you just seem to be endlessly gathering resources and spending them - and there were a few spaces that always seemed to be taken first. The lack of any turn order manipulation also bothered me.

RATING: 10
Hands down my favorite game. Of course it helps that I like the luck element in the game. But lets face it, there is much more to this game than luck. Any game with a consistant run of crappy dice rolls will kill your chances of a win, but what are the odds that that would happen? =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good, almost great worker placement game. I like the balance of options and the multiple scoring paths. The only thing I don't really like is the dice rolls for resource gathering. 1d6 is just too swingy for a game like this, and a few fantastic or terrible rolls by one player can skew the game quite a bit. The should have used some other distribution with a smaller range or a bell curve. As deep as the decisions in the rest of the game are, it feels very frustrating to have this one aspect be so dependent on random chance.
It does feel like this game works better with fewer players, so you get more turns total and more chances to get dice mitigation.

RATING: 8.5
First impression of a two player game.
The material is outstanding and can be compared to the one of Hamburgum. The little cup for the dies with the artisanal look is superb. The rules are easy to understand and to explain. The mechanic is similar to Pillars of the Earth but it flows better compared to Pillars. With the number of ways to make victory points it's hard to keep track. So for players who like to always have a knowledge of where they stand, it can be impossible, and so frustrating for them. Never the less, I realy enjoyed my first game and looking forward for the next one.
Next game: My first impression stands. I realy like this game. It flows very well and it's way better than Pillars of the Earth to my opinion.

Première impression d'une partie à deux joueurs.
Le matériel est exceptionnel. Il se compare à celui d'Hamburgum. La petite coupe pour les dés avec la touche artisanale est superbe. Les règles sont simples et facile à expliquer. La mécanique de jeu s'apparente à celle des Pilliers de la Terre, mais celle-ci coule mieux que pour les Pilliers. Le grand nombre de possibilités de faire des points de victoire rend presque impossible de déterminer votre position. Pour les joueurs qui aiment le contrôle et savoir leur statut par rapport aux autres joueurs, cet aspect peut déplaire voir frustrer. Néanmoins, j'ai bien apprécié ma première partie et j'ai bien hâte d'y rejouer.
Deuxième partie. Ma première impression demeure. J'aime bien ce jeu. Celui-ci roule vraiement bien et est nettement meilleur que les Pilliers de la Terre à mon opinion.

RATING: 10
10/10. Looking for the next step after Ticket to Ride? As a game to introduce new friends to resource management gaming, this is a hit. Have taught kids as young as 10 and adults in their 50's by going gently, step by step. (See my guide for teaching new players) It is a perfect balance between luck, planning and boldness. The theme is tightly integrated to the game play and play doesn't drag. It's a meaty game without being too heavy for the casual player, with the bonus of sneaky math teaching for the kids at the table. Beautiful board and components (the leather dice cup sells the hell out of the game) top it all off. Lots of comments about how it's too light for the serious gamer, but this is a game that hits the table all the time and never fails to please. Best game ever NOT to have won Speil  des Jahres!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(rating based on a few 2-player games only) An exceptionally elegant and engaging game from Hans Im Glueck, which manages to seamlessly combine a wide variety of player choices without losing focus. Each turn moves quite briskly, as players place meeples in a variety of places on the board to improve their tribe or collect resources, while making sure they gather enough food to keep their population fed at the end of each turn.

Much of the nuance comes from the civilization cards, which offer dual benefits, and to the huts, the two primary scoring mechanisms in the game.

Some have complained about the luck of dice rolls possibly souring the experience (Settlers style), but assiduous use of the tools counters in the game (which give bonuses to die rolls) should minimize this.

Perhaps most importantly, the slightly more unique theme is very well-integrated, and all the components are excellent -- especially the fabulous board art -- pushing the game to a solid "8" in my book.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Civilization worker placement building game with multiple routes to victory. A good amount of upkeep makes the game a little clunky, but beautiful components and very easy to pick up. A nice medium weight worker placement game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stone Age has a little steeper learning curve (imo) than Settlers or Carcassone...  But, once you get it, it is a lot of fun and easy.  I love a game that can be funny, and talking about making villagers eat bricks or sticks, making babies, and  making fun of the all mighty power you posses over your poor villagers makes this game one of the most fun games for those that don't win, even though the play is still competitive and a good amount of strategy is used.  Also, the fact that the game has a well-balanced mix of luck and strategy and points are counted during play and after adds a level of excitement for me as well.  I've also found that you can switch up your strategy and still keep a good chance of winning which can make the game more interesting to play often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like it better than Pillars.

RATING: 8.5
2P+
Dice
With homemade alterations, theme/details improvements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
24/08/2013: Had my first game with Steven, Trent and Liang. 

A lighter game than its cousins (i.e. The Pillars of the Earth and World without End), there is a tendency for players to converge on the same spots on the board during the first few rounds, namely those which increase food supply permanently, increase the number of workers on hand and provides players with tools to modify their die rolls. Apart from this, the game is not as deterministic as the other two due to the high dependency of resource collection rate on die rolls, and this ensures that each game will turn out differently.

RATING: 9
Has the addictive quality. Simple in concept, but difficult to win consistently. My family are not big boardgamers, but when we play we like a game that has enough strategy to be interesting, but is light enough to remember how to play readily enough. This ticks all the boxes that way, and has a nice theme and attractive board. A bit heavier than Ticket to Ride Europe and similar weight to 7 Wonders, it works well for us. Been playing it for over a year now and it gets better and better for what we want from a board game.

 Well deserved 9, from our camp anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Stone Age is a smooth playing worker placement game.  Like all worker placement games that have come out lately it feels like a descendant of Caylus.  In this case Stone Age is shorter, less complicated and comes with a healthy dose of dice rolling.

It's hard to imagine a game more carefully designed.  All the game play elements fit together perfectly - too perfectly.  There is no suprise or excitement in the game.  Players play their cave people into the various locations.  As they are cavemen they don't do much besides gather goods, or convert goods into points. Unlike other games of it's kind it doesn't feel like you are building anything.

The gathering is accomplished through rolling dice.  The more cave men you have in a location, the more dice you get to roll.  This is the most interesting part of the game.  Like most worker placement games you can block the other players out of an area by placing your cavemen first.  This adds a minor element of competition and planning to get what you need.

Stone Age's biggest problem is that it doesn't feel particularly new or innovative.  Also, it lasts way too long for the amount of excitement it provides.  Basically it's a bland experience all around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Now played about five times.  Ho hum. . .  It has gotten better [4] 5/26/2012

RATING: 7.25
The objective of this game is to be the point leader.  How you get your points is the key.  You must have a population and the population requires food every turn.  The population allows you to try and gather resources including food to feed your population.  Resouces are used to buy huts worth points or cards worth points at the end of the game.  Remember you need to buy cards.  Cards score points at the end of the game.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Takes the dice rolling in Kingsburg and marries it with a strong dose of contention a'la Aladdin's Dragons, and throws in a pinch of a Yspahan dice mechanic. There's a lot of placing, then rolling, then resolving, and every placement is contentious. If someone took your move first, it requires constant instant recalculations. It is a very good game, I like it similar to Kingsburg, but a tad less due to all the built-in conflict and blocking.

After playing again after awhile, I realize what I dislike about this game : you have to place your dice first, THEN roll. So if you get unlucky, there's nothing you can do about it.
In Kingsburg, if you roll badly, THEN you play and try to make the best of the bad luck.
THAT's the key difference, and why I like Kingsburg (much) more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.3
Stone Age is a fantastic game of resource management and powers acquisition, with a perfect blend of player interaction, advance planning, and balancing different strategies.  There are a huge number of options, increasing as the game progresses, with the best choice being far from obvious.  It plays a lot like Caylus as far as competion for resources, but has many clever game features that are different, for a completely different game of the same quality.  This is one of the very few games I decided I wanted to buy after the first play.

RATING: 4
I don't understand why people call this a gateway game.  The mechanics are kind of simple, but the scoring is so confusing to someone new to boardgames.  The civ cards and buildings require repeat reference to the booklet to decipher what they do and how they score.  And the amount of math in the game just becomes tedious.  There are way better worker placement games.  And for a gateway/beginner worker placement game, I would never recommend this over Lords of Waterdeep or Manhattan Project

RATING: 6
This game is fascinating.  The resources and the food production are almost like balancing monies, so you have to make sure that you don't spend more than you have as an income.  At the same time, players have to try to buy limited time cards and buildings before their opponents.  This game requires balancing many different aspects while simultaneously presenting many different methods to achieve that balance. 

***Update***

Rating lowered to a six because Stone Age is a little dull.  I don't feel any push to try a new strategy.  Collect civ cards and buy cheap resources while my opponent collects gold and builds golden huts with fancy tools.  There is no mechanic in Stone Age that gives me a reason to find a different strategy.  Perhaps playing with more than two players would change that because other players would be occupying the spots I want, but I've got better games to play with gamers and better games to play with my family.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Fun game.  Highly recommended.   For those interested....I'm in the camp that the game would benefit from stronger rules against the starvation strategy. 

3 Basic strategies:  be a hut builder (ends the game quicker), collect culture cards, or balance the two scoring mechanisms.  Several sub-strategy decisions:  optimal family size, feed or starve, how many tools to collect.....these sub-strategies will impact which cards you buy and be impacted by which cards you are able to get.

The hidden scoring at the end is one of the things that really makes this game shine.  You can be going for a strategy and if folks aren't paying close attention (or are too wrapped up in their own strategy), you make be able to make a killing in the final bonus scoring.

Lots of meaningful decisions, lots of dice rolling.  Just plain fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This was a very pleasant game to play. I can't think of any negative criticisms. I would highly recommend this game.

This is a worker placement game for casual gamers.  Most worker placement games can get very tight with high player counts.  So much so that people might feel put off by their limited options.  It's also pretty common to feel limited simply by the number of workers you get.

I don't think Stone Age falls into either trap.  Everyone starts with a fair amount of workers, and it goes up from there.  There are generally several open spaces no matter what the player count is.  Towards the end of the game it gets a tad tight (as everyone has so many more workers than when they started), but the limiting spaces are generally not as sought after by then.

If you are looking for a light weight worker placement game I can't think of any better game than Stone Age.

:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Components[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::star::star::star::halfstar: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Rules (well written and easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: [b]Replay Value[/b]
:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Player Uptime[/b]
:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Meaningful Decisions (luck factor)[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: [b]Total[/b]

RATING: 7.8
I may need to upgrade or downgrade this with future plays. You have a tribe of meeples, who you allocate to gathering various sorts or resources. You can build farms, or gather food to feed them, you can make tools (or more meeples), or you can get wood, clay, stone, or gold, to convert into victory points (which come in two flavours).
It has dice but feels very non-random.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Love playing this game.  Finally got bought a copy for Christmas 2011.  Yay!  Ok, so I guess the question is why?  Well this was my introduction to board gaming as the Geek knows it and my first worker placement euro game.  You always remember your first time :)
The theme, the mechanics, the quality of the pieces and board, even the start player token blew me away.

The theme is set during the stone age and your tribe is competing for resources to help build huts and cultural objects against other tribes.  You do this by sending them of to cut trees for wood, collect stone, gather gold or hunt for food each year.  We're guessing a year, because the other option you have is to expand your tribe numbers by going to the love shack.

Once your tribe has established a number of resources, you can use these to build huts to live in or expand your culture.  How well you do, is measured in victory points, which are tracked as the years progress with some additional VP's earned at the end of the game.
The person with the highest VP's win's the game.

There are worker placement games for any theme you can think of, personally, I still like playing this one because you can introduce it to non-gamer friends and still have fun.  The rules are straight forward to explain and the game length is reasonable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I guarantee you, no one will come away bored or unhappy.

RATING: 9.13
I'm very late to the party on this game. I'd been bringing it to game night's for a very long time now. I FINALLY convinced people to play it with me and it's absolutely FANTASTIC! The game play is great and fun. It has everything a worker placement game should have. I really enjoy the dice aspect of the game where you can have a decent guess of what you'll get, but not guaranteed. There is a way to mitigate the luck with the tools and also allocating more workers when it's a very important resource that's needed. I am in love with the type of end game scoring in this game (similar to Concordia) where you are in charge of how much things will score for you based on the cards you've purchased throughout the game. However, it's also the part I liked the least solely because of just how many points there are in the end game. I got 2/3 of my points after the game was over and it really diminishes the importance of in-game points. It's really only a small issue, but it seems silly to be lapping the track 2 or 3 times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm a big fan of this game. I've only played it online, so can't vouch for the board components.

It's a superb worker placement resource game, which scales very well to extra players. It involves long term planning with short term gains. So while simple to explain and play, it does require some strategy in thinking ahead. 

Dice rolls introduce some randomness, but bad rolls can also be offset somewhat by research - so this should placate those people who hate any game involving dice!

Overall, whether I've won or lost - I've always enjoyed playing and have never turned down an offer to play :)

15/2/2017 - Having now purchased and played the board game, I can say that the component and box quality are great as well. Another bonus is this is a game where there is no text on the board. Therefore, owning the German version of the game does not hinder me at all - I just download the English version of the rules and the game plays perfectly. Still one of my favorite games!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have warmed up to Stone Age, though it has been an interesting journey. I was introduced to this game after being "long-in-the-tooth" with deeper, mechanical, and/or complex euros. Admittedly, I was curious to see what the hype was about regarding the quintessential introductory-worker placement. Leery, I admit, as I am wary of hype. I was initially impressed by its novel simplicity, and enjoyed seeing the essence of dice and worker placement of later titles down the line. A few games left a bitter taste in my mouth, due to some truly poor instances of luck. A few more plays later, taking the good rolls with the bad, I can say I genuinely enjoy this game. It has its rough edges, but I am keen to play with the right group, if just for a pleasant romp of resource gathering.

(+) Accessible gameplay with instances of indirect player interaction.
(+) Strategies are rather straightforward and clear, but cards and tools allow for some novel tinkering.
(+) Stunning production quality. The art is just eye-candy.

(-) A string of unsuccessful rolls can really sting, but you take your lumps if you play this type of game.
(-) Limited strategies--even more limited dominant strategies.
(-) Actions are wrote. Every turn, just roll and move (resources, points, cards, tokens).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Beautiful worker placement game. I usually like worker placement games, but unfortunately I simply don't enjoy playing this one. Recently I've played several times on Yucata, and have been trying to figure out why this game just doesn't work for me. 

The random dice rolls for resources are supremely irritating to me, and the relative value of the different resources doesn't appear to correlate well to the difficulty/risk in acquiring them. Lucky rolls can lead to huge scoring on a couple huts which is hard to account for. The multipliers on the cards can be overwhelming if the right ones fall into your lap. Lucky draws and rolls rule this game. It's disappointing that I don't like this game because I really wanted to like it. It seems to be a popular game, and several friends enjoy it... but the more I play it, the more I dislike it. And I didn't like it much the first time I played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
After a few plays, I still enjoy this game.  It does share features of Pillars of the Earth (send out workers to get resources), but the die roll element adds a nice touch to the overall game as nothing is so certain anymore.  Shares some elements with Catan (die rolls for production), but much more control than Catan and no trading, so players are more in control of their own fate.  With the different ways of gathering points, I can see this one getting a fair share of table time.  Besides any game with a love hut (love shack?) can't be all bad.

RATING: 6
Seems to play well for 2-4 players, which is a nice target audience. Has a random component that seems unobtrusive. These are good things.

After a few plays, I'm beginning to feel that the "resolution" stage of each turn (after all workers are placed) takes a long time. Each player typically takes 3-5 minutes to resolve it, and the game grinds to a halt. This is a significant negative point, and one that may urge me to purge this game from the collection. These are bad things.

RATING: 7

If you think of it as an "arcade" version of Agricola and aren't into the heavy planning games, you should like this.

RATING: 6.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
13-07-2014. Rated after 1 play. Worker placement game in which you allocate people to get more guys, gather tools that help you get resources, buy buildings (VPs!) or cards. To gather resources, you roll a die for each guy you send.  More valuable resources are reflected by lower chance to get them (you roll dice, add the values and divide by a number that is higher for more expensive stuff). You use resources to buy die modifiers, buildings (VPs) and can go increase your amount of workers.

Light game, very fun. Im a bit afraid that the cards are overpowered unless everyone goes for them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Trastero
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game has a lot of popular features including cards, dice and gathering resources, making it very fun to play. Easy to teach any level of gamer, Lots of fun. One of my wife's favorite games.

However, if someone isn't rolling the higher numbers, they will be in for a miserable ride. If you consistently have to place a worker in the space that gives you tools in order to mitigate poor rolls while other players are scooping up resources and cards, you will be at a disadvantage. I have played this game enough that this issue has manifested several times.

I think this is a game you outgrow after about ten plays or so.

RATING: 4
----------

The components are top notch, and the board is beautiful.  I like how tools are used to mitigate the negative affects of poor dice rolls.  The game itself plays much differently with 2 compared to 4:  in a 2 player game, grabbing the green cards is a must as you try to collect all 7 symbols, but it's much harder to be profitable doing this in a 4 player game due to the increased competition for those cards.  For me, the most exciting part of the game is when you must choose how many workers to dedicate to a resource:  do you play it conservatively and over-allocate to ensure you get your resources, or do you try to spread yourself thin and hope for a good roll?

However, there's just not much here for me anymore.  Gameplay is tactical, and the purchases don't lead to anything useful other than victory points -- which, to me, is boring... especially when a majority of your points are decided after the game ends.  I suppose the challenge of the game is synergizing your point-modifier cards with your civilization strengths, but I REALLY wish the huts provided more than basic victory points... such as bonuses or aids.  

Also, converting the expensive resources (rock and gold) straight to victory points via huts at a 1:1 ratio means that the resources are functionally identical.  As BGG's Johnny5 so eloquently said:  "There is zero thematic differentiation of the resources. Not in how you get them, not in what you can use them for, not in how they score. They are completely and utterly generic."

----------
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
--May2008-- I really enjoyed this my first time out.  It's a very nice game merging a variety of familiar mechanics in a tight an coherent package.  The draft of scoring cards is reminiscent of Showmanager; the worker placement is a nice twist on earlier single-placement titles; and the dice mechanics are very delightful.  This is one I'll need to buy.
--Jul2008-- Picked up a copy.
--Jun2009-- Interestingly, after a year of play it's lost some of its lustre for me:  repeated plays are very similar.  And yet, daughter #1 enjoys it.

---
Munkáslehelyezés, "családi környezetben". Eléggé kiegyensúlyozott, gyönyörű grafikával (hiába,Menzel...) rendelkező társasjáték. Vonalas gémereknek nem ajánlott, mert az igazán kiélezett küzdelmeket végső soron a kockadobás dönti el, ha nagyon leszűkítjük a dolgokat. Azonban a szerencse ilyetén szerepét egyáltalán nem érzem zavaró méretünk, pl. a játékidő függvényében.
Worker Placemet-tel ismerkedőknek abszolút ajánlott! Ideálisan működik 2-3-4 fővel is. Nagyon korrekt darab. Könnyen, gyorsan, jól tanítható/tanulható. Családi játéknak tökéletes.
---
Most már több játék után azt mondom, hogy túlságosan "mechanikusan" játszható (erős lenne talán száraznak nevezni).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
And yet another worker placement game. On the good side, I like the way you can specialise in different areas to win and these all seem quite well balanced. However, of the four I've played (this one, Agricola, Age of Empires III and Pillars of the Earth), this is the one I like the least. Maybe my slightly negative feelings are a result of over-exposure to the genre. The new thing it adds is dice. I have no problem with the added randomness; the risk-management is relatively interesting. I just find the extra round of going through each player resolving their choices extends the game time without increasing the pleasure. Moreover, although towards the end of the game your productive engine should be a little larger than at the beginning, the difference is quite small and you don't have the pleasure of creating a vp machine and then watching it go. Another minus point is that it's clearly only going to work well with four.

I'll play it if it's on the table and no-one wants to play anything else, but there are many games I'd rather play than this one. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Felt a little single-dimensional for it's length (about 90-120 minutes with 4 players?). Some spots are so obviously more useful than others that almost always the first players will grab them. The farmer spot is just obviously overpowered - why should there be something in the game which is mostly a redundant no-decision. Didn't feel like there was enough tension at some points - except for last few rounds, the resource spots were almost never very scarce with 4 players. And then the good old "know when to stop investing and pressing for points" that every eurogame does. A lot of people complain about the dice, but that didn't feel like the problem - tools helped even out the occasional bad luck. Not a bad game for the first euro-game for somebody to start from - but from there on, there are more interesting and dynamic euros for this length.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
not very accessible Light Euro 

This one took a bit of getting used to. I found it unremarkable and stupid at first, little control, fairly arbitrary, no theme (starvation?!) etc. SOld. Of course, those were plays with 4, where a lot of the above is true.

Got pissed off with people talking about playing it 200 times in a month, thinking that either they were Gibbering Mouther insane, or I was missing something. Took it up again online, and lo and behold, what did we have here? When played 2 player, felt like a relative of backgammon...playing dice to scratch the probabilities for one or two points above average, counting the cards played and bought, maneuvering through their strategies, finding their holes and dead ends. Lovely! After a dozen online plays I was sold, bought it again.

I only play it with 2, and only play it very competitively. It actually has some real legs, is a fun one to really dig into. Prefer to play with another hardcore Stone Age player.

And I don't call it 'feeding my people' anymore (they obviously get adequate food--no workers die, do they? you just lose points), I call it 'feasting', which is of course necessary to maintain tribal (and inter-tribal) unity. So of course not having regular feasts will penalize a tribe...instead of 'starvation strategy', I call it the 'no-feasting strategy', which of course can be useful in some game situations. Absolutely no house rules are needed to 'fix' it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The game is fun, but technically it's very easy to exploit: push Agrculture so that you don't need to invest resources in hunting, focus on tools and remember that the progression points / resources is not linear but a power law, so that you score more points if you have one or two specialized sectors instead of trying to score points in all possible categories. Still, although not difficult, the game is always fun to play, and quick.

RATING: 6.5
I will almost always pick something heavier than this, and I see it's problems - luck dependance (although not as high as in Settlers of Catan), wildcard buildings are much better than others, difficulty with focusing your strategy as some spots are visibly better than others and will almost always be picked on the first round, which makes the decisions too easy and without a large overall impact. However, it's still fun to play, perhaps mostly because of nice production and a well implemented theme.

The expansion improves the game significantly by making it slightly heavier, giving you more strategic choices and making decisions less obvious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Upon reflection I might have been a little harsh on this game.

However, it's still a little repetitive. My turn, do the same, do the same, do the same. Simple with lots of adding and dividing numbers. It feels like a cross between Pillars of the Earth and St. Petersburg - more St. Petersburg. The cards are like the aristocrats, the buildings are like buildings, we go around and around until the cards (or one of the building stacks) runs out.  We have the points counting of our aristocrats (the cards) to add at the end and we're done. Next time I'm going to play it exactly the same based on what cards come out when. If you're looking for a worker placement game then Tribune has fun, flavour, varied mechanics and all the other good stuff this game is missing. Seriously though, it's okay, I don't mind it, but I just don't feel like I've got a grand plan I'm working on or any sense of accomplishment when I win. There's no real sense that I'm slowly building or developing something. It's okay, but it feels a bit "blah" - I've counted to a lot a points, but where's the fun, where's the flavour? Reflecting on this I think it's a pity the game has been dumbed down to a collection of points and multipliers. It would have helped the theme tremendously if the buildings DID SOMETHING rather than just giving more points. My disappointment lies in the fact that it could have been so much better than an exercise in counting points.

this is a fantastic worker placement game in that it really does reward along probabilistic dice curves... and still lets you choose how you want to play.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cute, but I don't envision it keeping my interest. I think a lot of what makes economic games interesting is the interaction between different parts. In puerto rico, you want to build buildings where the benefits stack. In Agricola, you pursue actions that increase the efficiency of other actions. In stone age, you try to maximize the efficiency of turning actions into resources. And, you try to maximize the efficiency of turning resources into victory points. Each of these decisions can be made largely independent of each other.

RATING: 4
One play, three players. Scores ranged from 289 to 196.

The game looks very nice, the components are well made and solid and I like the occasional worker placement game, but the dice rolling kills the game by adding a far too random element with every resource gathering action at their mercy.

This may be a good gateway game for the worker placement genre, but move on to something else as soon as the concept has been grasped.

RATING: 6.5
Suddenly we're seeing a number of worker placement games coming out, and there's just not that much to differentiate this one from Pillars of the Earth. 

It's not bad, and I actually like the dice mechanic for getting goods, but most of the time choices seem fairly obvious. 

I also hate the mechanical feel of "The Village." The first three people almost always pick Granary, Tools, and the Barry White Hut. Yawn. I want there to be a tough and interesting decision, and those first three placements just aren't. 

I'd definitely play again--I enjoyed it (I do wish it were a bit shorter). But given a choice, I think I'd always pick Pillars over this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun light Euro that is far deeper than it appears, and not as luck-dependent as you would think, because the luck comes only from the order in which the cards and huts appear. The strategy can be so subtle (a wasted dice pip here, an action more efficient than you think neglected there, a combo you failed to trigger), that it was lost on me my first few plays. Excellent components were the tipping point that drove me to purchase the game, and I'm loving the decision! I wish there were fewer spots on stone and gold.

First Eurogame where I've liked it enough to become a veteran. I love how every single play is different, because the cards come out differently, and players valuate things differently. All the strategies are finely balanced, and I've seen the game won with all of them; in fact, if you go into every game with the exact same strategy, you'll get whipped. The winner is the one who sees the most viable strategy and picks and maintains it. This is truly one of the games that keeps getting better as you play more, and the great balance within really speaks to hours and hours of playtesting. Love it best with 4, because of the viability of the starvation strategy, and 3 is also good (especially since I tend to win the 3-player version). 2 is interesting, as the set-collection is all over the place, there is a huge amount of blocking, and you have to think differently in making your decisions, such that it becomes almost an entirely different game. It's still good; just be aware that it's different.

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/330357]Check out my review here[/url].

The mechanisms are accessible and well-tuned, which made me anoint this initially as the '4th pillar' of gateway games, but when put to the test, it flopped. Doesn't engage non-gamers or budding gamers at all. Too dry. I got rid of it.

4+3

Taking the 1 point off design because you can often feel trapped in turn order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Birthday gift for Julia from Zack in winter of 2013

This is our favorite worker placement with resource management game that has fabulous components including a mural like game board along with wooden dice, illustrated cards and tiles, and colorful wooden cave meeples. This artful Euro plays well consistently for that kind of medium weight strategy game in about an hour and comes down to the wire at the end usually to see who wins.  I like that there are many options to acquire victory points along the way and that each player keeps their objective card victory points hidden so you won't know until the end who wins. For me the theme of being prehistoric hunters and gatherers really comes through with the hunting for food and mining of raw materials; the game has its own sense of humor too.

RATING: 9

Pro: Gateway to the genre, so mechanics are fairly streamlined, but still very engaging. Multiple paths to victory. Playtime is perfect. Artwork and components are great.

Con: End-game points are often worth more than double what you'd have earned during the actual game. Gets very mathy doing those moments, as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stone Age is an OOP though exceptionally fun worker placement game with dice rolling to add an element of chance you must overcome with keen resource planning. It's a great entry level game for those new to Euros, yet has enough meat to keep avid gamers coming back. The artwork and components are superb though that didn't stop me from upgrading most of the stock meeples, food and resources. It's much more fun to grab a steak meeple for 10 food for your tribe after a big hunt rather than a 10 denomination token. Similarly, carrots and potatos from other ag-based games nicely replace the 1 denomination tokens you earn from the agriculture track. I thoroughly enjoy the theme, mechanics, components and expansions of Stone Age and highly recommend it others if you can still locate a copy for not too much cash.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Stone Age -- Played three- and four-player.  Good with either number of players, but it does play differently.  I prefer four, I think.  Seems to me, play is likely to be more interesting when all three of the central locations are available.  But then, the change in value of those locations is more apparent in a three-player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
1 play, I won (200+ points, going for shamans and tools and above average dice rolls). 

Given how I thought I would hate this game, I found the experience surprisingly pleasing. Sure everything I don't like in euros is here: the hidden sets spread sheet scoring - VP ={n*X} + {m*Y} + {o*Z} + {a^2} + B1 + B2 + ...; the bidding for actions (worker placement) with no other interaction making it a MPS. 

On the other hand it's the best looking spread sheet game I've seen and enables various caveman jokes while each player peacefully goes about their business (common map helps making MPS a tad more social). And the strategy part is good and reminds me of Power Grid - because everything is balanced the key is to go for whatever other players are not going for (though it's less obvious here). Gameplays flows smoothly (great idea of combining multiple workers on one spot to work with dice probability) as you mostly know what you'll be going for in a given turn (+ plan B and C and dump everything on D if nothing else works). I suspect repeated plays will make it less interesting and samey. So far, it's the most pleasing VP matrix I've played. 

So the experience was an 8, but I suspect the game will feel samey on repeated plays.

RATING: 8
[38 plays] I like this quite a lot. For a dice dependent game, it is more reliant on skill than many. For a worker placement game, it may be among the best for new players. Everything about it makes lots of easy sense.

Stone Age is well designed and nicely produced. There is nice tension to the decisions here. There also seems to be several routes a player can choose, although a diversified strategy isn't always bad either. (Focusing too much early energy on civilization cards is not a good move, and I am largely skeptical of any tool heavy strategy - especially with regards to tool multipliers for end game scoring.)

Although this is a favorite 2 player, it does make for a really fun and competitive 3 or 4 player game as well.

Most recent play Sept '17.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
#18 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2016)
#14 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

This is the best gateway worker placement game, in my opinion. There are multiple strategies you can take, but it doesn't feel like there is too much going on at the same time. The randomized cards and buildings ensures that each game will be unique. In many Euro games, I feel like I haven't accomplished anything I really wanted before the game is over. I don't feel this way with Stone Age. I always feel like I've built up an engine that is really working for me- then I just sit back and watch the points roll in at the end and see how I fared. I like that you see what cards other players take when they grab them, but then they remain hidden in their hand, so it's hard to know for sure where everyone is at with their scores until the very end. An element of surprise with end game points is always welcome with me!

Acquired: November 2011 - Amazon

Competitive
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Ugh. Caylus has spawned a series of games involving drafting for actions in order to gain resources and abilities to build or buy VP-awarding cards/tiles/buildings. Pillars of the Earth improved it by streamlining the system but still keeping it fairly meaty. In the case of Stone Age, the system is dumbed down even more (it's too simple for people who want a complex game, it's too complex for people who want a simple game).

As mentioned, players use their meeples to draft for actions or resources. The only ‘twists’ are the scoring system (there are cards which provide multipliers for other resources/tiles which players have bought) and the rolling of dice for resources.

Players who like the game must surely have been wowed by the inclusion of a ‘real leather dice cup!’ It’s admittedly a nice touch but the game felt overly basic and even though the system placed restriction on the choice of actions each turn, players can easily adapt strategy to mitigate that ‘agony’. Sometimes, the game actions felt almost procedural. ‘Oh, the other two players chose agriculture and tools before me’, I think I will have to just grab wood…unless the civilization card is looking attractive. Worth a play or two but Pillars of the Earth offers a richer experience in a similar length of time.

RATING: 6.75
This game utilizes an interesting combination of worker placement, set collection, and some dice rolling.  As a result, the game play experience feels unique.  This game continues to grow on me with each play, but there are still few concerns that I have with the game: (1) The first few worker placements of each round are always love hut, worker tile, and food track; (2) dice rolling can be boon or bust (this can be mitigated by worker tiles, IF you can get them); (3) big points by collecting the green cards is not necessarily a good strategy since not all types may even be available during a particular game. Even though I don't love these attributes of the game, it can still be an enjoyable experience if played with the right group of people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Mechanically, the game isn't very thematic. That said, it's nonetheless an absolutely beautiful game. The art is gorgeous and the wooden bits are cute and thematic. Maybe this might be a bit shallow, but I think the great bits and art made the game easier to get into.

For the two player game, the zero-sum nature of scoring (at least, when you focus on civ cards) short circuits much of the on-the-fly math. It's not onerous, even for Michelle. The trickier part is knowing which village space to take when (opportunity cost and benefit varies depending on what else is going on), and when to grab wood. The emphasis on proper timing reminds me a lot of Jaipur. 

After crushing Michelle in ...  too many games, I decided to personally coach her (instead of just directing her to the strategy section of BGG). The next game I won on the tie-break, which was a pretty huge improvement for her. I may have reduced the fun for her a bit though? She says the game isn't actually what she thought it was about, and what it is now isn't as exciting as what she thought it was. I guess we'll see what she thinks a few games down the line, since she does like Jaipur quite a bit.

I remember reading somewhere that strategy for Stone Age is extremely sensitive to player count. We played a few games with 3 this holiday season, and it definitely feels different. I am much, much worse at the game with 3 players, and Michelle is better. She doesn't change the way she plays at all, so apparently her normal strategy is somehow not tuned for 2p. I guess we already sort of knew that, though.

RATING: 7.5
This game was the gateway game that got me into the hobby. You're a tribe leader sending out your villagers to do work to progress your village. It's fun seeing your village grow and you'll feel stronger as the game goes on. You'll also push your luck as you'll rely on some dice rolls to roll high. It's simple, yet theres a good amount of depth to give it a nice replay value. At the time, I didn't know anything about the hobby, let alone the bgg rating system but I knew I was playing something special. Unfortunately this game is quite rare as it is out of print and it's the one game I regret not owning. Fortunately a friend of mine has it!

RATING: 8.30838
It's a good game, but I'm afraid everyone wants to decode the perfect solution.  That's good, but I wonder if it will have lasting power do to this.  The 300 point total seems reachable, although the game could be won with as few as 100+.  The card acquisition strategy seems to be quite powerful unless the majority of players are attempting the same thing.  I guess a player might have to acquire a few cards for defensive point blocking opportunities too.  There are no animals in this game either, although a few of the little meeples can seeming transform into little beavers and termites to eat the lumber or among other things when the food gets too low.  The constant food production seems annoying and unfun.  The game has lots and lots of dice situations, but there is no true confrontation.

I think the game could use a nice cannibal or raiding party variant...

Update Nov. 19th : Ended up trading this game away.
Great game to introduce new gamers to worker placement. The art is wonderful. It has depth/different possible winning strategies, but all of them start by rushing village actions (tools/farming) before they are all taken then spending ressources in different ways. We now enjoy playing heavier games in which there is more liberty to do what you what and in which order.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a wonderful illusion of a game.  There are many things here to distract you as you try out different permutations of placement trying to best the odds in differing ways.  When you first read the rules, it is clear that it is yet another action selection engine builder created with the sole purpose of earning Victory Points.  Fine.  So after you pretend that this will be ok, the dice add an element of fun, and the whole thing just works, albeit in a silly way.  But as the game progresses the vernier runs thin.  It becomes a bit long for how dicey it is, the light fun becomes tedium as the game devolves into repetition.

I would gladly play this again if there was only a stack of 5 or 6 huts per pile.  This will cut down on the play time to prevent it from overstaying its welcome.  Also this way you won't max out on farming, it will force tougher decisions of instead of always opening in the village you will have more incentive to open with getting the cards.  Now knowing when to get the cards (as there will likely be fewer in the game) will be essential.  The greatest advantage to a shorter game is that it makes the starving strategy much less viable as they shouldn't have time to get their engine going.

The starving strategy just feels wrong to me. 

It was still pleasant enough.  I wouldn't turn the game down outright if offered, just to try only going for wood and cards.
