=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Took me exactly 21 tries to chalk up a victory in this game (one face-to-face and 20 on BSW) and the most salient point about my "9" rating is the extent to which I loved the journey.

This is one terrific game with just the right touch of 'brain burn' to elevate it above the level of common.

There is a need to balance in-game acquisition of VPs (by obtaining buildings) and the necessity of developing bonus multipliers (with civilization cards) that will score points in the end. The genius of the game is in this balance; understanding it and being able to execute it when opponents are constantly narrowing your options at every turn. Hard to settle in to the idea of moving your marker along the food track in a 4-player game, when three out of four times, those who go ahead of you claim the space. You need to stay nimble and adjust your tactics according to the options available to you when it's your turn.

There's a degree of 'down time' associated with this game, related to the process of both placement and resource collection. In many cases, if you're going last in a 4-player game, especially playing face-to-face, you could almost go out to lunch before your turn comes around. There is no advantage to paying attention to what others are doing because it won't be affecting the decisions you've already made (placement) or the actions you'll take when it is your turn (collection). Were it not for the fact that certain civilization cards being collected by opponents afford you the opportunity to select resources for your own use, you could tune out of opponent play altogether. Not a significant issue, though. There's more tension in the placement than there is in the collection process and with a group that's familiar and on the ball, things move pretty quickly.

A deceptively easy game to learn and play, although its proficiency learning curve is lengthy ("So easy," notes one 'room' on BSW, "even a caveman could do it."). Someone can explain the whole 'balance' thing a hundred times, but unless you 'feel it out,' in practice, it's not going to sink in. First few times through, one is unlikely to understand the importance of any given building or civilization card and how decisions at any given point have to be made with regard to an overall plan of action.

As noted previously, though, it's a great journey and with a group of like-minded and -experienced players, this is a terrific middle weight game.

RATING: N/A
Rahdo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I expected to dislike this game, but it surprised me. Very simple worker-placement mechanism allows the player to tilt the odds of getting needed resources one way or the other. Outcomes are usually based on the sum of lots of dice, which means tight distributions and more predictable payoffs. This is much better than the typical dice game (e.g., Settlers) where one very flat-distributed die roll can crush you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really enjoy this game. I also enjoy Kingsburg which involves dice rolling as a key mechanic but just like Kingsburg you have enough control over the 'randomness' that it never really becomes an issue. If you desperately need a high number you can add more dice or use tools to automatically boost your roll. The different strategies and randomness of the cards and buildings keep each game fresh. It's also really easy to teach people as the mechanics involved are very straight forward. A good board game is one in which you make a series of interesting decisions and that's exactly what you get with this game. I guess it just doesn't appeal to some people but I find it to be a lot of fun. It doesn't hurt that the pieces are also really well designed and made either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple, fun, and fast-playing. Take the best parts of Caylus, and roll them into a richly-illustrated game. It has many ways to win. (But did people really pan for gold during the stone age?)

After further plays, I wonder if the balance is off for some of the options. In my latest game, I ignored feeding my people altogether; instead I just procreated and built buildings and grabbed cards for People and Buildings. I won by a landslide.

From now on, we will be doubling the penalty for not feeding your people: -10 VP for your first offense, -20 VP for the second, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
This is a good worker placement game where the risk in dice rolling can be, to a limited extent, mitigated. Like a typical Euro-game, I like the various ways one can score points and in general, I think the better player will win the majority of games played. I think it functions well as a good introduction to Euro-games.

I have lots of worker placement games, but this one fires on all pistons better than most: plays fast, multiple victory paths, low AP or kingmaker quotients.  And the board is gorgeous.

RATING: 6

I think if there was a way that more than one player (at increased cost) could get tools, food production or have babies, it would make for more of an interesting, tense game.

UPDATE: After playing it for the first time in a long time, I realize that behind the chrome, there really isn't something great here and it is indeed missing the nice little element to make this more intriguing. I find it long for what it is, and would never play it with 4, and only occasionally with 3.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Decent gateway worker placement game with great components, but too long, and not enough variability. I feel that the multipliers on the cards are too large; they make end-game scoring determinative rather than important, and that trivializes scoring during the game, which means you don't have a good idea of how well you're doing until the end, unless you count cards. So you pick your strategy at the start, stick to it, and hope you come out on top. I liked it a lot at first, but my enthusiasm dwindled with each play, as with worker placement games in general. Agricola is better.

RATING: 6
Very nice going game. You always seem to have enough choice - even if the best choices are taken, you can always get more resources which will speed you later.

Nice tension between the people you gather, to the food you need to feed them.

It seems the score difference between the winner and the loser is very small - the entire game revolves around 20 or so points difference - so the game is actually a game of tactical maximization on every axis.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like Pillars of the Earth with a stone age theme: you allocate workers to various areas on the board in order to collect resources and then to convert them into points. The VP generation is more straightforward than Pillars, generally with simple recipes and a direct pips-to-points conversion scheme (with one exception: the civ card symbol set-collection). The major difference, other than theme, is that resource production is based not only on who got to the location first (some locations have only limited space for worker meeples), but on dice rolls.

This is probably my favorite of the lighter worker-placement games (Age of Empires would likely top my list of heavier worker-placement games): plays quickly (online, at least) and the luck of the dice is somewhat manageable. Still, I wonder if the game would be better:
- if it used averaging dice (2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 5) instead of standard d6's?
- if some of the huts or cards gave you ongoing powers of some kind?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sat on my shelf for about a year. I picked up Lords of Waterdeep before I even had a chance to play & ended up selling off Stone Age because they compete for the same space & I prefer the theme in Lords.

RATING: 7.5
Long ago in prehistoric times cavemen used to roll DICE to acquire gold and other resources that they were immediately able to convert into huts and playing cards. Now you can relive that same experience in the form of a board game!stoneage is a fun and thoughtful worker placement game that captures the exact feeling of ancient life, okay maybe it doesn't, but it is definitely a great and fun game. And the board itself is flat out amazing!

RATING: 9
One of the best new games I have played in quite a while.  My favorite so far of 2008 and right up there with Phoenicia, my favorite from 2007.  I'm intrigued to see how it will hold up-if one strategy seems to always work, such as focusing on either the cards or huts.  If so, I can see my rating slipping.  If not, a ten is a possibility here.  The rules are straightforward and the selection mechanic reminds me of Leonardo da Vinci.  The dice, coupled with the division rule for obtaining different commodities, add a nice bit of randomness and excitement.  I should have known I would like a game from the same designers as St. Petersburg!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Next to Carcassonne, this is the game I most don't get the popularity for.  It is an extremely bland by-the-numbers worker placement game.  Each turn players collect resources which they use to fill orders, build structures, and feed their workers.

It doesn't add anything to the worker placement formula and it isn't even an old game.  By 2008 when this was released there were already several popular worker placement titles that did new and interesting things.  This game should be buried in a discount bin somewhere, not on the front page of the Geek.

Sure, it's simple and light, which makes it a reasonably decent gateway game to teach worker placement mechanics.  But again, there are much better accessible worker placement games available such as Lords of Waterdeep and Fresco.  A game can be simple while also doing new and interesting things with the mechanics.

It's not a BAD game by any means, there's just no point to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2 PLAYER 25/05/08
It's a good game. Very well produced with fine components. The theme is very abstract.
It's fun enough to see the table now and then. I only think that maybe it drags for too long. I have to play it again soon to see if cards are really much more important than buildings. I guess they are!

06/06/08
Played again with four players:
It's better with four players than with 2. It flows better. The thing is that this is one of those games that need experienced players. It's a good way to introduce people into play but for a totally balanced game it needs full experienced players.

Michael Menzel made a good job on the art work of this game. It works pretty well and the components are excellent.
The game play is very simple and straightforward but I'm really starting to think that the options are not enough to make this game interesting for many plays. It results the same play after play - usually cards make the difference.
Also, picking the food increase and the worker growth seem to be the most obvious choices at the start mid game making it a bit dull.
Still a fun simple game to be played a couple of times for year.

(N)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
It's really fun to build up your little village and try to time when to build up resources and when to buy the various cards and buildings which actually give you points. In most games the points come in waterfalls and end-game bonuses so that you never quite know if you are winning or not. Great fun. The components are nice and the leather dice-rolling cup is a great touch.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For now 7 points but I am very sure this rating will change, not sure if for the better or worse. I find Stone Age difficult to judge, I am actually not sure if I like it or not, since I am willing to play more I am obviously intrigued. 
It is a game with a strong learning curve, which on the downside means mixing experienced and new players does not go very smoothly. But for players on the same level it is an interesting experience. A worker placement where you have to figure out the best strategy. There is a bit luck involved in the draw of new cards and the dice roll (when you determine whether you earned any goods this round), normally I do not mind luck to a degree but this game is so strategy heavy that the luck is sort of random and unfair. It bugs me.
But the game draws you in when it challenges you to find the best strategy to get the most points. At first I found it a bit overwhelming but exactly the diversity in placing opportunities makes it interesting. It sure has its appeal but I am not sure if it the right one for me. Time will tell.
Full point up, it did indeed grow onto me :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Gifted game. played several time prior to joining BGG.  what a gem.  our gaming friends birthday gifted this to me and its been in rotation.  probably our first worker placement game and we've loved the mechanic ever since, leading to waterdeep, pillars of the earth, lancaster and ninjato(the last 2 sorta worker placement, i've seen discussions).  anyway, there's lots to love.  the battle for civ cards, who's growing their families, who's increasing the farming, who's gathering the huts.  and the randomness of the cards is what makes it interesting.  who is willing to bypass the wheat hut for a juicy 3x hutbuilder card as an example.  oh no, i lost track of who has picked up the most invention cards and do they need that one, and are they willing to pay 4 resources for it?  some of the things you get to think about during play.  the expansion we doubted it was needed, but we discovered we played some things incorrectly and once remedied, the expansion is great.  plus it adds a 5th player.  what's not to love.  trading does help and i get up that chart as quickly as i can, again all dependent on our my opponents play.

RATING: 7
This is almost the archetype of worker placement games: your playing pieces are action points and you take turns placing them among the menu of options. The board is a nicely painted bird's eye view in vaguely isometric perspective and has enough little details to distract from it's abstract nature. After a number of plays, I've managed to perfect a losing strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
[i]Gameplay depth[/i] [b]8[/b]
[i]Immersiveness[/i] [b]7.5[/b]
[i]Elegance[/i] [b]9[/b]
[i]Aesthetics[/i] [b]10[/b]

Stone Age has no real flaws and would be my example of an all-round game. It has enough depth to be strategic and therefore appeals to seasoned players, but appeals to newcomers as well through its relative simplicity and its elegant design. All this is further complemented by stunning artwork and component quality. Stone Age features the best looking board I have ever seen, and even includes a high quality leather cup to roll dice with. Despite this, while adequate, theme is probably its weakest aspect, with the worker-placement and dice-rolling mechanics being both the most prominent and the least thematic aspects of the game. Nonetheless, Stone Age is a very good and enjoyable game for a wide audience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great worker placement game that is simple enough to teach to new gamers, but has enough meat to it to be appealing to seasoned gamers.  I really appreciate that there are various parts of the game you can focus on to try to achieve victory so that now every game is the same. Theme is very strong in this game.  WARNING - If you do not like dice, do not play this game!

I also own the expansion:  Style is the Goal

RATING: 7.5
The first thing that strikes you when you set up this game is the artistry of the game board, tiles, cards, etc.  It definitely leaves a positive first impression when you see the attention to detail that went into the graphic design.  As for the game play, it is a pretty straight-forward take on the now-popular "worker placement" genre, and I do enjoy its relative simplicity and the multiple paths to victory.  And yes, I even enjoy the random element of dice rolling for the resources, since it adds a bit of excitement and risk/benefit analysis when determining the number of workers to place.  Over-all, its a decent, well-designed game that I would definitely play again but don't enjoy quite enough to go out and purchase.  Game design:  4.5/5  Personal enjoyment:  3/5  Total:  7.5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My introduction to worker placement and still a game I greatly enjoy. For its weight, I am not sure what game does WP better (though I haven't played Lords of Waterdeep yet).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This should be the poster-child for spreadsheet game: take turns incrementing values in columns A and B, calculate column C as A*B, then sum it at the end of the game. Insofar as there is any excitement, it is intended to come from exclusive worker placement -- oh no, the first player has added one to cell A2 and now I can't! -- and from the fact that resources are harvested via dice rolling. (As though I needed to care less about who won.)

There's a smidgeon of development (one of the rows is additional workers, and one lets a player modify the harvest dice), a frisson of pain (pay 1 food per worker per round or lose points), and a minor set collection element, but the game as a whole is an extremely slight and unbearably dull exercise in choosing between options running the gamut from tolerable to acceptable.

Like the other big Bernd Brunnhofer designs, the theme is so shallow that the (primary school) maths shows through, but this time it lacks the tension of St. Petersburg or even the combination of spatial blocking and engine building in Pantheon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sort of Agricola, but lighter and less unforgiving. If you feel Agricola is like playing football in a phone booth (which isn't properly a bad thing), this might be your pick.
The only downside is the techs and buildings feel a little dry, I wish I could build the Granary or the Temple instead of the 12vp-1stone-2wood-hut.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Light Euro/family that uses dice as resource gathering tool.

+ Light - Simple compared to other Euros.
+ Artwork - Fantastic as with most of Menzel's art.
+ Different strategies - Choose between card goals or hut building or combine both.
+ Thematic - Most mechanics well fitted to theme.

- Random - Too many bad rolls can mean disaster.
- Card balance - Some cards are simply broken compared to others. This imbalance irritates me most. One card gives x3 modifier to your hut count, another x1, with no other differences. I find this design flawed.

RATING: 7
[RGG 'Stone Age' 08 edition w/ Spielbox-Almanach expansion hut tiles] {Civilization; dice-rolling, resource management, utility cards; optimal 4p}  Stone Age is a great family gateway game.  It has a nicely executed theme.  It's intuitive enough to learn.  The strategy is clear enough that players shall have no difficulty in understanding what's happening in the game.  And, players shall know what to do next or what actions/resources to choose.  In addition, scoring happens occasionally - most players would have a rough understanding about the game progress.  Nonetheless, the civilization cards give some hidden score so that the game keeps engaging until the end.  Luck is not very strong, even though dice are heavily used.  Stone Age is sort of multifaceted but I think civilization cards are just too important to be ignored.  The game time is approximately 60 minutes, which is suitable for family games.

There is much player interaction; especially with 4 players. Players have to compete for resources, civilization cards, huts, etc.  And, players need to pay attention for what other players are doing; otherwise, they would slip away golden chances to the opponents to get scores.

The component quality is real nice.  The people meeples are nicely shaped.  The illustration of cards and board is colorful.  The cards and huts are informative enough.  The resources tokens are nicely shaped!  However, the packing is real stupid - I have to cut the box insert to put in the player boards nicely.

This is one of the great gateway games.

RATING: 9
Erano tempi duri. I nostri antenati lavoravano sodo, sforzando gambe e schiena con l’aratro di legno nella terra rocciosa. Per fortuna il progresso non si è fermato all’aratro di legno: gli uomini hanno sempre cercato utensili migliori e piante più produttive per migliorare la resa del proprio lavoro. I giocatori rivivono questa epoca e, come fecero i nostri antenati, raccolgono la legna, lavorano la pietra e setacciano i fiumi in cerca d’oro. Commerciano liberamente, espandono il proprio villaggio e, in questo modo, raggiungono nuovi livelli di sviluppo e civilizzazione. In questo avvincente e affascinante gioco, dove la fortuna è ben bilanciata dalla strategia, i giocatori sono in competizione per le risorse e per il cibo. Rischia e cresci, come fecero i nostri antenati: solo in questo modo la vittoria ti sorriderà!

Elenco elementi di gioco
1 Mappa da gioco
4 Tessere Territorio del Clan
68 Risorse in legno
40 Pedine in legno
53 Tesserine Cibo
18 Tesserine Utensile
28 Tessere Edificio
36 Carte Sviluppo
8 Segnalini in legno
1 Segnalino Primo giocatore
7 Dadi, 1 Bicchiere in cuoio
1 Regolamento
1 Foglio di spiegazioni per Le carte Sviluppo

RATING: 7

RATING: 5
Interesting game, but I dislike how much dice rolling and luck there is in it. Would be more fun if there were more paths to victory, but there seem to be only a few dominate strategies that always win out.

EDIT: After more plays I don't mind the dice rolling so much as it averages out over the course of the game. However, player turn order with no control over it is very problematic. The "roll one per player and everyone takes one" is very dependent on turn order. Same for a lot of other action spots and cards which just come down to being unlucky in turn order. If there was a way to control turn order I'd probably rate the game a 6, but without that it pushes it below average to a 5.

RATING: 1
Mind numbingly unmeasurable game
First play I thought, yeah I like this.
But you cannot tell who is winning until the final count up.
After more plays you realise this inability to know whether you are winning, or not, begins to hollow out your soul. All the thinking and agonising and just not knowing.
For the masochist or those who dont care whether they win or loose as long as they can disrupt an opponents intended play. Very much for the sado/masochist.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Worker placement dice roller set in pre-historic times. The game is based around the collection of resources, which is achieved by sending workers to various areas (forest, quarry, hunt etc). Once all workers have been assigned to an area dice are rolled depending on how many workers have been placed in an area and this determines how many resources are acquired. The object of the game is to survive by collecting enough food for the workers but also gaining points for constructing huts with the resources and gaining point from cards that can also be obtained. The game is interesting enough but you never get far away from the realisation that you're depending on quite a lot of luck when rolling dice for resource production. It's solid, straightforward and nothing special. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent worker placement game.  Simple concepts with hard decisions.  Love it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game is often pitched as a non-gamer or gateway game. That's true in every aspect except for all the iconography on the huts and civilization cards, which makes quickly understanding the game a lot harder. 

Being a newbie boardgamer as of writing this, I have found as a personal preference that I don't like game mechanics where the first round plays more or less like the last one and you mostly gather "useless" victory points. Stone Age has this mechanic. Yes, there are upgrades but the base gameplay is the same on all turns.

Another small minus is the high amount of victory points which can reach up to more than 200. For some that might be a plus as tension is kept up until the end after all points are counted but I'm more fond of a much smaller range of victory points.

All in all still a good game though, especially if my dislikes don't put you off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played 3+ times.  Definitely a dice game, but you can do things to minimize the effect of the luck.  Definitely tactical elements surrounding getting people and fields.  My right hand neighbor LOVED fields and I only ever got them when going first, he had twice as many fields as I by the end, very frustrating, I wasted many actions hunting while he actually ended up making food on the last couple turns.  He beat us soundly with ~230 while second through 4th were in the 170-160 range.  

Totally unrelated question: Is there a first player advantage?  2008/11/05  **UPDATE**  I don't enjoy playing this.  I don't really dislike it but I would rather play something else.

RATING: 6.5
Good lightweight Euro game. Has everything a euro should have: limited workers + a mechanic to get more, limited actions where you try to be first to, resource gathering, bonus conditions, multiple strategic paths to victory, meaningfull tactical choices.

Cannot really rate this well as I only played one two-player game. Everything did work, but it doesn't really shine as a two player game as the game 'shut down' a lot of options leaving something to desired for complexity. Will try this out with 4 as well, I'm guessing it will be much, much more interesting while staying lightweight.

Together with Alien Frontiers, this one is highly recommended as a gateway Euro!

[SEP 2016] Traded it off, as it simply is not engaging enough, even playing 4. Too friendly, not constricting enough lets you cruise through a game without feeling challenged or really engaged.

RATING: 8
Stone Age is a fantastic game.  It plays casual or tense if you want it.  You don't get screwed too bad on a turn because there are so many options.  Beautiful board and pieces.  Plays in a respectable amount of time. This will always stay in my collection. 

I will say that the fun of dice rolling will turn against you at critical moments unless you can minimize the risk involved.  If you must have perfect information, then you better stay away.

RATING: 6
Seems like a hodge podge of typical euro games: rolling dice, collect cards for pts, construct an abstract tribe of wood/stone/gold gatherers to generate victory pts. etc. Somehow it all sort of works. The die rolling is more a calculated risk and doesnt seem to detract. What I dont like and feel will shorten the lifespan is that you have to know what is on the civilization cards  and when to take them. This may become formulaistic and take the fun out of the game. Play time is a little long for the amount of real decisions/excitement.

RATING: 8.9
WOW! I love this game! First of all, it looks beautiful. The art work is absolutely superb on the game board and cards. The components are excellent - all the tribes people,little logs, clay bricks, chunky stones and bars of gold are really delightful. Game play is quick and easy to pick up and plays in 60 - 90mins which is a great time slot for gaming with Emma my wife after work. Decisions are plentiful but not too brain burning which makes this very accessible for younger players or non-gamers but strategies are subtle and varied depending on opponents and circumstances. This means replayability is high. This is probably my favourite game right now and I can see me playing this reguarly for the foreseeable future. (24/8/08)

RATING: 9.5

Very popular with my game group and family.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Worker Placement at its best!
Gorgeous theme and artwork, and good materials. I just love that!
It's not too heavy, but still strategic. It's in a really good spot for a family game.
Some people say the dice rolling for gathering resources is too random, but I think it fits the theme: Life is hard in the stone age! And there are enough ways to mitigate the dice rolls.
I think the game is more about enjoying the theme than about playing competitively.
There aren't many games out there that contain a "love shack"! ;)

in short:
++ theme
++ gorgeous artwork and illustration
+ mechanics
++ great materials (You even get a leather dice cup!)
- game balance problems (e.g. turn order with weaker players, start player advantage, swingy cards, ...)

RATING: 10
A szabály alapján sokkal bonyolultabbnak tûnik, mint amilyen valójában. De egyszerûsége ellenére a játékélmény jó. Egyre jobban tetszik...
Tény hogy a játékban ha valaki rááll valamilyen kombinációra sokat nyerhet a játék végén a civilizációs lapokkal. Azonban pont ezért jó hogy a játékosok büntetlenül lefoglahtanka helyeket mások elől, mert így a játékosok rá vannak kényszerítve arra, hogy másokra is odafigyeljenek.

2011.07: Pont abban áll a játék nagyszerűsége, hogy nagyon oda kell figyelni a többiekre: el kell előlük happolni azokat a civilizációs kártyákat, amelyekkel nagyot kaszálhatnak

2011.08 Pontosítom az előző kijelentést. Nem lehet elvenni mások elől azokat a lapokat amikkel ők jól járnának, hiszen nem éri meg. Az egész játék arról szól, hogy a játékosok ráállnak valamilyen "témára" (házak számának szorzói, emberek szorzói, stb) és melyikük "kombója" fog több pontot hozni. Szerintem civilizációs kártyák nélkül nem lehet megnyerni ezt a játékot, de a civilizációs kártyák gyűjtése mellett nem szabad lemaradni nagyon a pontozósávon. Kiegyensúlyozott játék esetén (amikor minden játékos nagyjából egy szinten van) a zöld civilizációs kártyák szinte biztos győzelmet jelentenek, ha a játékos össze tudja gyűjteni az összeset de még 7-tel is jó esély van arra hogy nyer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Awesome artwork and I love the theme. On the high level, this is a "Gather-Resources-And-Spend-Them-For-VPs" game. I like how you Gather Resources; you allocate X guys to the Forest to gather Wood, and then roll Xd6. Divide by 3 (For Wood) and that's the number of Wood you gather. This adds a Risk Management aspect to gathering resources - should I allocate 3 guys in the Forest to guarentee at least 1 Wood, or should I risk it and allocate 1 guy and hope to roll 3+ on a 1d6? Also like the aspect of growing your tribe and feeding them - the larger the tribe the more you need to feed them. What I didn't like about - the "Huts" which you purchase for VPs. These simply denote Resource combis to earn VPs - there are no special abilities, no effects, nothing when you build a Hut apart from earning VPs. I'd have liked it if different types of huts gave you different types of abilities, like say a Woodcutter's Hut gives you a +1 to your dice rolls in the Forest, etc. Also didn't like the "hidden bonus VPs" which come into effect at the end of the game. To make things worse, these are multipliers which double, triple, quadruple, etc. your score in a certain aspect (eg. Bonus VPs = the number of meeples you have x 2). These add a HUGE number of VPS to players at the end, so much so that the end scores tend to be fairly skewed.Overall, it's a nice game with great artwork, but I felt that "spend resources for VPs" parts of the process to be fairly flat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2009 Secret Santa

RATING: N/A
Xmas 2009
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pillars done right. No programming of stages: the game doesn't need it since more powerful cards just can't be used to full effect early on. Many paths to victory: freeing meeples by increasing food production or producing more meeples ("When two meeples who love each other very much go to the love shack....") Concentrating on green-bottom cards. Concentrating on one or a couple sand-bottom cards. Combinations of the previous. One cannot control the game using resources as can be done with Caylus or CMC: the problem is converting all your resources to points--it usually cannot be done close to exactly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
If you've played other worker placement games and disliked the fact that you can count on what resources you'll come away with, then this game is for you. Two players putting the same number of workers on the same spot can walk away with pretty different outcomes for resources. Since these resources turn in to points, there's a whole game that has the final outcome decided by random rolls. Oh sure, your strategy will help you along, but your die rolls become the random kingmaker.

FEB 2009 - Played @ EGG 2009 - This is a great light- to medium- weight resource management game. I think it's likely to be more accessible to new gamers and kids than the more typical Euro fare. I've played twice so far and love it. Downtime is low and there's lots to do, even if someone takes your first choice. Many options for paths to victory here!

03 APR 2009 - Played this with the kids and had a blast! Bumped up my rating from 8.75 to 9.25. Love the bits, love the options, plays pretty quickly, just all around fun!

Soriano
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like this game. The artwork is beautiful and there are multiple valid strategies to follow. For me, the civilization cards are what makes this game so cool. They are so important for strategy reasons, and they make a HUGE impact on final scoring. Civilization cards seem to make up about half of the final score and that score is kept secret until the game is over. As an archaeologist I love the theme of this game. Wood, clay, and stone are the three most used resources in this game and that's pretty accurate for hunter gatherers. I also like how improving tools is important for increasing resource yield and how during the game you make a transition from hunting/gathering to agriculture.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
[Updated] Lowered the rating - I don't like that the game is cheating by trying to pretend it has multiple resources when they have the exact same conversion rates from dice to VP. The core of the game is: roll the dice, get some  resource of only one type then use it to buy VP.
I am still surprised how many people are suckers for a dice leather cup and a pretty board!
Linear (each turn is identical, there is no overall goal to the game), simplistic (all resources feel the same).

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
For me, a bit too light weight and the randomness of the dice (even with mitigation) does clash a bit with the fact that it is a strategic euro. But despite this, it still works. There is still enough interesting choices and replayability/strategic growth to keep me intrigued. It's fun, tense and I like the hut tiles and scoring cards. Stone Age has a great flow to it and ease of play, and really is a great 'gateway' euro. It gives a great intro into economic management, particularly with the risk taking aspect of worker upkeep and the dice (though this kind of sets Stone Age apart from more static euros) as well as coupling this with points gathering. The theme also works well with the gameplay. It's not hard to see why Stone Age is loved as much as it is.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent worker placement game, wish the manufacturer would re-make the expansion

RATING: 10
I played this four times at the 2008 Gathering of Friends and purchased it the same week (which says something, since I purchase games very selectively these days). I found Stone Age to be quite engaging. I tend to rank games that really grab me a bit low with the intention of bumping up the rating if the title stands up to the test of time. I think Stone Age may merit being bumped up to a "9" rating and a spot in the ranks of elite games in my collection ... if the large swings in luck inherent in all dice games don't someday sour my in ititial, very favorable reaction. Note: After many, many plays of Stone Age, it hasn't lost any of its luster. Rating bumped up to 9, making this one of the elite games in my collection. Update ... now one of fewer than 20 games out of 900 I've rated that scores a 10. However, I've found some averaging dice (with the numbers 2-3-3-4-4-5) that I use with Stone Age to smooth out the luck, which can unbalance the game at times.

RATING: 8
I've played this three times now and each time I enjoyed it.  The game length is about just right and I like the fact that I can explain the rules to someone in a manner of minutes.  I'm definitely seeing that the cards are the key to winning.  All in all, a very enjoyable game that I would recommend as a family game.  There is a luck factor (rolling dice for resources) that can have a significant impact on your success in this game so if you are a strategy purest, you won't like this game.  But for what it is, a fairly light, strategy, worker placement game, it fits the bill.

Definitely luck in the roll, but there is still some strategic depth to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Cute game about developing a tribe of hunter/gatherers. Can feel repetitive after several plays. There isn't any real differentiation in resources, and penalties for starvation aren't scaled to the size of your tribe, so ignoring food is a viable strategy...

Replaced by Roll Through The Ages (faster, better randomness) and Agricola (more depth, cuter/stronger theme)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While I enjoyed Stone Age, I feel that it is another incarnation of the worker placement mechanism that is not sufficiently different than previous games (Pillars of the Earth, Cuba, and to some extent, Leonardo da Vinci).  It is a very handsome game, and I will say that I loved the inclusion of the dice, to bring a bit of flavor to the game.  However, in the end, I have seen this game several times before, and in my opinion, it has been done better.  Less complex than either Pillars or Cuba, and especially Caylus, and less rewarding.  Preferred to Leonardo da Vinci (which is itself a ripoff of Princes of Florence).

UPDATE:  Nearly a year after my first play, I acquired a copy of Stone Age in trade.  I knew it would get played quite a bit around here, and it serves as a good counter to Agricola, which can be a bit of a bear to set up and play.  

What I have since found is that, quite surprisingly, Stone Age is nearly the perfect game.  It is not actually perfect, it has flaws and downsides, but the light depth that it carries, coupled with a quick play/teach time is superb.  The dice impact the game minimally, but add to the gameplay immensely.  What do I mean?  

The problem that I have with a good deal of Euro games is that they are so scripted to give the players more control over the game that they tend to become a little (or a lot) stale and lifeless.  Even some of my favorite Euros do not conjure up images of fun and enjoyment, but more images of challenge and mechanical operations.  Stone Age proves that challenge, mechanical operations, fun, and enjoyment can be combined, if even on a slightly shallow level.  Yspahan included dice, and did a good job at making a good game where fun simmered, but did not leap off the board.  Kingsburg was entirely too "you do your thing, I'll do mine" for my tastes.  The way the dice are used in Stone Age is simple, yet can cause for some devilish moments. 

But the game is not all that shallow.  I am sure that there are ways to break the game, to figure it out--I don't care about those ways, and I don't want to know them.  What I do care about is that every single player can play the game from a drastically different angle, and yet still interaction is all over the place, especially in a 2P game.

Is it innovative?  Absolutely not.  Is it polished, yes and no.  Is it interactive?  Most of the time.  So why is it such a great game?  Because it seems like it gets it--the designer has crafted a game that politely steals from several recent games (namely Pillars of the Earth, Cuba, et al) and somehow manages to present a game that works quite well in spite of its similarities.    

One more minor thing stands out:  Stone Age allows players to take buildings/cards, even if they cannot pay for them.  The minor effect is that you can slow another player's game down, stalling them.  The mass effect is that this is a very slight way of making the game cutthroat.  More than that, though, is that if a player is able to stall another player from scoring points in this manner, at just the right time, it can be used to steal something from under another player.  Most Euros prohibit such actions--you are forbidden from taking something that you cannot pay for.  The result of this is that players can play with blinders on, causing a bit of interaction detraction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A worker placement euro with a well intergrated theme. The object is to develop your tribe better than the rest of your opponents. The game allows for different strategies but not all of them are equally rewarding.

The game is amazingly appealing, the production quality has set an unmatched standard in attractiveness. At first I thought the game was uninspiring, but as I played more it grew on me somewhat, only to have it crash down again once I tried most of the strategies.

The main problem is that both the actions and the resources are unbalanced - the second because of the cards. Gathering any resource other than wood is a second class choice - by far. Actually the cheaper the resource, the better - by far. If that was different somehow, it would be a good game. 
Then they could balance the huts with the cards and make it a great game.. Oh well, poorly tested fail. (yes I know, how dare I?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Seemed like something I'd really like at first play.   In fact, the more I think on my experience playing (once) and watching (2-3 times) this game the less enamoured I am with it.  Basically, it doesn't fill any niche better than other games that I own or have access to.  For a Euro with dice, I prefer Kingsburg or Yspahan -- where your decisions about what to do with the dice are actually meaningful.  For a worker placement game, I prefer Agricola, Pillars of the Earth, Keythedral, or even Caylus Magna Carta.  For a family/gateway game, there are many that I prefer.  And to top it all off, the games that I have seen and played all seemed to run longer than desirable for a game of this weight.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A beautiful looking game which makes use of an old but good mechanic, that of worker placement. My only criticism would be that resources toward the end of the game become almost meaningless as you run out of spots to place your neandermeeples. The cards scoring system is almost identical to Oasis. The scoring track is almost useless as at least one player goes well over 100 points even in a four player game. Overall- I love it, even if the player interactivity is a tad on the low side (yet it is probably a high level for a Euro).

**UPDATE**

After a few plays this lost all appeal. It is a very simplistic worker placement game that relies too heavily on end game scoring.

RATING: 5
I simply don't see any reason for this game to exist.  I understand that every designer wants to try his or her hand at the worker placement genre, and some manage to distinguish themselves sufficiently to make them worthwhile, but more often than not they simply end up paling in comparison to the original and greatest worker placement game - Caylus.  Just like Pillars of the Earth which came before it, Stone Age is another worker placement, resource collection, turn resources into victory points game that I can't see ever wanting to play when I could just as well be playing Caylus.  The added randomness of Stone Age is a downside in my mind, as is the scoring of the artifact cards (reminiscent of the aristocrats in St. Petersburg or markets in Hacienda).  I didn't like that scoring progression in those games and don't like it in Stone Age either.  I simply don't understand why games like this and Pillars of the Earth exist.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
One play, 4p.  I had fun, but really hated the randomness of dice.  I felt bad for my hubby rolling two 1's with his two meeples on gold, while I rolled a 25 with five meeples on food.  In this game the number of pips you roll seems to directly correspond with points for any resource except food, so it seems easy to get screwed by the dice gods.  I would like to see this game with the rolling randomness removed - i.e. how about each meeple is worth 3?  Could be fun, could be boring.

RATING: 6
Good gateway game for worker placement games. Theme is nice, components are good quality and board is beautiful. There are also many balanced ways to win the game and rules are very elegant. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
love this game, and find it nearly perfect as a 2, 3, and 4 player.

(especially with expansion)

It's got that great mechanism of mitigating randomness, where you can play things fairly safe and stockpile some resources, or push a bit of luck when the payoff is worth the risk. Plus, it has a great balance between tactics (grab that while it's available!) and strategy (go for all tool-based bonuses and push for it no matter the cost). 

We find the expansion balances out all the strategies well, bringing a basic building strategy into contention (with low cost buildings and more builder bonus cards) plus allows for clever play using the trading track.

I honestly cannot find a fault with the game other than it's over-long with 5 players. The only reason not to play it repeatedly is that my other games will get jealous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Some complain that getting resources relies on the roll of the dice too much, but this doesn't bother me at all.  It would be boring if there wasn't any randomness, and there are ways to mitigate that randomness here.  Overall, it is engaging and satisfying.

RATING: 10
The only flaw in this game is it's expansion.  I wish they'd just added a 5th player and nothing else.  Other than that, the base game is definitely board gaming perfection.  You can strategically push people out of resources, yet if they're savvy enough, they can find a way to block you.  You will never run away with a game, unless your opponents let you.  You will always have to win by optimizing your resources better than your opponent.  Yet you do have some luck results with the die, but not to the point where you felt the die roll was the reason anyone won.  PERFECT GAME!!!

RATING: 6
This definitely makes for a good gateway game and family game. With two people it's quick but there is usually a large gap between the number of points for each player (for us at least, maybe I am just bad at this game).
Buying huts feels a bit pointless - they only give you points, no special abilities. Definitely a lightweight game for a euro, with a bit of dice thrown in to make it a bit more random

If there were for example three full sets of 5 cards it might feel a bit more balanced, but basically for us whoever buys the most green cards wins

I am keen to try the expansion, which adds better tiles (e.g. the personal wood camp @1:2)

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Players struggle to survive the Stone Age by working as hunters, collectors, farmers, and tool makers. As you gather resources and raise animals, you work to build the tools needed to build your civilization.
Players use up to 10 tribe members each in 3 phases. In the first phase, players place their men in regions of the board that they think will benefit them, including the hunt, the trading center, or the quarry. In the second phase, the starting player activates each of his staffed areas in whatever sequence he chooses, followed in turn by the other players. In the third phase, players must have enough food available to feed their populations, or they face losing resources or points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The best gateway game.  

Once you are good at it, becomes a math exercise, which is interesting.  It then revolves around clever placement and a race to get the cards you need and stop your opponents from getting their cards.  Still worth playing here and there.  

This one shows newbies that games have decisions within your control.  How many workers you place shows how many dice you get.  Easily infuse the decisions with value.

RATING: 8
Good game, quite similar to Pillars Of The Earth. Still not sure if it is worthwile to have both games in your collection. I do like the addition of dice and dice modifiers in this game, and after watching a player claim victory after some really bad die rolls, I am convinced that the amount of luck they introduce is not overbearing.
UPDATE: Played again after several years and really liked it. Components are great, the artwork is inviting and the rules are very accessible. It also scales quite well with 2 to 4 of players. It has more replayability and less randomness than POTE, so I generally like it better! If played with its expansion (the new huts and the talisman), the game is a solid 9 for me.

RATING: 7
11/2010:7
Mixed feeling about this game. I like it and enjoyed playing it even though it was with two and I can see how the game would be more tension-filled with a couple more players. However, two major quibbles...worker placement is fine, but each of those resources do not feel unique enough. Yeah, sure, for buying huts, it seems important, but after that, the different types of resources are quite useless. If you go just for resource card strategy, might as well take wood all the time. The second major boo boo for me is that some of those actions are WAY too important and powerful and seems to be taken first almost every turn. Also, unlike Agricola, food seems very easy to come by. Overall, the game still remains fun. I am not sure if this game will have longevity but it is a decent gateway game.

Nov 2010 update: Still a decent gateway game but it feels really repetitive after a while. It also seems to drag quite a bit. Can have runaway issues midway when your resouce engine is up and going.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I seem to like the lighter side of the worker placement games.  Games like Caylus and Agricola wear out their welcome for me.  There is just too much to decide between.  I prefer the games with a move fixed set of decisions, like Pillars of the Earth and now Stone Age.  Several people have said that they like this better than Pillars.  Their main objection to Pillars has been with the luck of the worker placement draw.  The luck in this game is better controlled, but Pillars has more flavor.  Since I don't really object to the luck in Pillars, I still give it the edge.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Worker Placement, multiple paths to victory... but tends to push everyone towards a similar score, assuming you realize the value of the cards.  Biggest oddity is that, mathematically speaking, everyone that grows their family at all should intentionally starve it (-10 points a turn) for the majority of the game,  because the pip-cost of points retained by expending food exceeds the pip-cost of points that could be gained elsewhere.  not a "flaw",  but the game will be almost exclusively won by those who try to starve their families, and that's probably not the intent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great game that pleases a variety of gamers.  I confess that I don't like that the starvation strategy is viable, but I'd rather just not use it than try to change the rules to work around it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: classic gateway game with worker placement mechanic integrated with dice rolling, great theme, good art

Cons: no direct player interaction, limited winning strategies, lengthy playtime for what it is, relatively non-thematic, arbitrary victory point system

While I love the theme, there are just too many little quirks about this game that I dislike. I personally desire more strategic options than simply choosing between going after the civilization cards or building. I don't mind similar dichotomies of strategies in other games, but there is something quite bland or anti-thematic about it in this. There is just too much of a disconnect between theme and game mechanics in this one for me, I guess. And I wish the game wouldn't let you feed your workers with resources when out of food. Other than that, the game works great--each decision you make is meaningful, and the effect of the dice is handled in a thematic way. I simply wanted more from this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This one is right up my alley.  Good resource management, with a little luck of the dice throw in.  The limited number of workers in each field allow for a fair amount of screwage while leaving enough viable alternative options available.  Easy to teach and fun to play.

RATING: 7.5
I've played this game A TON. Mostly because it has a really great iOS app. Stone Age is a worker placement game where you are cavemen (or something like that) trying to grow your family, build houses, and learn new technologies. There are definitely a lot of ways to victory which is nice. The game also seems really balanced overall (no major issues with Kingbuilding, analysis paralysis, player elimination). However, I am getting to the point that I've played this game so much, I know way too much to play it with most people. This isn't a bad thing. The fact that I've played this game a ton just shows how great it is. But you can't play any game endlessly and have it still remain the same level of fun. Therefore I'm only giving it a 7.5 for me right now.

RATING: 7
A very uncomfortable first play - the dice hated me - though subsequent plays were better.  It did get me thinking of why I much prefer Kingsburg, and I think it's because in that game, you roll the dice and then decide how best to use them - with poorer rolls bringing first choice - whereas in Stone Age you decide what you would like to do, which can then be denied.  One is opportunity, the other is frustration.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Just a note, I mostly have played this on the iOS app, and on BGA.com.  Only a few times in person.

I like this game, but not as much as most seem to, and I don't see it as such a great gateway game as most believe it to be.

Stone Age feels a little too fiddly with the constantly moving workers around, replacing buildings and boats, and rolling dice on top of it.  I find it cumbersome to teach with all of the multiplication rules.  And after several plays, it feels like you've mostly mastered it, and the game is playing you as you just go through the motions.  Most moves are decided for you based on turn order. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
1st update (Jan 2011)[9]: It's fast, little downtime, but many meaningful choices (at least to an untrained newbie). Faster and more interaction than Agricola, easier to teach.
Downside: As someone who hates random luck in games, the dice may be bad. But you KNOW they are there so you calculate that you might not get what you want, which is good. Perhabs over-powered Civ card (+4 tools), but more plays will tell that.

2nd update (Dec 2013)[8]: I kind of burned out a little bit on this game, though I still believe it is a fantastic game. I haven't played the physical version for several years though, so I ended up selling it.

RATING: N/A
I was so disappointed by this game.  I had very high expectations and there is a very good game in there somewhere but man does it stay way past its welcome.  It has some of the mechanisms of Pillars but don't let that fool you, it is fundamentally a set collection game with dice rolling aspects.  So much of this game depends on what's available when you're the start player.  I truly don't enjoy games which are so heavily weighted to this kind of luck.  In addition to that very significant short fall the game we played went on for well over the 60 minutes it should take which in and of itself maybe too long.  It didn't seem like we were playing terribly slowly which makes me question where that 60 minutes estimate comes from.  I might play this again but unless it plays significantly faster I probably won't give it a third try.

RATING: 5
Update: My husband has now 'broken' the game. He can calculate the dice probabilities/victory point outcomes for every meeple placement decision in the game... in his head in real time. The game has degraded into a competitive 'spreadsheet solve'. I either mathematically calculate optimum meeple placement each turn... or lose... We're going to trade it and buy something he can't break.

Update: Downrated to 5 after additional plays. 

Update: Downgraded again. We now own genuinely good light games...

Very disappointed with Stone Age. The pieces are lovely, but
the scoring system feels opaque so you have no idea who is winning until the end. The theme has no connection to the game and strategy seems to involve mathematical calculations of which cards to pick. 

It's definitely harder to teach than Agricola because of the obscure win conditions. With Agricola, you need to find out HOW to build a better farm. Stone Age is more abstract.

It feels less intuitive than Agricola family rules, significantly less thematic and much less fun to play. No idea why it's seen as a 'gateway' to Agricola.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
 The one new mechanic here is the dice rolling to get resources: you roll one die for every worker you placed in that particular resource region and then divide the total number of pips rolled by the divisor for that resource (for better resources the divisor is higher), and that's how many of the resource you get. This is clever, but everything else about the game is painfully straightforward. The scoring mechanisms are so plain- during the game you literally convert the value of the resources you've obtained to VP at a 1-1 rate; and the end-game scoring consists of having done some set-collecting via card drafting.. yawn. In short, a perfectly functional game I won't object to but will never request. I think the enjoyment here as much as anything else is the excitement of hoping for a good roll of the dice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Basic worker placement. Find it hard to play now with many better in the genre.

RATING: N/A
Bernd Brunnhofer (aka Michael Tummelhofer); solo varient; Category: Prehistoric;  Mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : RioGrande, anglais, année?, #e édition?.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 4 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 1h00 à 1h30.
Éditeur, âge : 10 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu de stratégie mixte (quelques éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné). 
☺ Gateway-game (à mi-chemin entre un jeu tactique ou plus stratégique selon le niveau des joueurs qui s’affrontent).
☺ Jeu familial (pour jeunes et/ou adultes).

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Meilleur : 4
# Recommandé : 3
# Non-recommandé :
# Non-essayé : 2

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
+ Configurations équilibrées selon le nombre de joueurs.
- Déroulement scripté : peut favoriser l’adoption de "scénarios répétitifs" d’une partie à l’autre.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
Jeu où chaque joueur incarne un chef d’une tribu préhistorique qui envoit les membres de sa famille aux différents lieux (à l’intérieur et à l’extérieur du village) pour se procurer de la nourriture ou récupérer des ressources en vue de construire des huttes et développer leur civilisation.

Un des premiers jeux de placement d’ouvriers que je montrerais à des joueurs n’ayant jamais essayé un jeu de ce genre à cause de certaines de ses cases d’actions permettant d’accueillir des ouvriers de plusieurs joueurs ce qui le rend plus abordable pour les nouveaux joueurs (moins restrictifs que les habituels jeux de placement d’ouvriers où 1 case d’action ne peut être occupée que par 1 seul joueur). Cependant, il ne faut pas se laisser berner par cet aspect "gentil" car les parties peuvent aussi être plus "méchantes" selon les stratégies employées.

Stratégiquement parlant, les joueurs qui connaissent celles-ci seront avantagés par rapport aux autres :
1e- Les actions suivantes sont à privilégier : Reproduction, Agriculture, Cartes « Civilisation ». 
2e- Les cartes « Civilisation » étant achetables avec 1 à 4 ressource(s) de n’importe quelle sorte, la récupération de bois devient donc l’action de choix pour se les procurer à moindre effort.
3e- La fin de partie étant déclenchée après la fin d’1 des piles « Hutte » ou à moins de 4 cartes « Civilisation » restantes sur le plateau, un joueur pourrait retarder le déclenchement de la fin de partie en plaçant 1 de ses ouvriers sur celles-ci et en les laissant en place par la suite afin de provoquer un tour de jeu supplémentaire (un joueur s’étant placé sur une tuile « Hutte » ou une carte « Civilisation » n’est jamais obligé de la récupérer même s’il possède les ressources nécessaires).
4e- Une stratégie de blocage peut aussi s’appliquer sur les lieux de ressources afin d’empêcher un adversaire de se procurer des ressources convoitées (dans cette situation, le joueur-bloqueur récupérera des ressources mais cela n’a aucune influence sur la fin de partie puisque les ressources sont considérées illimitées).

À noter que certains commentaires reprochent au jeu que le score en cours de partie n’est jamais représentatif du score final à cause du décompte des cartes « Civilisation » révélées en fin de partie qui vient tout chambouler. Personnellement, cet aspect du jeu ne m'a jamais dérangé mais je laisse à chacun le soin de décider si cela lui convient ou non. Cependant, j’ai remarqué que lorsque des nouveaux joueurs affrontent des habitués, les nouveaux joueurs restent motivés tout au long de la partie puisqu'ils n’ont pas sous les yeux les hauts pointages des habitués pour leur rappeler qu’ils sont moins performants.

►JEU(X) COMPARABLE(S) ESSAYÉ(S):
Bien que j’ai aussi joué à d’autres jeux utilisant une mécanique de placement d’ouvriers, aucun d’entre eux ne me semble assez comparable pour l’instant puisqu’ils sont plus complexes et/ou restrictifs (ex : Agricola, Caylus, Village).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As you start setting the game up, you may ask yourself, "Is this Pillars?", namely because the way you put out the resources, and the way you place your workers to take them, are pretty similar.  The differences really end there, since at that point the dice add a different random element that, really, is a little more palatable than drawing pawns out of a bag.  At least you have some control over your odds, with being able to place a number of peeps to correspond to the number of dice you roll.  There are fewer options to choose from in this variation of the game, but there seems to be something less dry about the end result.  Go figure.  It helps that there are more than one way to get VPs in the game, though, meaning you can try different strategies each time you play, whereas with Pillars, you have to pretty much use your craftsmen to earn VPs.

The 2-player game is pretty good, too.  Some of the actions become unavailable after a certain point, and only one player can place to a particular resource site, so there's a lot of potential for screwage.  There's definitely more of a chance that someone will pick a building, but not be able to build it.  There are so many different ways to score points, and they seem to be balanced so that the game is always close.

2 plays: 2 players
1 play: 3 players
8 plays: 4 players

RATING: 5.5

Edit: re-played this a couple more times on Board Game Arena and downgrading it. The amount of chaos introduced by relying on dice makes it a truly horrible experience when you roll badly two or three times in a row. Will be playing catch up for the rest of the game and usually end up just waiting for the game to end knowing you will lose anyway.

For a better experience I would advise Tzolkin, the Mayan calendar.

RATING: N/A
Players struggle to survive the Stone Age by working as hunters, collectors, farmers, and tool makers. As you gather resources and raise animals, you work to build the tools needed to build your civilization.
\13\\13\
Players use up to 10 tribe members each in 3 phases. In the first phase, players place their men in regions of the board that they think will benefit them, including the hunt, the trading center, or the quarry. In the second phase, the starting player activates each of his staffed areas in whatever sequence he chooses, followed in turn by the other players. In the third phase, players must have enough food available to feed their populations, or they face losing resources or points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Worker placement with dice as risk management mechanism. Almost enough rolls to even out the streakiness of dice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I knew Stone Age was a lighter worker placement game, but it was a lot easier to play than I anticipated.  We played a 2P game, and I was a little surprised that neither of us ever seemed to feel strapped for food or resources.  There always seemed to be plenty of opportunities for both, so it didn't feel like there was much tension for fighting over spots to place people.  As a result, gameplay felt a lot more casual and easy-going.  For all of these reasons, I think this would make a great gateway game.

UPDATE:  Played this 3P and 4P and there was a bit more contention for resources.  A great time at any player count!

*Also own iPad version* Great implementation!

RATING: 8
Count me among those who freaked out when I saw that many dice. However, the system of adding pips rather than taking each die at its value goes a long way toward mitigating the screwage factor, and adds an interesting twist to the worker placement mechanic by not guaranteeing you'll end up with something for each person you place. I like that there doesn't seem to be a single dominant strategy. It does run a little bit longer than I'd like (it can take as long as a game of Agricola, and I think that one is a little deeper), but it's certainly not boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A very conflicted rating, at the moment.  I had a lot of fun playing this game, but the post-game (mathy) analysis turned up a lot of oddities, like the utter domination of agriculture over baby-making.  Coming to BGG, we discovered the imbalance was even greater than we figured.  Unbalanced actions aren't inherently a problem, of course, and often add interesting trade-offs and decisions, but agriculture seems so wildly over-powered that it's a bit suspicious.  Very anxious to see how this plays now that we're all a bit wiser.  If it's still fun, the rating will definitely go up.

RATING: 8.6
Отличная игра для всей семьи. Очень приятна на глаз и на ощупь. Голове тоже есть где себя применить. Игра бесконфликтная, каждый "роет свой огород" и в финале все подсчитывают свои победные очки.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yes, it can be luck-driven, but this randomness goes hand in hand with excitement. There's just enough depth and strategy in this game to satisfy both beginners and advanced players. And it looks gorgeous! 

The downside is that the resolution of actions may take a while and it's hard to estimate who is actually winning - there's a ton of points to be scored from cards at the end of the game. You might feel that you are doing ok throughout the game only to be crushed during final scoring. 

Nevertheless, this is probably the ultimate gateway to the world of worker placement games. Highly recommmended! It's not a strategic masterpiece, but if you treat it as a light, fun euro (which it is) you'll have a great time with it. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The amount of resources you got from your workers are determined by the dice. It has a nice fluid game system and seems to be an excellent gateway game for worker placement style games ..

RATING: 8
Pretty board,  nifty dice cup.  Very good worker placement to convert resources into VP game.   Playing ran a little long though - a bit of downtime since it's player at a time after the worker placement,  and there's a bit of light math with the addition/division.  Seems like there's resilience to both group-think and strategies - I played two games collecting the technology cards and got to over 200 points,  whereas a game where people pushed hard at building huts scored barely over 100 points.I'm impressed that the randomness stares you in the face - look at all those dice! - but there's just enough control to feel that you can earn your victory regardless - it feels like a strategic game!  Maybe because there's randomness everywhere and fluid valuation changes all the time,  it really feels like long term strategies combined with tactical optimization.  Rating has increased.Update: Seems to be holding up well to analysis...and I'm doing a lot of thinking on this one.  Lots of 3 and 4er games on BSW,  definitely plays well with those numbers.  Curious as to how 2er plays...Already wishing for a 5-6 player expansion...the only niggle about this game is that round to round things are pretty much the same.  Maybe some really big things to shoot for on an expansion board...although given that the box is already overflowing,  not sure where the expansion would go... (Maybe it could come with a bonus replacement insert!)

Dinged it half a point for length due to repetitive nature.  Otherwise,  excellent!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good gateway that I'll play if it hits the table though prefer something deeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The definitive "how to worker placement" game. 

It has dice which mitigates experienced players ability to edge out and alienate new players. It has resource gathering and card/set collecting which translates well into many other games.

This is the ultimate light to medium weight gateway game. 

Plus the theme is neat and it looks good laid out on the table.

Excellent game from a teacher's standpoint.

RATING: 8.42
Worker placement game; grow your tribe, plant crops food a steady food supply, craft tools to help your workers, gather resources, build huts and recruit specialists (for points at the end of the game).  The mechanics have been kept surprising simply, yet it still feels quite involved when playing it, which is a nice balance to strike.  There is a luck-based element but it seems to average out nicely.  The artwork on the board is fun.

RATING: 6
I don't like that there is almost no progression in the game - the buildings come out randomly and the only change over the course of the game is the number of workers you have and the number of tools. These do impact your ability to do things, but they feel very incremental so the actual actions are a little too repetitive. Add to that the fact that values are not obfuscated or variable enough in the building set collection - there is variation in the action cards and their symbols which plays a big part in the end game scoring, but the collection of resources to build buildings is just not a particularly satisfying loop. Lovely bits and presentation and a light atmosphere make this a mildly fun experience that I can be in the mood for and will be happy to play if someone suggests it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
One of my favourites. Each game is so different and there are so many ways to victory. The dice rolling for resources is great fun and there's this constant feeling of uncertainty when placing your workers down, altough you can easily mitigate the bad rolls with the Tools that you can get throughout the game. 

Usually I try to go for max workers & max food levels and try to get the corresponding cards that give me x times the points for my worker/food levels but some games it's wiser to concentrate on something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
So straightforward, and yet so fun! I was introduced to this game as using the same mechanics as Agricola, which is true to a degree. However, it's a different kind of fun to play. Stone Age felt more forgiving, and seemed to encourage wackiness, which is nice when most of the medium to heavy games are pretty dry. Agricola, on the other hand, put me on the edge of my seat, like, "Will I be able to feed my family or not?" I actually liked Agricola better (with all of one play on each...), but Stone Age does everything right in my book, and would, I think, make a pretty solid introductory game before introducing newbies to Agricola.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Our first 'worker placement'...we found Stone Age to be fantastic as an introduction into the genre.

After a few plays, and other more involved gaming, Stone Age has lost it's initial luster. It is a terrific game in the vein of Ticket to Ride and other gateway games. But unlike Ticket to Ride, there is little to warrent playing this game except when sitting down with new gamers.

It is not a bad game, and it has an appeal. There are simply more worker placement games now that have more depth. Still, we keep this game because it does appeal to new gamers and helps to keep a flow of immigrants to the board gaming hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
Fantastic components and an absolutely beautiful game board.  As you're playing, you are gazing upon artwork--no doubt.  Leather cup adds to theme and is one of my favorite elements of the game.  

Gameplay itself falls a bit flat for me.  I think it's because every turn feels the same.  Roll dice, gather resources or enlarge your family, grab a card or two.  Tension never seems to build. 

I like tension in games, believing it's the lifeblood of gameplay.  The only tension I feel in Stone Age is hoping for particular cards, though even then--not much.  

  
As far as worker placement games go, it seems to be the slickest, most streamlined version of that genre.  Place workers, get benefits, collect your workers.  There is no narrative.  You don't feel as if you are building toward anything.  It is a very pretty victory point machine.  That's it.

For me, though I don't dislike it, it fails to draw.  :( 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
After one play, I like this one a lot.  It's a light-weight Agricola, sort of.  So it's a little quicker to play, and has a similar but simpler worker placement mechanic.  It also is a dice game, which adds both randomness and drama.  It's more fun to play than Agricola (because it's less taxing), but also is less satisfying to win because of the luck factor.

RATING: 9
A beautiful yet functional board, nice components, dice, and an engaging theme have pushed this game to the top of my favourites.  Every time I play this game I try a slightly different strategy, and no single strategy seems dominant yet.  Maybe I will feed my people food, maybe wood (hehe).  Maybe I will grow my tribe to a massive size, maybe not grow at all.  Tools, fields, cards, huts... so many different paths to take and all equally viable.  I love it. 

Update: After 30+ plays I have begun to tire of this gem but still can't find any faults in it.  Excellent game that has what I like in a euro: some luck, variable strategies, and baby making ;)

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm not sure if I was completely uninterested in this before even playing it because of the theme which is as common as sliced bread or because the group I was playing with was as flat as the Great Plains. Mechanically, this is, without a doubt, a very strong game but the flavor is lacking.

There are plenty of worker placement games that revolve around the concerns of Caucasians before the modern age. Caverna, Agricola, Castles of Burgundy, and Puerto Rico are all thematically similar. Mechanically they may be very different, but the theme does very little to separate them. There is little to none in the way of player interaction, and it ends up just being an optimization 

This would probably be rated higher if I wasn't into LCGs (Legend of the Five Rings) and looking for more thematic and interactive games. Mechanically, its a very solid game and for anyone that is a fan of Euros, I imagine it would be extremely fun. People looking for thematics and player interaction are probably going to pass.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.05
Decent game, GF didn't like it at all tho.

RATING: 9
Описание: Строительство деревушки в каменном веке.
Суть: Расстановка рабочих, сбор ресурсов, небольшая конкуренция между игроками за карты и позиции.
Сложность: небольшая, объясняется за 15 минут.
Игроков: 2-4 одинаково хорошо любым числом.
Тип: стратегия 50%, тактика 30%, удача 20%.
Длительность: 1-1,5 часа.
Оформление: очень хорошее.

Хорошая, красивая, несложная стратегия. Игра с хорошо дозированным элементом случайности. Любимица как новичков, так и ветеранов. Очень хорошее оформление. Не быстро надоедает. Отличная игра на час.

RATING: 7.5
Resource management and worker placement where the more workers you place the higher your odds of getting the goods (or on good rolls, the more goods you get) provided someone else hasn't beaten you to the resources you want.  A very good medium-light strategy game.

My wife suprised me with this for my 30th birthday (wry irony?) and it has been a lot of fun. It can be tense with the unknown score cards, but it certainly lets everyone feel they are doing well.  Best played with 4 but scales alright down to other numbers.
