=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It may be unfair for me to say this, but I keep wanting to call Stone Age a dumbed down version of Pillars.  The game felt very mechanical.  Your first couple of choices every turn will always be the same, with the exception of when the end condition has been reached.  It is obviously pointless to waste a worker on any of the resource space if you can claim a tool that will improve your subsequent rolls as well as giving you VP opportunities.  The same with the spot to improve your agriculture track.  There is zero subtlety here and I hate the constant dice rolling as well as the amount of pointless arithmetic involved.  I can see this being a decent choice for a family game night, but as for me, once is plenty enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nothing exciting just your average worker placement game. It main attraction is that it's quick and easy to get into. Overall a okay but slightly boring game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you are looking for an introductory game to the worker placement mechanic, Stone age is a great choice. There's enough interesting tactical choices that makes this game enjoyable. I'm a fan of the dice rolling in this game - makes it more exciting and stops the gameplay from being deterministic . It adds a fun element of risk management - Do I put two meeples on bricks and risk not getting enough this turn or three to be safe? Bad luck might ruin your plans for one turn, but there are ways of mitigating bad rolls and the luck factor is much less compared to a game like Catan (where a player can have no chance of winning just because of the dice variance) The components and art is gorgeous in this game too! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting choices to make, although some can almost be made on autopilot each turn.  If the dice are constantly cruel to you, there's not much you can do about it, which is something I prefer to see mitigated in interesting ways in dice games.  No, alas, Stone Age pretty specifically and exclusively rewards high rolls at every moment.  That said, the choices make this about the closest thing you could have to a dice-driven Pillars of the Earth with a dash of Agricola and La Città (must... feed... growing... populace).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After 10+ Plays: A good worker placement game when you don't want something as heavy as Agricola or Caylus, and this game is far superior to Pillars of the Earth and Leonardo da Vinci.

After 20+ Plays: I keep requesting this game it it never fails to deliver.  The use of dice is particularly well done in Stone Age.  There are plenty of rolls to even each player's results out over the course of the game, but in the short term players must consider the possibility of low results on individual rolls.

After 30+ Plays: Lowering rating from 9 to 8.  I think I've seen what this game has to offer by now.  It's still fun to play in a comfort food type of way, but after 30 plays I've seen all the game's tricks.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you don't own this game get it now it is fantastic. My #1 game and the only game I currently own that I give a 10 rating.

RATING: 6.5
This is a fun worker placement game. the amount of hidden information is a bit off-putting as, unlike in Agricola, you're never sure how you're doing against your opponents unless you pay really close attention. The effort required to mentally tally all those variables for your opponents isn't worth the effort.

RATING: 8

As for the randomness I feel like you roll so many dice that by the end of the game you dont even remember the times you got bad or good results. RATING: 8.5
My wife and I really enjoy playing this relaxing worker placement game. It's a little like sitting down to read a book together since we're making up a little story of what's happening in our world as we play the game. We usually have a good laugh and the score at the end isn't really a big deal.

RATING: 8
One of the most played games this year. Very well designed worker-placement game. Can be teached very fast and leaves (at least when we played) no question open during play. I also like the dice rolling - it adds some randomness which I prefer to a completely dry game. Oh, also the theme as well as the overall graphic style (especially the board) are great.

RATING: 8.5
The worker placement game with which to introduce anyone to worker placement games. A few actions that are seen as 'the correct place to go' and dice rolls dictating the volume of resources generated hurt it a little, but it really is best in class as a gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Possibly the best (as in, fun) worker placement game I've played to date. Easy enough that we were able to almost play along as we were reading the rules, yet has enough strategic and tactical depth to satisfy all but the most hardcore gamers.

The 2-player rules adaptation turned out to be very good and, while it did change a bit the way the game was played, kept it very enjoyable and balanced.

Would heartily recommend to anyone, especially for family nights boardgaming.

While I'd rather play Agricola, Le Havre or Caylus as far as strategic games are concerned, the fact that this one is faster to play and doesn't cause me AP and brain bubbles from thinking too much is a big plus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
